question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
hint: This patient has manifestations of acute bacterial sinusitis (e.g., fever, headache, foul-smelling nasal discharge). Periorbital edema and abducens nerve palsy suggest the development of cavernous sinus thrombosis, a rare but dangerous complication of acute bacterial sinusitis.
learning_objective: Recall neuroanatomy of the trigeminal nerve and cavernous sinus.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the abducens nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Patients present with the inability to abduct the eye, medial strabismus, and diplopia, all of which are seen in this patient. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

Compression of the oculomotor nerve can result from cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, oculomotor nerve palsy also causes ptosis, mydriasis, and a down-and-out pupil. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

images.title: Bilateral complete oculomotor palsy
images.description: Eyes and forehead of a 20-year-old female patient with tubercular meningitisImage A shows bilateral ptosis, due here to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. To open her eyes, the patient must contract the frontalis muscle, resulting in the forehead wrinkles seen in image B. Both eyes deviate outwards (exotropia) and downwards (hypotropia) from the primary gaze position. This occurs due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are the only unaffected extraocular muscles. Mydriasis indicates involvement of the parasympathetic portion of the oculomotor nerve.Ptosis, mydriasis, exotropia, and hypotropia are the classic signs of complete oculomotor palsy. Complete oculomotor palsy is more commonly unilateral than bilateral.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the trochlear nerve can occur due to cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, trochlear nerve palsy also causes extorsion with an inability to adduct and depress the eye simultaneously. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

Compression of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Affected patients present with an absent corneal reflex and/or impaired sensation in the upper face. Progression of the thrombus results in cavernous sinus syndrome, causing compression of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), and abducens nerve (CN VI).

images.title: Pituitary gland and cavernous sinuses
images.description: The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is surrounded by the left and right cavernous sinuses and the intercavernous sinuses connecting them. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of each cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerves are located towards the lateral wall of the sinuses.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve can be due to cavernous sinus thrombosis, which causes loss of sensation of the midface. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

question_text: A 71-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of lower back pain and no urine output. Medical history is remarkable for Hodgkin lymphoma. Physical examination shows inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is no suprapubic fullness or tenderness. Serum creatinine is elevated compared to 1 week prior. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows retroperitoneal fibrosis, bilateral hydronephrosis, and a collapsed bladder. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 71-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of lower back pain and no urine output. Medical history is remarkable for Hodgkin lymphoma. Physical examination shows inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is no suprapubic fullness or tenderness. Serum creatinine is elevated compared to 1 week prior. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows retroperitoneal fibrosis, bilateral hydronephrosis, and a collapsed bladder. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: This patient's bilateral hydronephrosis and empty bladder suggest urinary tract obstruction (UTO) at the level of the ureters.
learning_objective: Recognize urinary tract obstruction due to retroperitoneal fibrosis, and choose the initial management.

answers.explanation_why: A urethral catheter can be used to bypass a lower urinary tract obstruction (e.g., due to benign prostatic hyperplasia, urethral mass, urethral stricture). Because this patient's empty bladder suggests obstruction at the level of the ureters, a urethral catheter would not resolve the obstruction.

Ureteral stenting is the first-line management of uncomplicated upper UTO. In this patient, retroperitoneal fibrosis due to Hodgkin lymphoma most likely obstructs the ureters, leading to upper UTO. Other common causes include traumatic injury, instrumentation, malignancy, infection, and congenital obstruction. Further evaluation and treatment of the underlying cause are indicated once the acute obstruction has been resolved.

images.title: Urinary tract and vasculature of the testes

answers.explanation_why: Oxybutynin is a muscarinic antagonist commonly used for the treatment of spastic bladder. This patient's anuria and acute kidney injury suggest UTO rather than spastic bladder. Furthermore, oxybutynin can cause urinary obstruction and would be contraindicated in this patient.

Suprapubic catheterization may be used to resolve complicated lower UTO. A catheter is inserted through the abdominal wall above the pubic symphysis directly into the bladder. This patient's obstruction is proximal to the bladder, as noted by a lack of suprapubic fullness and a collapsed bladder on CT scan; drainage of the bladder would not resolve the obstruction.

Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 antagonist frequently used in the treatment of benign prostatic enlargement, a common cause of lower UTO and chronic kidney disease in elderly men. This patient's anuria and elevated creatinine are suggestive of acute kidney injury and his empty bladder on imaging suggests upper UTO due to ureteral compression. Tamsulosin would not be helpful in this situation.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several years of recurrent pelvic pain and constipation. She has increased fecal urgency and a sensation of incomplete evacuation following defecation. She has had no problems associated with urination. Her last menstrual period was 6 years ago. She has had three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. Physical examination shows normal external genitalia. Speculum examination of the vagina and the cervix shows bulging of the posterior vaginal wall during Valsalva maneuver. Weakness of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several years of recurrent pelvic pain and constipation. She has increased fecal urgency and a sensation of incomplete evacuation following defecation. She has had no problems associated with urination. Her last menstrual period was 6 years ago. She has had three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. Physical examination shows normal external genitalia. Speculum examination of the vagina and the cervix shows bulging of the posterior vaginal wall during Valsalva maneuver. Weakness of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: In a multiparous, postmenopausal woman presenting with pelvic pain, constipation, and bulging of the posterior vaginal wall during Valsalva maneuver, rectocele is the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize rectocele, and recall its anatomical cause.

answers.explanation_why: The pubocervical fascia, which is located between the cervix and the pubic bone area, forms part of the anterior vaginal wall. Weakness of this fascia results in a loss of support of the urethra and/or bladder, leading to cystocele and/or urethrocele. Patients typically present with urinary symptoms such as urgency, hesitation, incomplete emptying, and urinary incontinence, none of which is seen here. In addition, fecal urgency and a feeling of incomplete evacuation would not be expected. Moreover, anterior rather than posterior bulging of the vaginal wall would be expected during Valsalva maneuver.

The rectovaginal fascia is part of the fibromuscular structure of the perianal body, and it separates the vagina and the rectum. Acquired weakness of the rectovaginal fascia, e.g., due to multiple vaginal deliveries or low estrogen levels during menopause, can cause herniation of the posterior vaginal wall, which is associated with protrusion of the rectum into the vaginal canal (i.e. rectocele), which can become visible during Valsalva maneuver. Typical symptoms of rectocele include increased fecal urgency and a sensation of incomplete evacuation following defecation. Patients with large rectoceles may report needing to insert their fingers into the vagina to press against the rectovaginal fascia, thereby facilitating the emptying of stool.

First-line therapy consists of conservative strategies, such as Kegel exercises, weight loss, a high-fiber diet, and vaginal pessaries.

The uterosacral ligament travels from the uterus to the anterior wall of the sacrum and fixes the upper vagina and uterus in place. Weakness of the uterosacral ligament can lead to uterine procidentia. This type of herniation can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, uterine procidentia typically manifests with other symptoms as well, including a bulging vaginal mass, urinary incontinence, and vaginal bleeding, none of which is seen in this patient.

The external anal sphincter can be compromised by perineal tearing during traumatic vaginal births. However, weakness of the external anal sphincter would cause fecal incontinence (i.e., involuntary loss of feces) rather than pelvic pain and constipation. Moreover, this patient has no history of complicated vaginal deliveries.

The cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the lateral wall of the peritoneum, providing support to the upper vagina and cervix. This ligament can be injured during hysterectomy, but it would not be affected by multiple vaginal births. Moreover, weakness of the cardinal ligament would not result in rectocele, but rather cause uterine prolapse.

The bulbospongiosus muscle is part of the inferior aspect of the urogenital diaphragm. Weakness or injury to this muscle (e.g., during vaginal delivery) can cause stress incontinence. However, this patient does not have urinary symptoms. Instead, she has defecatory symptoms associated with rectocele.

question_text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
hint: Epigastric pain and vomiting, combined with ST segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF are consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Dissociated P waves and QRS complexes are indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block.
learning_objective: Recognize inferior wall myocardial infarction and its associated ECG changes, and recall the coronary artery anatomy.

answers.explanation_why: The left coronary artery (LCA) branches to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the left circumflex artery (LCX). Occlusion of the LCA can lead to a massive myocardial infarction involving a combination of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), apical (leads I, aVL, V3– V5), and posterolateral (leads II, III, aVF, and V5– V7, and sometimes lead I and aVL) walls. This patient's ECG is consistent with infarction of the inferior wall, which can be supplied by the distal LCX but is more commonly supplied by a different artery.

Occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery (RCA) can cause an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which in turn can present atypically with epigastric pain. High-degree atrioventricular block can occur in this setting because the sinoatrial node (SA node) and atrioventricular node (AV node) are usually supplied by the RCA (the SA node directly, and the AV node via the AV nodal branch). Right-sided leads (V4R, V5R, and V6R) should also be obtained to evaluate for right ventricular (RV) infarction (especially given the patient's jugular venous distention), as the RCA supplies the RV via its right marginal branch.

images.title: Illustration of the coronary arteries
images.description: This image shows the anatomical location of the coronary arteries from a ventral and dorsal view. The left and right coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinus and run along the corresponding coronary sinuses on the caudal side of the heart. The majority of the population has right-dominant coronary artery circulation.

answers.explanation_why: The left circumflex artery (LCX) supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle. Occlusion of the LCX causes ECG changes in the lateral (V5, V6, I, aVL) leads. In patients with left-dominant coronary circulation, occlusion of the LCX causes distal infarction of the posterior descending artery, leading to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and ECG changes in the posterior/posterolateral (V7–V9) and inferior (II, III, aVF) leads. However, the LCX is not the most likely source of this patient's inferior wall myocardial infarction because only approx. 10% of the population is left-dominant.

Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) causes infarction of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), and/or apical wall (leads I, aVL, and V3– V5). The inferior wall is not typically supplied by the LAD. Moreover, although an anteroseptal myocardial infarction can sometimes cause serious arrhythmias, such as a high-degree atrioventricular block (the LAD supplies the left and right bundle branches and partially supplies the left anterior and posterior fascicles), conduction abnormalities are more common following an inferior myocardial infarction.

Occlusion of the posterior interventricular artery would cause a posterior wall myocardial infarction, which would manifest as ST segment depression in leads V1 and V2, sometimes with prominent R waves. Posterior leads (V7– V9) would show ST segment elevation. Epigastric pain is not common in posterior wall myocardial infarctions, nor are conduction abnormalities, since the posterior interventricular artery does not supply the conduction system.

images.title: Posterior myocardial infarction
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Heart rate: ~ 83/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Downsloping ST depression in leads V_2 and V_3 and horizontal ST depression in V_4 (examples indicated by red overlay) is accompanied by positive T waves (examples indicated by blue overlay). This appearance is reciprocal to posterior ST elevations with T-wave inversions.
– Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V_2 (example indicated by green overlay): reciprocal to posterior Q waves
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): rSR′ complex in V_1 and QRS duration of 0.12 sThese findings suggest a posterior myocardial infarction. To confirm, an additional ECG including the posterior leads V7–V9 can be obtained to look for ST elevation, T-wave inversion, and Q waves. Note that ST depression ≥ 0.5 mm in leads V1–V4 is a STEMI-equivalent ECG finding (i.e., management is the same as that for STEMI).

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of episodic chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. He is at the 99^th percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. Examination shows a high-arched palate, long and slender upper extremities, and elbows and knees that can be hyperextended. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. The murmur is most likely to be heard best over which of the following labeled areas?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of episodic chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. He is at the 99th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows a high-arched palate, long and slender upper extremities, and elbows and knees that can be hyperextended. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. The murmur is most likely to be heard best over which of the following labeled areas?
hint: This boy's tall stature, long and slender arms, joint hypermobility (as evidenced by his hyperextensible elbows and knees), and high-arched palate are consistent with Marfan syndrome, an inherited connective tissue disorder associated with ocular, musculoskeletal, and cardiovascular abnormalities.
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall the auscultation location for mitral valve prolapse.

answers.explanation_why: Area A corresponds to the carotid area. Aortic stenosis causes a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that can radiate to this area. Severe carotid artery stenosis can also cause a carotid bruit heard over this area. The murmur most commonly associated with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

Area B corresponds to the aortic area, which is located in the right 2^nd intercostal space in the parasternal line. Aortic stenosis causes a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over this area. Marfan syndrome, which this patient has, commonly causes aortic root dilation and, consequently, aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation due to aortic root disease, an early diastolic murmur is heard over the aortic area during diastole. The systolic murmur in this patient, however, is best heard over a different area.

Area C corresponds to the pulmonic area, located in the left 2^nd parasternal intercostal space. Pulmonary stenosis causes a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over this area. Pulmonary stenosis is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

Area D corresponds to the left sternal border. Aortic regurgitation (AR) due to valvular disease can cause a murmur that is best heard over this area. AR in Marfan disease, although a common manifestation, is due to aortic root dilation, which causes a murmur best heard at the right rather than the left sternal border. Moreover, the murmur in AR is early diastolic. The systolic murmur in this patient is best heard over a different area.

Area E corresponds to the tricuspid area located in the left 4^th parasternal intercostal space. Ventricular septal defects (the most common congenital cardiac defect) can cause a holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur best heard over this area. Tricuspid stenosis causes a diastolic, low-pitched, decrescendo murmur and tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur, both of which can also be heard over this area. The murmur most commonly associated with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

Patients with Marfan syndrome can have mitral valve prolapse (MVP), which causes a late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. This murmur is best heard at the heart apex (mitral area, located at the left 5^th intercostal space in the midclavicular line) when the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. Other cardiovascular abnormalities associated with Marfan syndrome include aortic disease (e.g., aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection) and berry aneurysms.

Marfan syndrome can lead to other musculoskeletal abnormalities, including arachnodactyly and spinal abnormalities (scoliosis and sternal kyphosis). Ocular manifestations can include ectopia lentis (superiorly and temporally), myopia, retinal detachment, and glaucoma.

images.title: Anatomical locations and auscultatory sites for heart valves
images.description:
I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves1. Aortic area: 2^nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).2. Pulmonary area: 2^nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs3. Tricuspid area: 4^th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs4. Mitral area: 5^th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

answers.explanation_why: Area G corresponds to the left midaxillary line. Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur that can radiate to this area, particularly if the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. The murmur most commonly found in patients with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

images.title: Auscultatory sites of the heart valves
images.description:
(A) Carotid area
(B) Aortic area
(C) Pulmonic area
(D) Left sternal border
(E) Tricuspid area
(F) Mitral area
(G) Axilla

question_text: A 33-year-old man is evaluated by paramedics after being found unconscious outside of his home. He has no palpable pulses. Physical examination shows erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on his lower extremities. An ECG shows ventricular fibrillation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man is evaluated by paramedics after being found unconscious outside of his home. He has no palpable pulses. Physical examination shows erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on his lower extremities. An ECG shows ventricular fibrillation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: The fern-leaf pattern on the patient's lower extremities is caused by local hyperemia.
learning_objective: Recognize a lightning strike.

answers.explanation_why: The fern-leaf pattern seen on this patient's lower extremities is also referred to as a Lichtenberg figure, which is pathognomonic of a lightning strike. In about 30% of cases, a lightning strike is fatal; the most common cause of death is cardiac arrest due to a fatal arrhythmia, such as ventricular fibrillation or asystole. Superficial burns and metallization of the skin may also occur after a lightning strike injury.

images.title: Lichtenberg figures
images.description: Faint erythematous cutaneous markings in a fern leaf pattern (Lichtenberg figures; example indicated by arrow) are visible on the lower left leg.Lichtenberg figures are pathognomonic of lightning injury.

answers.explanation_why: Cholesterol emboli, as well as other vascular diseases that cause slower blood flow due to obstruction of blood vessels (e.g., vasculitis, atherosclerosis), can lead to livedo reticularis. However, cholesterol emboli are unlikely to lead to ventricular fibrillation and have a different appearance than the fern-leaf pattern seen here.
Severe hypothermia (< 82°F) can lead to pulselessness or ventricular fibrillation. However, the usual skin finding with hypothermia is livor mortis, rather than the fern-leaf pattern seen here.

images.title: Livor mortis
images.description: Photograph of a deceased patientPurple discoloration of the skin is visible in the dependent parts of the body.This is the typical appearance of livor mortis. The intensity of the discoloration and color depends on the cause of death.

answers.explanation_why: Opioid overdose should always be considered when a person is found unconscious without a known history of present illness or past medical history. Although opioid overdose can result in cardiac abnormalities, the associated skin findings do not appear in a fern-leaf pattern.

Infective endocarditis can cause arrhythmias if a perivalvular abscess forms. Skin findings associated with infective endocarditis include Janeway lesions, splinter hemorrhages, and Osler nodes. However, these skin findings do not have the fern-leaf pattern seen in this patient. Furthermore, severe constitutional symptoms (e.g., high fever, malaise) and progression over at least days would be expected with infective endocarditis.

images.title: Janeway lesions
images.description: Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressively worsening paresthesias in her upper limbs. She has accidentally burned her fingers on hot dishes several times. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Neurological examination shows absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation over the upper extremities and upper chest. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressively worsening paresthesias in her upper limbs. She has accidentally burned her fingers on hot dishes several times. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Neurological examination shows absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation over the upper extremities and upper chest. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Dissociated sensory loss (dysesthetic pain and absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation) occurs as a result of the anterior white commissure compression. This finding in a cape-like distribution (upper extremities and upper chest) indicates a central cord syndrome of the cervicothoracic spinal cord (most likely at the level of the C5–T1 spinal nerves). The most likely cause of the condition in this patient is syringomyelia secondary to a whiplash injury.
learning_objective: Recognize central cord syndrome, and recall the associated clinical finding.

answers.explanation_why: In syringomyelia, damage to the anterior horn cells by an expanding syrinx would cause features of lower motor neuron injury (e.g., hyporeflexia, flaccid paresis) at the level of the syrinx. Since the syrinx is most likely located at the level of the C5–T1 spinal nerves and the anterior horn cells that form the efferent arc of the biceps reflex are located at the level of the C5 and C6 spinal nerves, the patient is at risk of developing a decreased or absent rather than exaggerated biceps reflex. Features of upper motor neuron injury (e.g., hyperreflexia) can occur below the level of the syrinx due to damage to the upper motor neurons in the medial part of the lateral corticospinal tracts.

Syringomyelia does not affect cognition, and therefore, a decreased Mini-Mental State Examination score is not expected in this patient. Conditions associated with spinal cord involvement and altered cognition include subacute combined degeneration (due to vitamin B_12 deficiency) and tabes dorsalis with paralytic dementia (due to syphilis).

The anal wink reflex is controlled by the pudendal nerve and nerve fibers arising from the sacral region, specifically at the level of S3 to S5. The absence of sacral sparing is characteristic of complete spinal cord injury. Patients with incomplete spinal cord injuries such as central cord syndrome typically have sacral sparing (i.e., an unaffected anal wink reflex or bulbocutaneous reflex) because the corticospinal fibers that innervate the anterior horn cells of the sacral segments are located in the lateral-most part of the corticospinal tract.

The trigeminal nerve provides innervation to the muscles of mastication and a unilateral lesion affecting the trigeminal nerve or its motor nucleus can manifest with a deviation of the jaw. The motor nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is located in the pons and is unlikely to be affected by the cervical syrinx. Only the spinal trigeminal nucleus (a sensory nucleus) extends into the cervical spinal cord (up to the C2 level).

Expansion of the cervical syrinx damages the first-order oculosympathetic neurons, which are located just lateral to the central canal and carry descending sympathetic innervation from the hypothalamus to the ciliospinal center of Budge in the lateral horn. Damage to these neurons results in central Horner syndrome, which manifests with ptosis, i.e., drooping of the eyelid (because the superior tarsal muscle is sympathetically innervated), miosis, and anhidrosis.

As the syrinx expands, the patient will develop features of LMN injury at the syrinx's level (due to damage to the anterior horn cells) and features of UMN injury below the level of the syrinx (due to damage to the medial parts of the lateral corticospinal tract).

images.title: Horner syndrome
images.description: Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S_2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of a large patent ductus arteriosus, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
answers.explanation_why: A single overriding great vessel is called a persistent truncus arteriosus. This single arterial trunk arising from the heart provides mixed blood to the pulmonary arteries and the systemic circulation. Pulses may be accentuated and bounding; however, oxygen saturation would be decreased in all extremities. Furthermore, if it is not diagnosed prenatally, it will typically present perinatally with symptoms of global cyanosis and heart failure, while this adolescent patient only has differential cyanosis.

answers.content: Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are often asymptomatic. In adults, larger defects may lead to a distinct left-to-right shunt, which can result in right heart failure, supraventricular arrhythmias, and pulmonary hypertension, and ultimately lead to an Eisenmenger reaction and global cyanosis. Differential cyanosis would not be seen.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
answers.explanation_why:
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to completely close postnatally allows blood to flow from the descending aorta back to the pulmonary artery (left-to-right shunt). In a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), this leads to volume overload of the right ventricle and the lung circuit. This increased blood flow causes pulmonary hypertension and irreversible remodeling of small pulmonary vessels, which may eventually lead to an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). This patient's palpable right parasternal heave and pronounced S_2 are evidence of increased right heart strain. In patients with a large PDA, the features of differential cyanosis occur once shunt reversal develops. Because the ductus is located on the descending aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, reversal of the shunt results in deoxygenated blood reaching only the lower body. Due to the rise in pulmonary pressure, the characteristic continuous machine-like murmur heard in patients with PDA eventually disappears.

Infants with PDA usually receive an infusion of indomethacin to induce closure of the duct, while in older children symptomatic PDAs are typically closed surgically or via percutaneous catheter occlusion. The presence of an Eisenmenger reaction is, however, a contraindication to a PDA closure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
answers.explanation_why: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect is seen in tetralogy of Fallot. The other features of this cardiac abnormality are pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is typically symptomatic in infancy and presents with tet spells and mild cyanosis in all extremities.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus
answers.explanation_why: Abnormal narrowing at the aortic isthmus is consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA), which would cause differential cyanosis if the CoA is severe (i.e., a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect) but this differential cyanosis would be evident from the neonatal period. In addition, patients with CoA have a brachio-femoral pulse delay rather than synchronous pulses. The symptoms of a mild CoA can begin later in life but in such a scenario, differential cyanosis would not be expected. Instead, patients present with features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headaches, epistaxis), lower extremity arterial insufficiency (manifesting with claudication and cool skin with faint or unpalpable pulses, but no cyanosis), and evidence of compensatory collateral arteries (e.g., continuous murmur over the back).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

question_text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a 2-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a 2-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
hint: This patient presents with syncope, orthostatic hypotension (drop of ≥ 20 mm Hg in systolic pressure from supine to standing), and a diastolic murmur over the apex, all of which raise suspicion for an obstruction of blood flow into the left ventricle.
learning_objective: Recognize a cardiac tumor presenting with syncope and orthostatic hypotension.

answers.explanation_why: Stokes-Adams attacks are characterized by a sudden loss of consciousness, usually without warning and lasting for a few seconds. However, these episodes of fainting are caused by an abnormal heart rhythm (especially complete atrioventricular block) and not due to a mechanical obstruction of blood flow.

Aortic valve stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease and may manifest with dizziness and syncope. It should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in an older patient with a heart murmur, such as this one. The auscultatory finding in aortic valve stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the 2^nd right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's rumbling diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.

Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor, commonly located in the left atrium. They may be pedunculated, in which case they often present with position-dependent symptoms of obstructed blood flow through the atrioventricular valves, or they may embolize. Additionally, patients may present with constitutional findings (e.g., weight loss, fever, or anemia). The typical auscultatory finding (also present in this patient) is an early diastolic “plop,” caused by a movement of the mobile tumor mass, followed by a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the apex that results from the obstructed blood flow through the mitral valve, and mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis.

Various drugs can cause (orthostatic) hypotension and may lead to syncope, including alpha-1 blockers. This patient is taking an alpha-1 blocker and presents with orthostatic hypotension. However, among the alpha-1 blockers, tamsulosin is the agent with the lowest potential of inducing hypotension because of its increased selectivity for alpha-1 receptors of the bladder neck and the prostatic urethra. The peculiar heart murmur of a diastolic “plop” followed by a rumble suggests a different diagnosis.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly idiopathic but can also be alcohol-induced. It usually manifests with signs of heart failure. While this patient consumes critical levels of alcohol, and has symptoms that may suggest impaired pump function of the heart (syncope, hypotension), dilated cardiomyopathy does not manifest with a position-dependent diastolic heart murmur.

question_text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department after an episode of dizziness and vomiting followed by loss of consciousness lasting 1 minute. She reports that her symptoms started after lying down on her back to rest, as she felt tired during yoga class. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On arrival, she is diaphoretic and pale. Her pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is lying in the supine position with a fundal height of 36 cm. There is a prolonged fetal heart rate deceleration to 80/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to reverse this patient's symptoms in the future?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department after an episode of dizziness and vomiting followed by loss of consciousness lasting 1 minute. She reports that her symptoms started after lying down on her back to rest, as she felt tired during yoga class. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On arrival, she is diaphoretic and pale. Her pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is lying in the supine position with a fundal height of 36 cm. There is a prolonged fetal heart rate deceleration to 80/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to reverse this patient's symptoms in the future?
hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with supine hypotensive syndrome, which frequently occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava associated with the anatomical changes involved in pregnancy.
learning_objective: Recognize supine hypotensive syndrome in pregnancy, and choose the position to alleviate symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Muller maneuver causes intrathoracic pressure to become more negative, thereby improving venous return to the heart. Although it could be beneficial for this patient, this maneuver would not resolve the cause of her symptoms.

answers.content: Lying in the supine position and elevating legs
answers.explanation_why: Elevating the legs while lying in the supine position increases venous return to the heart. Although it could be beneficial for this patient, this maneuver would not resolve the cause of her symptoms.

answers.content: Gentle compression with an abdominal binder
answers.explanation_why: Gentle compression with an abdominal binder can be used in pregnant patients with back problems. However, abdominal compression can decrease venous return to the heart, which could worsen this patient's symptoms.

answers.content: Lying in the left lateral decubitus position
answers.explanation_why: The left lateral decubitus position is generally recommended for pregnant women when lying down, especially in the third trimester, because this position shifts the uterus away from and thus avoids compression of the inferior vena cava. Compression of the inferior vena cava is the cause of supine hypotensive syndrome, which results in compromised venous return and leads to decreased cardiac output, fetal hypoxia, and prolonged decelerations on cardiotocography, as seen here.

Hand grip maneuver increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload. This maneuver is used for better evaluation of heart murmurs (e.g., mitral regurgitation, aortic regurgitation, VSD). It would not, however, resolve the cause of this patient's symptoms.
Valsalva maneuver increases intrathoracic pressure, thereby decreasing venous return to the heart. This maneuver could worsen this patient's symptoms.

question_text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
hint: This patient's presentation of shock (hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status) after severe blunt chest trauma in the setting of a motor vehicle accident is highly suggestive of blunt thoracic aortic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize injury to the aortic isthmus.

answers.explanation_why: Papillary muscle rupture is a notorious complication after a myocardial infarction and presents with acute hypotension, new-onset mitral regurgitation, and subsequent pulmonary edema. Rapid deceleration injury in a motor vehicle accident is not associated with papillary muscle rupture.

The aortic isthmus, a physiological narrowing at the final section of the aortic arch, is located just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery and is tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. It is the most common site of injury due to blunt aortic trauma because it is extremely vulnerable to rapid deceleration injury, which can occur in motor vehicle accidents when the chest smashes against the steering wheel or is abruptly restrained by the seatbelt.

Management aims to assess the severity of injury and includes a CT angiography in hemodynamically stable patients or a TEE if hemodynamically unstable.

In rare cases, rapid deceleration injury in the setting of a motor vehicle accident can lead to a large aortic tear that extends to the aortic valve. Nevertheless, this is not a common site of injury. Moreover, a diastolic murmur would be heard due to new-onset aortic regurgitation.

Injury to the inferior vena cava may occur in patients after blunt decelerating trauma, but it is extremely rare. Aside from that, the hematoma seen on the patient's chest would not be typical as injury to the inferior vena cava would likely result in retroperitoneal hematoma.

Although the coronary arteries may also be affected together with aortic injury, the absence of ST-segment abnormalities on this patient's ECG makes involvement of the left main coronary artery unlikely.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after undergoing rotator cuff repair surgery. Physical examination of the right shoulder shows decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch over the lateral shoulder. There is normal passive range of motion of the shoulder, but she has difficulty externally rotating and abducting her right arm. Which of the following structures was most likely injured during the surgery?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after undergoing rotator cuff repair surgery. Physical examination of the right shoulder shows decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch over the lateral shoulder. There is normal passive range of motion of the shoulder, but she has difficulty externally rotating and abducting her right arm. Which of the following structures was most likely injured during the surgery?
hint: Injury to this structure can also occur after delayed reduction of an anterior shoulder dislocation.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation of axillary nerve injury.

answers.explanation_why: The radial nerve can be injured by compression within the axilla (e.g., due to crutches), a midshaft fracture of the humerus, or repeated pronation/supination of the forearm. In contrast to the features seen in this patient, radial nerve palsy manifests with impaired elbow, wrist, and finger extension; reduced grip strength; and sensory deficits over the posterior arm, posterior forearm, and dorsal hand.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.content: Upper trunk of the brachial plexus
answers.explanation_why: Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus results in Erb palsy. Paralysis of the deltoid, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus muscles results in impaired shoulder abduction and external rotation, which are both seen in this patient. However, the biceps brachii muscle is also affected, resulting in impaired flexion and supination. Patients present with an extended, medially rotated, and pronated arm. In adults, Erb palsy typically occurs secondary to trauma (excessive traction or tear of the nerves). It occurs most often in newborns as a result of excessive lateral flexion of the head during delivery.

images.title: Waiter's tip deformity in Erb palsy

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the axillary nerve results in impaired abduction (from 15–100°) due to deltoid paralysis, limited external rotation due to teres minor paralysis, and sensory deficits over the skin of the lateral deltoid. Because the axillary nerve circumflexes the neck of the humerus, injury to the nerve from excessive traction or direct injury can result from rotator cuff surgery, fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, or anterior dislocation of the humerus.

images.title: Clinical features of axillary nerve injury

answers.content: Lower trunk of the brachial plexus
answers.explanation_why: In adults, injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus typically occurs secondary to trauma (e.g., an attempt to grab an object to break a fall from a height) and leads to Klumpke palsy. In contrast to this patient's features, it manifests as paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles (lumbricals, interossei, thenar eminence, and hypothenar muscles) and often forearm muscles (flexors of the wrist and fingers; sometimes also the pronators), which classically presents as “claw hand.” Klumpke palsy is uncommon in adults. It is most commonly seen in newborns following a birth trauma (i.e., hyperabduction of the arm during delivery).

Long thoracic nerve injury typically occurs secondary to chest wall injuries and axillary node dissection during mastectomy. Injury to this nerve results in paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, which causes medial winging of the scapula and impaired shoulder abduction beyond 90°. Long thoracic nerve injury would not, however, account for this patient's sensory deficit over the lateral shoulder or the impaired external rotation in her arm.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of jugular venous distention suggests right heart failure, which can manifest with findings such as exertional shortness of breath and chest pain, as seen here. Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause pulmonary embolism, resulting in pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. A mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 25 mm Hg at rest confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, and a normal PCWP (4–12 mm Hg) excludes left heart failure as the cause.
learning_objective: Recognize right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Constriction of the renal afferent arteriole
answers.explanation_why: In cases of systemic hypoperfusion, reduced renal perfusion results in dilatation of the afferent arteriole via myogenic autoregulation and the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, as well as constriction of the efferent arteriole via an increase in angiotensin II synthesis. Afferent arteriole dilation and efferent arteriole constriction then work in combination to maintain a constant GFR despite decreased cardiac output. Right heart failure is a condition that can cause systemic hypoperfusion. For this reason dilatation (not constriction) of the renal afferent arteriole would rather be expected in this patient.

Right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension involves increased afterload of the right ventricle, resulting in reduced right ventricular output. Reduced right-sided cardiac output leads to venous congestion in the vessels that drain into the right heart, including the coronary sinus, which can become dilated as a result.

images.title: Coronary veins
images.description:
The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart. It lies in the left posterior atrioventricular groove and opens into the right atrium.

Main tributaries of the coronary sinus:
- Great cardiac vein: lies in the left anterior atrioventricular groove; receives the anterior interventricular vein that begins at the cardiac apex
- Small cardiac vein: lies in the right posterior atrioventricular groove; receives the right marginal vein and the anterior veins of the right ventricle
- Middle cardiac vein: lies in the posterior interventricular groove
- Posterior vein(s) of the left ventricle: lies to the left of the middle cardiac vein

answers.explanation_why: Decreased left ventricular contractility is the hallmark of systolic left heart failure. Although left heart failure can lead to right heart failure, PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure (> 18 mm Hg). This patient's normal PCWP makes left heart failure unlikely.

Mitral valve leaflet thickening can occur in mitral valve diseases such as mitral stenosis (e.g., due to rheumatic fever). Mitral valve disease usually results in increased left atrial pressure and therefore increased PCWP, whereas PCWP is normal in this patient.

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (heart failure cells) are typically seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary congestion due to blood leakage into the alveolar spaces. Conditions that cause chronic pulmonary venous congestion include left heart failure and mitral stenosis. PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure and mitral stenosis, whereas it is normal in this patient.

images.title: Heart failure cells in decompensated heart failure
images.description: Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a barking cough, a raspy voice, and noisy breathing for the last 3 days. Five days ago, she had a low-grade fever and runny nose. She attends daycare. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) and respirations are 33/min. Physical examination shows supraclavicular retractions. There is a high-pitched sound present on inspiration. Examination of the throat shows erythema without exudates. Which of the following is the most likely location of the anatomic narrowing causing this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a barking cough, a raspy voice, and noisy breathing for the last 3 days. Five days ago, she had a low-grade fever and runny nose. She attends daycare. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) and respirations are 33/min. Physical examination shows supraclavicular retractions. There is a high-pitched sound present on inspiration. Examination of the throat shows erythema without exudates. Which of the following is the most likely location of the anatomic narrowing causing this patient's symptoms?
hint: A chest x-ray of this patient would most likely reveal a steeple sign.
learning_objective: Recognize croup, and recall the location of anatomic narrowing.

answers.explanation_why: Narrowing of the supraglottic larynx in children is typically due to laryngomalacia, which is characterized by excessive flaccidity and collapse of the supraglottic cartilage during inspiration that worsens in the supine position, during crying and/or feeding. Although children can also present with inspiratory stridor, barking cough and signs of upper respiratory tract infection would not be expected. Also, laryngomalacia typically manifests within the first 2 months of life.

Narrowing of the distal trachea (e.g., due to a vascular ring) can also present with inspiratory stridor. The trachea is composed of horse-shoe shaped cartilage rings, which allow the lumen of the trachea to expand if mucosal swelling occurs. However, tracheal compression usually results in severe dyspnea and, in some cases, apnea and cyanosis, which are not present in this patient. Hoarseness and a barking cough would not be expected. In addition, vascular rings most commonly manifest within the first weeks of life.

Inflammation of the pharynx (e.g., strep throat) typically presents with erythema and exudates of the pharynx and tonsils. Patients primarily develop sore throat and dysphagia. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also a typical finding. Hoarseness and barking cough do not occur.

Inflammation of the epiglottis (e.g., as seen in epiglottitis) can also manifest with inspiratory stridor. Edema of the small and flaccid epiglottic cartilage in children quickly results in drooling, sore throat, dysphagia, and muffled voice, rather than hoarseness and a barking cough. Children with epiglottitis typically have a toxic appearance (e.g., respiratory distress, cyanosis, inspiratory retractions, restlessness) and are at high risk of developing respiratory distress.

Croup, the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the subglottic larynx (below the vocal folds). The cricoid cartilage ring of the subglottis cannot expand. Given the small size and floppiness of the larynx and trachea in children, mucosal swelling quickly causes hoarseness, barking cough, and inspiratory stridor.

images.title: Larynx (sections)
images.description: The larynx is divided into three sections: the supraglottic space, laryngeal ventricle, and subglottic space.

answers.explanation_why: Inflammation of the bronchioles (e.g., bronchiolitis) can also manifest with symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection (e.g., low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, cough). Narrowing of the terminal bronchioles due to edema and excessive mucus causes wheezing and crackles. Hoarseness and inspiratory stridor do not occur. In addition, bronchiolitis most commonly affects children < 2 years.

question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision that began this morning. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and insulin. Physical examination shows the right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. Serum studies show a hemoglobin A_1c of 11.5%. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision that began this morning. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and insulin. Physical examination shows the right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. Serum studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 11.5%. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: The most likely cause of an isolated oculomotor nerve palsy in a patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is diabetic mononeuropathy, which occurs as a result of microangiopathic ischemia.
learning_objective: Recognize diabetic mononeuropathy presenting as oculomotor nerve palsy, and recall the associated clinical feature of ptosis.

answers.content: Inability to abduct the right eye
answers.explanation_why: This patient has an isolated oculomotor nerve palsy due to his poorly controlled diabetes, as the right eye is abducted with slight intorsion. Abduction of the eye is governed by the abducens nerve (CN VI), which is unlikely to be affected by diabetic microangiopathy.

answers.content: Absent consensual light reaction on the right eye
answers.explanation_why: An absent consensual light reaction on the right eye would suggest a defect of the parasympathetic fibers of CN III, which are responsible for pupillary constriction. Because microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared. Therefore, one would not expect to see a pupillary defect.

answers.content: Loss of the right nasolabial fold
answers.explanation_why: The nasolabial fold, along with most facial movements, are controlled by branches of the facial nerve (CN VII), which is unlikely to be involved by diabetic microangiopathy.

answers.content: Upper eyelid droop on the right eye
answers.explanation_why: Ptosis occurs in patients with oculomotor nerve palsy because levator palpebrae superioris is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Whereas patients with oculomotor nerve palsy due to compression usually show dilated pupils, those with diabetic mononeuropathy normally do not have pupillary involvement because the microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared.

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.explanation_why: Anosmia occurs through dysfunction of the olfactory nerve (CN I). Neither this patients symptoms nor the likely etiology of his condition (diabetic microangiopathy) suggests involvement of the olfactory nerve.

answers.content: Absent direct light reaction on the right eye
answers.explanation_why: Microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared. Because both CN II (responsible for detecting light on the retina) and the parasympathetic fibers of CN III (responsible for pupillary constriction) are intact, there is no pupillary defect when light is shone on the right eye. Of note, if this patient's oculomotor nerve function had been caused by compression (such as uncal herniation), the parasympathetic fibers running superficially along CN III are actually first to be affected.

question_text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
hint: Men with a history of cryptorchidism are at increased risk for testicular germ cell tumors, even after cryptorchidism has been surgically repaired.
learning_objective: Recognize teratoma in a patient with a history of cryptorchidism.

answers.explanation_why:
Testicular germ cell tumors are divided into two groups: seminomas (most common) and nonseminoma tumors. Nonseminoma tumors include embryonal carcinomas, yolk sac tumors, testicular choriocarcinomas, teratomas, and tumors with mixed germ cell histology. Pure teratomas typically do not cause an elevation in testicular tumor markers (beta-hCG, AFP, PLAP), which is consistent with this patient's laboratory studies. Teratomas are more common in children but are usually benign in this patient group. In adult males, they are rare but more often malignant.

Unlike hydroceles, testicular tumors do not transilluminate on examination. Typically, testicular tumors should not be percutaneously biopsied because a biopsy can cause seeding of malignant cells in the scrotum.
Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Sertoli cell tumors. Moreover, Sertoli cell tumors are very rare, accounting for < 1% of all testicular cancers in adults.

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Leydig cell tumors. Moreover, Leydig cell tumors are very rare, accounting for only approx. 2% of all testicular cancers in adults.

Yolk sac tumors are nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. While this patient's history of bilateral cryptorchidism puts him at increased risk of developing germ cell tumors, he is unlikely to develop a yolk sac tumor because it most commonly manifests before puberty. Moreover, yolk sac tumors are associated with an increased level of AFP, which is normal in this patient.

Testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in men > 60 years of age. It usually arises when non-Hodgkin lymphoma metastasizes to the testicles. This 30-year-old man is unlikely to have a testicular lymphoma, and cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for testicular lymphoma.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 3-month history of vulvar itching and pain. She was diagnosed with lichen sclerosus 4 years ago. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm nodular, ulcerative lesion on the vaginal introitus and left labia minora with surrounding erythema. Punch biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows enlarged lymph nodes concerning for metastatic disease. Which of the following lymph node regions is the most likely primary site of metastasis?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 3-month history of vulvar itching and pain. She was diagnosed with lichen sclerosus 4 years ago. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm nodular, ulcerative lesion on the vaginal introitus and left labia minora with surrounding erythema. Punch biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows enlarged lymph nodes concerning for metastatic disease. Which of the following lymph node regions is the most likely primary site of metastasis?
hint: This lymph node region would also be the first site of metastasis in penile cancer.
learning_objective: Recognize the primary lymphatic drainage sites for vulvar cancer.

answers.explanation_why: The superficial inguinal nodes are the primary lymphatic draining site for the distal vagina and vulva. The path of lymphatic drainage then continues via the deep inguinal to the pelvic and external iliac lymph nodes, and finally to the paraaortic lymph nodes. This pathway is different from all other cancers of the female reproductive tract.

The para-aortic lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the ovaries. The lymphatic fluid follows the gonadal arteries back to the abdominal aorta, near the site of early gonadal development and differentiation of the mesonephros. The para-aortic lymph nodes do not drain the distal vagina and vulva.
The inferior mesenteric lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the colon starting from the splenic flexure to the upper rectum. They do not commonly drain the genital tract.

The external iliac lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the body of the uterus as well as the superior bladder. While they also receive lymph from the distal vagina and vulva at some point, they are not the first site of lymphatic drainage for these organs.

The internal iliac lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the middle third of the vagina as well as the cervix. They do not drain the distal vagina and vulva. The internal iliac nodes also drain the bladder and the lower rectum to the anal canal (above pectinate line).

The deep inguinal lymph nodes are located medial to the femoral vein. Although lymphatic fluid from the distal vagina and vulva may collect in these lymph nodes, they are neither the most direct nor the primary site of lymphatic drainage from these organs. Metastatic cancer from these organs is possible in this lymph node basin but would not be the most likely location for metastasis.

question_text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He reports right hip pain and numbness along the right thigh. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch over a small area of the medial thigh. X-rays of the pelvis show a displaced pelvic ring fracture. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He reports right hip pain and numbness along the right thigh. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch over a small area of the medial thigh. X-rays of the pelvis show a displaced pelvic ring fracture. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This man has a pelvic ring fracture with decreased sensation over a small area of the right medial thigh. This is consistent with an obturator nerve injury.
learning_objective: Recognize obturator nerve injury, and recall its motor function deficit.

answers.content: Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot
answers.explanation_why: Sensory deficits of the dorsal foot can be caused by injury to the superficial peroneal branch of the common peroneal nerve, which provides sensory cutaneous innervation to the lateral lower leg and dorsal aspect of the foot. However, injury to the common peroneal nerve or its branches would not cause decreased sensation in the medial thigh.

Impaired hip extension can occur in the setting of hip dislocation or hip arthroplasty. The muscles involved in hip extension include the gluteus maximus (innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve), and the semitendinosus and semimembranosus (both innervated by the sciatic nerve). Neither the inferior gluteal nerve nor the sciatic nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial thigh.

Impaired dorsiflexion of the foot can be seen in common peroneal nerve injury, which typically occurs in the setting of fibular head fractures or external compression of the common peroneal nerve at the level of the fibular head. The branches of the common peroneal nerve provide sensory innervation to the first dorsal web space and the lateral lower leg and dorsal foot. Injury to this nerve would not explain the patient's decreased sensation in the medial thigh.

Impaired extension of the knee can occur following injury to the femoral nerve, which innervates the quadriceps muscles. Although femoral nerve injury can be caused by direct trauma (e.g., fracture, compression from a hematoma) it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's sensory deficit on the medial thigh because sensory fibers from the femoral nerve also provide cutaneous innervation to the medial lower leg and foot.

Absence of the cremasteric reflex is seen in patients with injury to the genitofemoral nerve, as the nerve provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle. The genitofemoral nerve also provides sensory cutaneous innervation to the scrotum in men and to the mons pubis and labia majora in women; there are also cutaneous branches to the proximal aspect of the anteromedial thigh. This patient presents with decreased sensation to the medial thigh, which could be seen in genitofemoral nerve injury. However, pelvic ring fractures are not associated with genitofemoral nerve injuries.

Pelvic ring fracture is a common cause of obturator nerve injury. In addition to providing sensory cutaneous innervation to a small area of the medial thigh, the obturator nerve also provides motor innervation to the hip adductor muscles in the medial compartment of the thigh. Thus, injury to the nerve can result in impaired adduction of the hip.
