question_text: A male newborn is born at 37 weeks' gestation after spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother had no prenatal care. Physical examination shows a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis, 4 mm proximal to the glans. There is a 3-cm defect in the midline abdominal wall superior to the pubic symphysis with exposure of moist, erythematous mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A male newborn is born at 37 weeks' gestation after spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother had no prenatal care. Physical examination shows a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis, 4 mm proximal to the glans. There is a 3-cm defect in the midline abdominal wall superior to the pubic symphysis with exposure of moist, erythematous mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
hint: This male newborn has epispadias, a condition that manifests with a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis. Epispadias is often associated with bladder exstrophy, which causes herniation of bladder mucosa through the lower midline abdominal wall, as seen in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize epispadias and bladder exstrophy, and recall their embryological origin.

answers.explanation_why: Persistence of the urogenital membrane is associated with the development of posterior urethral valves, which, due to the fetus's inability to properly excrete urine, can lead to oligohydramnios. Severe oligohydramnios results in Potter sequence, which consists of craniofacial abnormalities, clubbed feet, and pulmonary hypoplasia. Posterior urethral valves can cause bladder dysfunction but are not associated with epispadias or bladder exstrophy.

answers.content: Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings
answers.explanation_why: Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings causes a bifid scrotum, which manifests with a midline cleft in the scrotum. Bifid scrotum is associated with hypospadias, not epispadias or bladder exstrophy. Any atypical genitalia findings in a newborn should prompt evaluation for a disorder of sexual development such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia or androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Misdirected growth of the genital tubercle in the posterior (rather than superior) direction during the 5^th week of gestation results in epispadias. It is very rare for bladder exstrophy to occur without epispadias, but epispadias can occur without bladder exstrophy.
If the gubernaculum does not involute, the testes may not descend properly into the scrotum, which results in cryptorchidism. This condition is not associated with epispadias or bladder exstrophy.

answers.content: Failed fusion of the urethral folds
answers.explanation_why: Failed fusion of the urethral folds during the 17^th week of gestation results in hypospadias, which manifests with a urethral opening proximal to the glans on the ventral aspect of the penis. Hypospadias is associated with inguinal hernias and cryptorchidism, not bladder exstrophy.

question_text: Seven hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. Neurologic examination shows left leg strength 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Seven hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. Neurologic examination shows left leg strength 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Postoperative anteromedial thigh and lower leg paresthesias with concurrent decreased patellar reflex, hip flexion, and knee extension are consistent with damage to a peripheral nerve of the anterior lower extremity.
learning_objective: Recognize femoral nerve injury.

answers.explanation_why: Sural nerve injury is usually caused by Achilles tendon rupture, entrapment, or ganglion lipomas. The sural nerve is a purely sensory nerve, and injury to it typically manifests with decreased sensation on the posterolateral lower leg and the lateral border of the foot. It would not explain the loss of sensation on the anteromedial thigh and decreased strength in knee extension seen in this patient.

This patient has evidence of femoral nerve injury, likely from prolonged compression during surgery. Injury of the femoral nerve typically results in loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg (anterior cutaneous branches), as well as decreased strength in hip flexion (iliopsoas muscle) and knee extension (quadriceps femoris muscle).

images.title: Innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (leg, ventral view)

answers.explanation_why: Fibular nerve injury is usually caused by injuries in the lower leg (e.g., fracture of the fibular head or tight-fitting casts of the lower leg). It typically presents with foot drop (weakness of foot dorsiflexors) and a loss of sensation between the first and second toe (deep peroneal nerve branch) and the back of the feet and toes (superficial peroneal nerve branch). Fibular nerve injury would not cause loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh or the decreased knee extension seen in this patient.

Obturator nerve injury usually results from pelvic ring fractures or entrapment. It typically manifests with loss of sensation of the medial thigh (cutaneous branch of the obturator nerve) and decreased strength in the hip adductors. It would not explain this patient's loss of sensation in the anterior thigh or her decreased strength in knee extension.

S1 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the posterior leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral foot, weakness in plantar flexion and eversion, and a decreased Achilles tendon reflex. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

L5 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot and strength deficits in foot dorsiflexion and eversion. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after being hit in the face with a baseball at high velocity. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, posterior displacement of the left globe, and tenderness to palpation over the left infraorbital rim. There is limited left upward gaze and normal horizontal eye movement. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following as a result of this patient's trauma?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after being hit in the face with a baseball at high velocity. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, posterior displacement of the left globe, and tenderness to palpation over the left infraorbital rim. There is limited left upward gaze and normal horizontal eye movement. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following as a result of this patient's trauma?
hint: The patient's findings of enophthalmos (posteriorly displaced eye) and infraorbital rim tenderness are suggestive of an orbital floor fracture (orbital blowout fracture). The mechanism of this injury can lead to downward displacement of orbital fat and inferior rectus muscle entrapment, which in turn can cause impaired upward gaze.
learning_objective: Recognize an orbital floor fracture, and recall its radiological sign.

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the lacrimal duct system is associated with nasoethmoid fractures. Fracture of the maxillary bone in this portion of the medial orbital rim can also result in disruption of the medial canthal ligament, causing eyelid displacement and entrapment of the medial rectus muscle, which would prevent horizontal eye movement. Nasoethmoid fractures are the second most common orbital fractures after orbital floor fractures, but this patient has none of the accompanying signs, and such a fracture would not explain his limited upward gaze or inferior orbital rim tenderness.

Clouding of the maxillary sinus is a radiological sign known as the “tear drop sign.” It will most likely be seen on further evaluation due to the inferior rectus muscle and orbital fat herniating through the fractured orbital floor. Other symptoms may include diplopia, crepitus, ecchymosis, and loss of sensation in the area innervated by the infraorbital nerve (midface from the lower eyelid to the upper lip).

images.title: Blowout fracture of the orbital floor
images.description: CT of the midface (frontal view, bone window)Orbital (O) floor fracture (white line shows the original course of the bone), resulting in herniation of the infraorbital adipose tissue (green overlay) into the maxillary sinus (MS). This is also known as the teardrop sign. The inferior rectus muscle (green hatched overlay on the right) is no longer clearly defined on the left and likely entrapped in the area of the orbital floor fracture.

answers.explanation_why: Pneumatization of the frontal sinus is a part of normal development as bone marrow in the frontal sinuses is slowly replaced by air starting at 2 years of age until adolescence. Pneumatization of the frontal sinuses may also occur as a result of orbital trauma in cases of orbital roof fractures. These fractures are rare in adults because of the strength of the orbital roof. They are more common in children, who have a higher cranium-to-midface ratio relative to adults. Orbital roof fractures result in CSF leaks and mucocele formation, none of which are present in this patient.

Cerebrospinal fluid leak is seldom associated with orbital fractures. When CSF leak does occur, it is typically due to an orbital roof fracture with extension to the frontal sinuses. Orbital roof fracture is inconsistent with this patient's inferior orbital rim tenderness and limitation of upward gaze (signifying inferior rectus muscle entrapment).

Disruption of the medial canthal ligament is associated with nasoethmoid fractures. Fracture of the maxillary bone in this portion of the orbital rim could also result in disruption of the lacrimal duct system and entrapment of the medial rectus muscle, which would prevent horizontal eye movement. While these nasoethmoid fractures are the second most common orbital fractures after orbital floor fractures, this patient has normal horizontal eye movement, and such a fracture would not explain his limited upward gaze or inferior orbital rim tenderness.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This mass will also move cranially with swallowing.
learning_objective: Recognize a thyroglossal cyst.

answers.explanation_why: A thyroglossal cyst arises if the thyroglossal duct fails to obliterate completely during embryonal development. The cyst can develop anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct and manifests as a painless, firm, midline mass of the anterior neck. Like the thyroid gland, the thyroglossal cyst is enclosed within the pretracheal fascia, which is responsible for the upward movement of these structures during swallowing. In addition, a thyroglossal cyst moves upward with tongue protrusion because the fibrous remnants of the thyroglossal duct are connected to the base of the tongue.

A ranula is a mucocele arising from the sublingual gland that manifests as a translucent, dome-shaped, blue mass below the tongue. Although large lesions can cause swelling of the neck, this would occur lateral to the midline and would not move upwards with tongue protrusion or swallowing.

Laryngocele, a saccular dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle, can herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and appear as a lateral neck swelling. The neck mass is typically a small, air-filled sac that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver.

A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system in the neck. The neck mass is typically painless, soft, and compressible, and is located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma is associated with fetal aneuploidy (e.g., Turner syndrome).

images.title: Cystic hygroma
images.description: Right lateral region of the neck(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

answers.explanation_why: Dermoid cysts are cystic teratomas that can arise anywhere in the body, including the neck. As a neck mass, they usually manifest at 10–20 years of age as a slow-growing mass in the submandibular or sublingual space.

Branchial cysts can arise if the 2^nd branchial cleft fails to obliterate completely. These neck masses are typically painless and firm, as in this patient, but located lateral to the midline and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not move with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodes of shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and palpitations. During the examination, he reports the onset of one such episode. His pulse is 170/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia; no P waves are visible. A common clinical maneuver to diagnose and/or relieve the patient's symptoms involves stimulation of which of the following nerves?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodes of shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and palpitations. During the examination, he reports the onset of one such episode. His pulse is 170/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia; no P waves are visible. A common clinical maneuver to diagnose and/or relieve the patient's symptoms involves stimulation of which of the following nerves?
hint: Intermittent palpitations, lightheadedness, dyspnea, and ECG findings that show a narrow complex tachycardia without P waves are all features of atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia, a type of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Several maneuvers that elicit an autonomic response can be used to diagnose and terminate this cardiac arrhythmia.
learning_objective: Recognize atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia, and recall the nerve involved in vagal maneuvers.

answers.explanation_why: The parasympathetic fibers of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) supply the salivary glands, the lacrimal glands, and the nasal mucosa. They do not supply the myocardium and will therefore not help to diagnose or relieve this patient's PSVT. In addition, the trigeminal nerve does not lie in close proximity to the carotid sinus.

Although the recurrent laryngeal nerves lie in close proximity to the carotid sinus and branch out from the vagus nerve, they do not participate in the autonomic response that would terminate this patient's PSVT.

The parasympathetic fibers of the facial nerve (CN VII) supply the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands and the lacrimal glands. They do not supply the myocardium and will therefore not help to diagnose or relieve this patient's PSVT. In addition, the facial nerve does not lie in close proximity to the carotid sinus.

Although the phrenic nerves lie in close proximity to the heart and provide sensory supply to the pericardium, they do not provide autonomic supply to the myocardium. Therefore, they will not help to diagnose or relieve this patient's PSVT.

The nerve of the carotid sinus (nerve of Hering) is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) that terminates in the vasomotor center of the medulla oblongata (nucleus tractus solitarius). Carotid sinus massage stimulates baroreceptors, which transmits a signal to the medulla oblongata via CN IX. The efferent signals from the medulla to the myocardium are conducted via the vagus nerve (parasympathetic supply), which results in ↓ AV nodal conduction, ↓ heart rate, ↓ contractility, and vasodilation (↓ blood pressure). This patient's symptoms are caused by AV nodal re-entry; slowing AV nodal conduction terminates the arrhythmia.

Other vagal maneuvers include the Valsalva maneuver and breath holding.

images.title: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor pathways
images.description: Baroreceptors are stretch receptors that are located in the carotid sinuses and in the aortic arch of the aorta. Baroreceptors sense minute blood pressure (BP) changes and send afferent signals to the brain stem (nucleus tractus solitarius) via the vagus nerve from the aortic arch and the glossopharyngeal nerve from the carotid sinus. The brainstem modulates autonomic outflow to alter the heart rate and peripheral vascular resistance to normalize BP (i.e., ↓ BP → sympathetic stimulation → ↑ HR, ↑ peripheral vascular resistance → ↑ BP; ↑ BP → parasympathetic stimulation → ↓ HR and ↓ peripheral vascular resistance → ↓BP). This pathway is known as the baroreflex.A prolonged decrease in BP also stimulates long-term homeostatic mechanisms of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone pathway (RAAS) and ADH secretion (↑ ADH release → ↓ water excretion by the kidneys → ↑ intravascular volume → ↑ BP).Chemoreceptors detect minute changes in pH and partial pressures of respiratory gases. Peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid body and aortic body, are stimulated by a fall in pH and pO_2 or a rise in pCO_2, which occurs in hypoxia. Chemoreceptors send afferent signals to the brain stem (dorsal respiratory group) via the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves, which stimulates the respiratory centers of the brain, resulting in an increase in the rate and depth of breathing. Chemoreceptor stimulation also increases the sympathetic outflow to the heart.

question_text: A 70-year-old man with right-sided renal cell carcinoma comes to the physician because of shortness of breath for 1 month. Yesterday he had an episode of hemoptysis. He appears cachectic and chronically ill. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows multiple pulmonary nodules. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown. This patient's tumor most likely spread via which of the following labeled structures?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man with right-sided renal cell carcinoma comes to the physician because of shortness of breath for 1 month. Yesterday he had an episode of hemoptysis. He appears cachectic and chronically ill. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows multiple pulmonary nodules. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown. This patient's tumor most likely spread via which of the following labeled structures?
hint: Renal cell carcinoma metastasizes via hematogenous and lymphatogenous spread. Hematogenous spread is usually via the venous system.
learning_objective: Recall intraabdominal anatomy, and the route of hematogenous metastates in renal cell carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Option A on this axial CT scan corresponds to the small intestine. Small intestinal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma is rare and the small intestine itself is not part of a route for hematogenous or lymphatogenous spread of metastatic RCC cells.

Option B on this axial CT scan corresponds to the mesenteric vessels. Although these vessels supply blood to and from the small intestine and large intestine, they do not supply the kidney. While metastatic RCC cells may eventually spread to the intestine via these vessels, they would first follow the path of venous and lymphatic drainage from the kidney.

Option C on this axial CT scan corresponds to the left-sided renal vessels. Although a left-sided tumor could metastasize hematogenously via the left renal vein, this patient has a right-sided RCC, which would follow a different path.
Option D on this axial CT scan corresponds to the aorta. Although hematogenously metastasizing RCC cells may eventually reach the arterial system, they first follow the path of venous drainage.

Option E on this axial CT scan corresponds to the inferior vena cava (IVC). Venous drainage from the right kidney enters the right renal vein and flows into the IVC. By this route metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) cells could be transported via the IVC to the right heart and from there into the lungs, causing this patient's pulmonary symptoms and pulmonary nodules on CT.

images.title: Abdominal CT
images.description:
(A) Small intestine
(B) Mesenteric vessels
(C) Vessels of the left kidney
(D) Aorta
(E) Inferior vena cava

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The swelling started several weeks ago but is not always present. Physical examination shows an 8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The swelling started several weeks ago but is not always present. Physical examination shows an 8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
hint: This patient presents with a fluctuant, painless scrotal mass that transilluminates and does not reduce in a supine position. These features are suggestive of hydrocele.
learning_objective: Recognize a hydrocele due to fluid imbalance.

answers.content: Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by tunica vaginalis
answers.explanation_why: Since this patient has no signs of ongoing inflammation, no history of recent testicular trauma, and a normal testis on palpation, he most likely has a primary/idiopathic hydrocele, which is caused by an imbalance in the rate of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis. Primary hydroceles differ from secondary/reactive hydroceles in that the underlying cause of fluid accumulation within the tunica vaginalis is not known (idiopathic). In secondary/reactive hydroceles, inflammation (e.g., epididymitis, orchitis), trauma, or neoplasia causes an imbalance in fluid secretion and absorption by the tunica vaginalis.

answers.content: Failure of processus vaginalis to obliterate
answers.explanation_why:
Failure of the processus vaginalis to obliterate results in a communicating hydrocele and is seen in infants and young children. Although a child with a communicating hydrocele will have the same clinical findings as this patient, the onset of this patient's symptoms in the 6^th decade of life makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, in contrast to this case, a communicating hydrocele would increase in size on coughing/straining due to its communication with the peritoneal cavity.

A patent processus vaginalis is also the cause of indirect inguinal hernia, which can be congenital or acquired and also present as a nontender scrotal mass that may vary in size and, if the content is omentum, absent bowel sounds within the mass. However, since an inguinal hernia enters the scrotum through the superficial inguinal ring with solid content, the examiner will not be able to palpate normal tissue above the mass and the transillumination test will be negative. It would also increase in coughing/straining (unless it is an obstructed/strangulated hernia).

answers.content: Extension of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal
answers.explanation_why: An inguinal hernia can also present as a nontender scrotal mass that may vary in size and, if the content is omentum, absent bowel sounds within the mass. However, since an inguinal hernia enters the scrotum through the superficial inguinal ring, the examiner will not be able to palpate normal tissue above the mass. Since the contents of an inguinal hernia are solid, the transillumination test will be negative. The contents of an inguinal hernia are in direct communication with the peritoneal cavity, meaning that coughing/straining will increase the size of the mass (unless it is an obstructed/strangulated hernia).

answers.content: Dilation and tortuosity of veins in the pampiniform plexus
answers.explanation_why: Dilation and tortuosity of the pampiniform plexus of veins cause a varicocele, which, if symptomatic, manifests as a dragging sensation/dull pain in the affected scrotum. However, varicoceles typically present at a younger age (puberty/adolescence) and the dilated veins will present as a characteristic "bag of worms” feeling on palpation. Furthermore, a transillumination test will be negative in varicocele. Lastly, varicoceles are usually left-sided.

answers.content: Primary germ cell neoplasia of the testicle
answers.explanation_why: Although testicular cancer can manifest as a painless scrotal swelling, palpation would generally reveal a testicular mass and the transillumination test would be negative (unless there is reactive fluid collection around the testis). Some testicular tumors may be nonpalpable and the testes may appear normal on examination. However, it is unlikely that a nonpalpable testicular tumor would cause a reactive hydrocele.

answers.content: Obstruction in lymphatic drainage of the scrotum
answers.explanation_why: Obstruction in lymphatic drainage causing scrotal swelling (usually bilateral) causes hydrocele and can occur in patients who have undergone iliac lymphadenectomy, pelvic irradiation, or those who have lymphatic filariasis due to Wuchereria bancrofti infection. This patient has no history of undergoing these procedures and filariasis has been eradicated from the United States. Moreover, the transillumination test is often negative in hydroceles caused by lymphatic obstruction, since the scrotum is thickened and the hydrocele fluid is often turbid and chylous.

question_text: Thirty minutes after normal vaginal delivery of twins, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 4, has heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Physical examination shows a soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus. Despite bimanual uterine massage, administration of uterotonic drugs, and placement of an intrauterine balloon for tamponade, the bleeding continues. A hysterectomy is performed. Vessels running through which of the following structures must be ligated during the surgery to achieve hemostasis?
content_preview: Thirty minutes after normal vaginal delivery of twins, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 4, has heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Physical examination shows a soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus. Despite bimanual uterine massage, administration of uterotonic drugs, and placement of an intrauterine balloon for tamponade, the bleeding continues. A hysterectomy is performed. Vessels running through which of the following structures must be ligated during the surgery to achieve hemostasis?
hint: The uterine artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery, supplies blood to the uterus. It runs through a structure located at the base of the broad ligament of the uterus.
learning_objective: Recall the anatomical location of the uterine artery during a hysterectomy.

answers.explanation_why: The suspensory ligament of the ovary (infundibulopelvic ligament) attaches the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall. The ovarian vessels travel through this ligament to supply the ovaries and the upper part of the uterus. To achieve rapid hemostasis, the ligament containing the uterine arteries (main blood supply to the uterus) should first be ligated. Because this patient is young, the ovarian vessels and ovaries should ideally be preserved during hysterectomy to avoid premature menopause.

The uterosacral ligaments are avascular fibrous bands that connect the cervix to the sacrum, thereby providing mechanical support to the uterus. Although the uterosacral ligaments will be divided during the course of a hysterectomy, this will not contribute to achieving hemostasis in this patient.

The cardinal ligament (transverse cervical ligament) connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall, providing support to the uterus. It contains the uterine artery, which is the main blood supply of the uterus. Ligation of the uterine vessels is imperative to perform hysterectomy and obtain hemostasis in this patient. During hysterectomy, the ureters are at increased risk for injury due to their proximity to the cardinal ligament.

Uterine atony (as evidenced by the soft, boggy uterus in this patient) is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage and occurs when the myometrial fibers of the uterus fail to fully contract and compress the uteroplacental vasculature (branches of the uterine artery) after placental delivery. Patients with a history of multiple pregnancies are at increased risk.

images.title: Supporting ligaments of the uterus (dorsal view)
images.description:
The uterus is connected to the pelvic walls by ligaments and peritoneal folds. These structures provide support and allow for flexible movement of the uterus between the urinary bladder and the rectum, especially during pregnancy.- The round ligament extends from the lateral horn of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall and via the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
- The largest ligament is the broad ligament of the uterus, a peritoneal fold that connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. The broad ligament can be divided into the mesosalpinx, the mesovarium, and the mesometrium.
- The ovaries are suspended from the uterus by the ovarian ligament and from the lateral pelvic wall by the suspensory (infundibulopelvic) ligament of the ovary.
- The cardinal ligament encloses the uterine artery and vein and connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall.
- The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum.

answers.explanation_why: The round ligament connects the uterine fundus to the labia majora. It contains the Sampson artery, which is a small, insignificant vessel that anastomoses with the uterine and ovarian arteries. Although the round ligaments would be ligated during a hysterectomy, their ligation will not contribute to achieving hemostasis in this patient.

The ovarian ligament connects the uterus and ovaries. The ovarian branch of the uterine artery runs along the lower border of the ovarian ligament, but this vessel has no role in postpartum hemorrhage.

question_text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain. Over the past 9 months, she has had multiple similar episodes of abdominal pain, each lasting for 4–5 days. Menarche has not yet occurred. Examination shows suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Pelvic examination shows bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain. Over the past 9 months, she has had multiple similar episodes of abdominal pain, each lasting for 4–5 days. Menarche has not yet occurred. Examination shows suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Pelvic examination shows bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Recurrent lower abdominal pain in a 15-year-old female with age-appropriate secondary sexual characteristics suggests that menstruation is in fact occurring but is hidden (cryptomenorrhea)!
learning_objective: Recognize imperforate hymen.

answers.explanation_why: Labial adhesions manifest with a thin, vertical midline fold in the perineum due to adhesions between the labia minora. This condition does not cause a mass at the vaginal introitus and is typically asymptomatic. Additionally, this condition usually affects infants and young children (peak incidence of 2 years of age) and spontaneously resolves around the time of puberty, when increased circulating levels of estrogen thicken the labia. Patients with labial adhesions typically do not have primary amenorrhea.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) manifests with primary amenorrhea in patients with normal breast development and female external genitalia. However, in contrast to this patient, individuals with AIS have very sparse or absent pubic hair. Pelvic examination shows a blind-ending vaginal pouch rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. Cryptorchid testes may be palpable as bilateral masses in the abdominal or inguinal region. AIS does not cause cyclical pelvic pain.

Endometriosis causes cyclical pelvic pain, which is seen in this patient, but does not manifest with primary amenorrhea or a bulging, bluish mass within the vaginal introitus. Additionally, this condition typically manifests in women who are 25–35 years of age and is unlikely to develop in an adolescent patient.

Ectopic pregnancy can cause pelvic pain, but the pain is usually acute, nonrecurring, and develops in a postmenarchal patient after 4–6 weeks of amenorrhea (secondary amenorrhea). This patient, who has primary amenorrhea, has had recurring symptoms for 9 months. Moreover, while ectopic pregnancy can lead to an enlarged uterus or an adnexal mass, it would not manifest as a mass within the vaginal introitus.

Imperforate hymen manifests with primary amenorrhea, cyclical pelvic pain, and otherwise normal secondary sexual characteristics. As is the case here, patients with an imperforate hymen are asymptomatic until menarche, when the obstructed outflow of menstrual blood distends the vaginal tract and uterus and results in a characteristic bulging, bluish mass at the vaginal introitus (hematocolpos). Treatment of imperforate hymen includes hymenectomy and consequent evacuation of the retained blood.

Müllerian agenesis (MA) manifests as primary amenorrhea in patients with normal secondary sexual characteristics. This condition causes vaginal agenesis; pelvic examination typically shows normal external genitalia and a vaginal dimple (small vaginal pouch) rather than a mass at the vaginal introitus. In almost all cases, individuals with MA also have uterine agenesis or underdevelopment and thus do not menstruate. Rarely, these individuals have a rudimentary uterus and can develop cyclic pelvic pain due to menstruation. However, because the menstrual blood cannot pass into the lower vagina, a mass would not be present at the vaginal introitus.

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
content_preview: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
hint: S1 radiculopathy causes motor deficits in the gastrocnemius muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize S1 radiculopathy, and recall its effect on reflexes.

answers.explanation_why: Difficulty walking on heels (e.g., foot drop) is consistent with an injury to the L5 nerve roots (i.e., L5 radiculopathy). In addition, L5 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the dorsolateral thigh, the lateral side of the knee, lower leg, and dorsum of the foot and big toe.

An absent patellar reflex is consistent with an injury to the L3 and L4 nerve roots (i.e., L3 and L4 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits of the anterolateral area of the thigh. L4 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the anterolateral thigh, the area over the patella, the medial aspect of the leg, and the medial malleolus.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anus and genitalia
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anus and the genitalia is seen in cauda equina syndrome. Although patients typically present with asymmetric, unilateral radicular pain in the lower limb dermatomes (due to a lesion below the level of L2), there are usually numerous spinal nerves (L3–S5) involved rather than an isolated nerve root (S1 dermatome) as seen in this patient. Furthermore, other expected findings (e.g., saddle block anesthesia, fecal incontinence, urinary incontinence or retention) are lacking in this patient.

S1 radiculopathy is caused by compression of the S1 spinal nerve root and can manifest with a weak Achilles tendon reflex. The S1 nerve root controls plantar flexion through the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, so weakness in these muscles can lead to a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and impaired toe walking. Additionally, the S1 nerve root controls sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the thigh, the posterior calf, and the lateral side of the foot, which explains this patient's radiating pain in these regions.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is consistent with an injury to the L3 nerve root (i.e., L3 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit of the anterolateral area of the thigh, as well as weakness of hip flexion, hip adduction, and knee extension.

question_text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
hint: The boot-shaped heart on this boy's x-ray is caused by right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). His harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border is caused by pulmonary stenosis. These findings, along with his acute hypoxic spells (which cause cyanosis), indicate a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize right ventricular outflow obstruction.

answers.content: Persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: A persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery characterizes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic heart defect that can cause cyanosis if Eisenmenger syndrome develops. However, patients with a PDA and Eisenmenger syndrome typically develop differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Additionally, PDA causes a continuous, machine-like murmur heard throughout systole and diastole (unlike this patient's systolic murmur), and chest x-ray shows a prominent mediastinum caused by an enlarged pulmonary artery and aortic knob (not a boot-shaped heart).

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Hypoplasia of the left ventricle is caused by hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), a heart condition that is typically acyanotic in the early postnatal period because a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ensures systemic perfusion. Cyanosis develops when the PDA closes, usually within a few days of birth (not as late as 3 months as in this case). Neonates with HLHS also have weak peripheral pulses, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis as the hypoplastic left ventricle cannot maintain adequate cardiac output. Additionally, HLHS does not cause a murmur, and findings on chest x-ray are variable (e.g., small, normal, or enlarged heart and increased pulmonary venous markings) but do not include a boot-shaped heart.

answers.content: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch
answers.explanation_why: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta, manifests variably depending on the degree of aortic stenosis (AS) and the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Patients with significant AS and PDA present with differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Once the PDA closes (usually within a few days after birth), heart failure develops and manifests as dyspnea, sweating during feeds, and poor weight gain. Examination shows pallor (rather than cyanosis), features of inadequate left ventricular output (absent or weak femoral pulses, brachio-femoral delay), and signs of right heart failure (e.g., raised jugular venous pressure, edema, and hepatomegaly). Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary venous markings, not a boot-shaped heart.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why:
Right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) in this patient is caused by pulmonary stenosis, which is one of the components of TOF, along with RVH, an overriding aorta, and a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Exertion, such as crying or feeding, increases the RVOO. This results in cyanosis (tet spells) due to right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD instead of the pulmonary valve, which in turn causes the murmur to become softer. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it chronically pumps against high resistance caused by the RVOO.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during a tet spell. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which increases left ventricular pressure and decreases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the VSD. Infants who are having a tet spell should be placed with their knees toward their chest to achieve the same effect.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Anatomic reversal of aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anatomic reversal of the aorta and pulmonary artery is known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV). This condition causes cyanosis because the aorta arises from the right ventricle and thus results in systemic circulation of deoxygenated blood. However, unlike this patient, cyanosis in TGV manifests immediately after birth. Additionally, chest x-ray in TGV shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to an enlarged heart with a narrowed mediastinum, which resembles an egg lying on its side.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) in infants is usually due to a malformed and displaced tricuspid valve in Ebstein anomaly. These infants may develop cyanosis only if there's an associated ASD or PFO that allows for right-to-left shunting of blood. Auscultation would reveal a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, like in this patient, with a widely split S2. However, a chest x-ray in Ebstein anomaly will show right atrial enlargement (due to chronic reflux of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium) - not a boot-shaped heart as seen in this infant.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

question_text: A 2600-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 34 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman. The mother did not have prenatal care. Upon examination in the delivery room, the newborn's skin appears blue. He is gasping and breathing irregularly. The ears are low-set with broad auricles, and the nasal tip is flattened. The lower jaw is small and displaced backward. The right foot is clubbed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2600-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 34 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman. The mother did not have prenatal care. Upon examination in the delivery room, the newborn's skin appears blue. He is gasping and breathing irregularly. The ears are low-set with broad auricles, and the nasal tip is flattened. The lower jaw is small and displaced backward. The right foot is clubbed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn presents with low-set ears, flat nose, micrognathia, foot clubbing, and respiratory distress, which suggests Potter sequence. Compression of growing fetal tissue in utero due to oligohydramnios is the underlying etiology for Potter sequence.
learning_objective: Recognize Potter sequence due to posterior urethral valves.

answers.explanation_why: Fetal anemia (e.g., due to alloimmunization in utero) causes a state of high cardiac output, which in turn increases urine production and may subsequently result in polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

Pulmonary hypoplasia is a classic complication of Potter sequence, which results in respiratory distress and cyanosis, as seen in this patient. However, it is not the underlying cause of this patient's overall presentation, but rather the consequence of a problem in the earlier stages of fetal development.

Esophageal atresia causes polyhydramnios because of the fetus' inability to swallow and digest amniotic fluid. Certain types of esophageal atresia that occur in conjunction with tracheoesophageal fistulas may present with respiratory distress as a result of recurrent aspiration. However, esophageal atresia would not explain this patient's facial and limb abnormalities.

Maternal diabetes causes hyperglycemia in both the mother and the fetus. Hyperglycemia in the fetus results in osmotic diuresis and, consequently, increased fetal urine output, which leads to polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. Maternal diabetes is associated with fetal caudal regression syndrome, which is characterized by agenesis of the sacrum and/or lumbar spine, paralysis of the legs, and anal atresia; this is not consistent with this fetus' malformations.

images.title: Caudal regression syndrome
images.description: Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

answers.explanation_why: Fetal anencephaly results in the inability to swallow and digest amniotic fluid, followed by subsequent polyhydramnios. Anencephaly is marked by a severely dysmorphic skull and the absence of a brain, which is (in almost all cases) fatal within the first few hours after birth.

Common causes of oligohydramnios include chronic placental insufficiency, chronic amniotic fluid leakage, and decreased fetal renal output. Prenatal posterior urethral valves lead to a bladder outlet obstruction and a decrease in fetal renal output. Other causes of decreased fetal renal output include bilateral renal agenesis and autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.

The decreased amount of amniotic fluid may result in the development of deformities in the face (Potter facies) and limbs. Oligohydramnios can also affect fetal lung development, resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. This infant's cyanosis and respiratory distress are likely due to pulmonary hypoplasia, which is also the most common cause of death in Potter sequence.

question_text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in his left shoulder. He is physically active and plays baseball twice a week. The pain is reproduced when the shoulder is externally rotated against resistance. Injury of which of the following tendons is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in his left shoulder. He is physically active and plays baseball twice a week. The pain is reproduced when the shoulder is externally rotated against resistance. Injury of which of the following tendons is most likely in this patient?
hint: The rotator cuff tendons, which help to stabilize the glenohumeral joint through its broad range of motion, are commonly injured in overhead throwing athletes.
learning_objective: Recognize infraspinatus tendinopathy in overhead throwing athletes.

answers.explanation_why: The teres major contributes to internal rotation, extension, and adduction of the humerus. This muscle is not part of the rotator cuff. Tendinopathy of the teres major is rare; such cases would present with pain that occurs during resisted internal rotation of the humerus. The teres minor is an external rotator of the humerus and could be affected in this patient.

images.title: Latissimus dorsi muscle and teres major muscle

answers.explanation_why: The pectoralis major is a large muscle on the anterior chest that is responsible for adduction, internal rotation, and flexion of the humerus. Tendon avulsion, or rupture of the pectoralis major, can occur in bodybuilders as a result of excessive muscle loading and is accompanied by a sharp, tearing sensation, weakness, swelling, and ecchymosis. This patient has pain during external rotation of the shoulder, which suggests the injury of a different tendon.

Overhead throwing activities (e.g., baseball pitching) place supraphysiological loads on the tendons of the rotator cuff. Through eccentric contraction, this type of activity especially strains the posterior rotator cuff when slowing down after releasing the ball. Tendon overload can cause microscopic tears called microinjuries. The relatively avascular nature of tendons means that these microinjuries have limited healing potential and can propagate into partial or full-thickness tears, or tendinopathy. The infraspinatus muscle, along with the teres minor muscle, is responsible for the external rotation of the humerus. This patient's shoulder pain during external rotation suggests infraspinatus tendinopathy.

images.title: Rotator cuff muscles and their function

answers.explanation_why: The supraspinatus is a rotator cuff muscle that is responsible for shoulder abduction in the scapular plane (30° of forward shoulder flexion). The supraspinatus is the most commonly affected tendon in rotator cuff tears. However, reproduction of this patient's pain during shoulder external rotation suggests the involvement of a different tendon, as the supraspinatus does not perform external rotation.

images.title: Jobe test
images.description: In Jobe test, the examiner applies downward pressure (red arrow) onto the abducted, horizontally flexed, and internally rotated arm of the patient. The patient is asked to resist the downward pressure (green arrow). The supraspinatus muscle, in particular, is required to maintain the arm's position. If there is pain or if the patient is unable to maintain this position against resistance exerted by the examiner, this indicates a functional disorder of the supraspinatus muscle (e.g., rupture, tendinopathy, or subacromial bursitis). If an impairment is present, Jobe's test is considered positive.

answers.explanation_why: The subscapularis is a rotator cuff muscle that is responsible for internal rotation of the humerus. Injury of this tendon would present with pain on resisted internal rotation during a bear hug or belly-press test. This patient has pain during external rotation, which suggests the injury of a different tendon.

images.title: Belly press test
images.description: The patient is asked to press the anterior abdominal wall with the flat of his/her palm while keeping the hand in a straight line with the forearm, and the elbow flexed to 90°. The test is positive if the patient is unable to press the abdomen without flexing the wrist. A positive test indicates a difficulty in internal rotation of the shoulder due to a lesion in the subscapularis muscle.

question_text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right flank pain that started 3 days following a procedure. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. An intravenous pyelogram shows a dilated renal pelvis and ureter on the right with a lack of contrast in the lower third of the ureter. This patient most likely recently underwent which of the following procedures?
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right flank pain that started 3 days following a procedure. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. An intravenous pyelogram shows a dilated renal pelvis and ureter on the right with a lack of contrast in the lower third of the ureter. This patient most likely recently underwent which of the following procedures?
hint: The intravenous pyelogram results describe a ureteral stricture located close to a structure that is commonly ligated in this procedure.
learning_objective: Recognize ureteral injury post-hysterectomy.

answers.explanation_why: A cesarean section is performed by opening the anterior abdominal wall and making a low transverse incision on the anterior wall of the uterus. Although the ureters are in close proximity to the lateral walls of the uterus in a non-gravid state, they are pushed laterally as the uterus enlarges during pregnancy. This makes them less susceptible to injury during a cesarean section.

The lower third of the ureter (pelvic ureter) lies just below the cardinal ligament, which contains the uterine artery. Because the uterine arteries are ligated during a hysterectomy, the ureters are at risk of being injured. The ureters are also susceptible to injury during ovarian surgeries (e.g., oophorectomy) as they lie below the infundibulopelvic ligament, which contains the ovarian arteries. Although any abdominopelvic surgery is a risk factor for ureteric injuries, hysterectomies are the most frequent cause.

A Foley catheter is usually inserted into the bladder through the urethra (in rare cases through the anterior abdominal wall in suprapubic catheterization) and can therefore potentially damage the urethral mucosa (not the ureter), resulting in a urethral stricture as it heals. Instrumentation of the ureter (e.g., during ureteroscopy) is a risk factor for ureteric stricture, but urethral catheterization with a Foley catheter is not.

An inguinal hernia protrudes either through the deep inguinal ring (indirect inguinal hernia) or posterior wall of the inguinal canal (direct inguinal hernia). The contents of an inguinal hernia usually consist of intraperitoneal structures, most commonly omentum or bowel. In large hernias, the bladder may also be involved. The ureter is rarely involved in inguinal hernias and is thus rarely injured during a hernia repair.

The appendix lies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, in close proximity to the cecum, ileum, and psoas and obturator muscles. The free portion of the appendix may assume a variety of positions, and in the pelvic position, lies in close proximity to the right ureter. However, the retrocecal position is much more common and the ureter is rarely injured during an appendectomy. A different procedure is more likely to have resulted in this patient's symptoms.

question_text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left side of the back. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 12^th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following injuries?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left side of the back. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 12th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following injuries?
hint: The lower ribs, also known as floating ribs, are not attached to the sternum. Fractured ribs can damage visceral organs.
learning_objective: Recognize the association between lower rib fractures and adjacent organ injury, and recall the most likely injury with a left 12th rib fracture.

answers.explanation_why: The liver lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen deep to the 5^th–12^th ribs. Right-sided rib fractures are commonly associated with liver injury due to direct transmission of force from the causative blow to the liver and/or penetration of the liver by a fractured segment of a rib. This patient has sustained a left-sided 12^th rib fracture, making a liver injury unlikely.

A pneumothorax can develop if there is an inlet of air into the pleural cavity. The posterior attachment of the parietal pleura extends to the 12^th rib. The inferior border of the lungs extends only to the 10^th rib posteriorly but could be injured and result in a pneumothorax if a fractured segment of the 12^th rib penetrates the lung parenchyma during deep inspiration. However, another organ that lies in close proximity to the 12^th rib is more likely to be injured.

The colon is a hollow organ that is elastic and compressible. It is rarely injured in blunt force injuries. Although the splenic flexure of the colon lies in the vicinity of the left 12^th rib, they are not in direct contact with one another. Colon perforation due to a fractured segment of a rib is unlikely in this patient.

The kidneys normally lie in a paraspinal, retroperitoneal position that extends from T12–L3. The right kidney is displaced more inferiorly because of the liver. Inferior rib fractures (10–12^th ribs) are commonly associated with solid organ injuries to the liver, spleen, and/or kidneys. This patient has sustained a fracture of the posterior aspect of the left 12^th rib as is evident from the tenderness over his back and the x-ray findings, which makes a kidney laceration the most likely associated injury.

Left lower rib fractures also commonly cause splenic injury (including splenic rupture) due to the proximity of the posterior surface of the spleen to the left 9^th, 10^th, and 11^th ribs. Splenic injury is more common than kidney injury.

images.title: Kidneys, lungs, and liver within thoracic skeleton
images.description: The superior pole of the left kidney is located approximately at T12, while the right kidney is located approximately 3 cm lower due to expansion of the liver.

answers.explanation_why: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that extends diagonally from the C-loop of the duodenum, anterior to the L2 vertebra (pancreatic head) to the splenic hilum, anterior to the T12 vertebra (pancreatic tail). The pancreas is well-protected from blunt abdominal trauma because it is surrounded by the liver, spleen, stomach, small intestine, left kidney, and the left lower ribs, which diffuse the transmission of force from the causative blow. A forceful blow to the epigastrium (e.g., from falling on the handlebar of a bike) is more likely to injure the body of the pancreas rather than a posterior blow, which this patient has sustained.

images.title: Pancreatic regional anatomy
images.description: The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of right flank pain. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness and right flank tenderness. An ultrasound shows diffuse dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis; the left ureter and kidney appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of right flank pain. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness and right flank tenderness. An ultrasound shows diffuse dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis; the left ureter and kidney appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's unilateral hydronephrosis is most likely caused by urinary tract obstruction.
learning_objective: Recognize iliac artery aneurysm as a cause of unilateral hydronephrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Renal artery stenosis can cause reduced blood flow to the kidneys and result in renal ischemia. Lack of blood flow also causes activation of RAAS, which leads to hypertension. However, renal artery stenosis would not cause abdominal or right flank tenderness. Furthermore, it is not a known cause of hydronephrosis.

The urethra runs through the prostate just distal to the bladder. Enlargement of the prostate, as seen in BPH, can cause blockage of the urethra, resulting in bladder outlet obstruction. Patients with BPH typically present with urinary frequency, urgency, and incontinence, not abdominal pain. Moreover, this type of obstruction would result in bilateral, not unilateral, hydronephrosis.

Polycystic kidney disease can manifest with flank pain and hypertension (due to increased production of renin). However, polycystic kidney disease causes bilateral renal enlargement due to development of numerous cysts in the renal cortex and medulla; unilateral hydronephrosis is not consistent with this condition.

This patient's right flank tenderness, abdominal pain, and hypertension are all symptoms of urinary tract obstruction, which can, over time, lead to hydronephrosis. The middle portion of the ureter runs anterior to the common iliac artery as it enters the pelvis on its way from the kidney to the bladder. Although rare, large aneurysms of the common, external, or internal iliac artery may compress the ureter, causing an extrinsic urinary tract obstruction and resulting in unilateral hydronephrosis.

images.title: Urinary tract and vasculature of the testes

answers.explanation_why: The urethra originates from the bladder. A urethral stricture would result in a bladder outlet obstruction. This type of obstruction would result in bilateral, not unilateral, hydronephrosis.

question_text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of nausea and weakness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses an oral contraceptive; she uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 4 days ago. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101°F). Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Pelvic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of nausea and weakness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses an oral contraceptive; she uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 4 days ago. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101°F). Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Pelvic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Costovertebral angle tenderness, nausea, and fever are classic characteristics of pyelonephritis.
learning_objective: Recognize ascending bacteria from the bladder as a cause of pyelonephritis.

answers.explanation_why: Ascending bacteria from the endocervix can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID could explain this patient's fever, nausea, and weakness, the condition is not associated with costovertebral angle tenderness. In addition, PID would cause abdominopelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness, and possibly abnormal vaginal discharge.

Noninfectious inflammation of the bladder, causing chronic interstitial cystitis, manifests as a chronic pain syndrome with symptoms of urgency, increased frequency, suprapubic pain, and dyspareunia. This patient has none of these clinical features. Additionally, interstitial cystitis could not explain this patient's nausea and weakness, fever, and distinct right costovertebral angle tenderness.

Ascending bacteria from the bladder, typically due to underlying cystitis, is the most likely cause of this patient's pyelonephritis. Other risk factors include pregnancy, urinary tract obstruction (e.g., catheter, benign prostatic hyperplasia, vesicoureteral reflux), immunosuppression, and recurrent urinary tract infections.

A decreased urinary pH (e.g., due to a metabolic syndrome or medication) promotes the formation of radiolucent uric acid stones. Although the patient's nausea, weakness, and right costovertebral angle tenderness can present with kidney stones, the absence of colicky flank pain that often radiates into the groin area makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Since ∼ ⅔ of calcium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, a decrease in renal calcium reabsorption can cause radioopaque calcium urinary stones to form. Renal stones would be most common in individuals with excessive supplemental calcium intake or taking certain medications, such as loop diuretics or topiramate. Although the patient's nausea, weakness, and right costovertebral angle tenderness can present with kidney stones, the absence of colicky flank pain that often radiates into the groin area makes this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he frequently misplaces his personal belongings and becomes easily confused. His daughter mentions that his symptoms have progressively worsened for the past one year. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He vividly recalls memories from his childhood but can only recall one of three objects presented to him after 5 minutes. His affect is normal. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by damage to which of the following?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he frequently misplaces his personal belongings and becomes easily confused. His daughter mentions that his symptoms have progressively worsened for the past one year. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He vividly recalls memories from his childhood but can only recall one of three objects presented to him after 5 minutes. His affect is normal. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by damage to which of the following?
hint: Short-term memory loss is often the earliest sign of Alzheimer disease, the most common cause of progressive dementia in the United States.
learning_objective: Recognize Alzheimer disease, and recall the brain structures involved in memory formation.

answers.explanation_why: The substantia nigra is part of the basal ganglia and plays a role in initiation of voluntary movements. Damage to this region occurs in Parkinson disease, which presents with bradykinesia, tremor, and/or rigidity. This patient has memory deficits, which are unlikely to be caused by damage to the substantia nigra.

The amygdala is a structure of the limbic system that plays a role in the processing of emotions. Involvement of the amygdala in Alzheimer disease causes emotional lability, depression, and/or anhedonia. Damage to a different structure would more likely explain the short-term memory loss in this patient with a normal affect.
answers.explanation_but: Bilateral damage to the amygdala results in Klüver-Bucy syndrome, which is characterized by emotional lability, anxiety, hypersexuality, hyperorality, and hyperphagia.

answers.explanation_why: The ventral posterolateral nucleus is a structure of the thalamus involved in relaying sensory input from the spinothalamic tract and dorsal column to the primary somatosensory cortex. This nucleus does not play a role in memory formation and is not affected in early Alzheimer disease. The medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus and the anterior thalamic nucleus are involved in memory formation.

The nucleus accumbens is a basal forebrain structure that has a role in the reward pathway. This structure does not play a major role in semantic (factual) recall. Degeneration of other basal forebrain structures such as the nucleus basalis of Meynert can cause memory loss and cognitive decline in Alzheimer disease.
answers.explanation_but: Decreased GABA secretion by the nucleus accumbens is seen in Huntington disease and anxiety disorders.

answers.explanation_why: The earliest sites of neurodegeneration in Alzheimer disease are structures in the medial temporal lobe such as the hippocampus and parahippocampal cortex, which are critical for memory formation.

The superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere contains the primary auditory cortex and the Wernicke area. Damage to this structure would result in sensory aphasia. Early Alzheimer disease can cause atrophy of the medial temporal lobe structures but typically has little impact on the superior temporal gyrus.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman with polycystic ovarian syndrome comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of left lower abdominal pain that began suddenly while she was running. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left adnexa and rebound tenderness in the left lower quadrant. There is no tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urine pregnancy test is negative. An ultrasound is ordered to confirm the diagnosis of ruptured ovarian cyst. Visualization of fluid in which of the following locations would be most consistent with this diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman with polycystic ovarian syndrome comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of left lower abdominal pain that began suddenly while she was running. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left adnexa and rebound tenderness in the left lower quadrant. There is no tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urine pregnancy test is negative. An ultrasound is ordered to confirm the diagnosis of ruptured ovarian cyst. Visualization of fluid in which of the following locations would be most consistent with this diagnosis?
learning_objective: Recognize a ruptured ovarian cyst, and recall the anatomy of the rectouterine pouch.

answers.explanation_why: The lesser sac (omental bursa) is the largest intraperitoneal recess and lies dorsal to the stomach and lesser omentum. It is a common site of fluid accumulation in patients with intra-abdominal bleeding or acute pancreatitis. In a patient with a ruptured ovarian cyst, however, visualization of free fluid in this space is unlikely.

images.title: Peritoneal cavity (sagittal section)
images.description: The peritoneal cavity is the space between the parietal peritoneum, which lines the abdominopelvic cavity, and the visceral peritoneum, which invests the intraperitoneal organs. The visceral peritoneum also forms the mesentery, the greater omentum, and the lesser omentum. Intraperitoneal organs lie within the greater sac that extends from the diaphragm to the pelvis. The lesser sac (omental bursa) lies posterior to the stomach and the lesser omentum.

answers.explanation_why: The rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas) is an anatomic space located between the rectum and the uterus in females. It is the lowest point of the peritoneal cavity and therefore a common site of fluid collection (e.g., blood, serous fluid) in supine patients. A pelvic ultrasound showing free fluid in the rectouterine pouch would support the clinical diagnosis of ruptured ovarian cyst in a patient with classic features, as seen here.

The hepatorenal space (Morison pouch) is an anatomic space between the right kidney and the right lobe of the liver. It is a common site of fluid accumulation in a recumbent patient with intra-abdominal bleeding or ascites. Rupture of a large hemorrhagic ovarian cyst could cause hemoperitoneum with collection of blood in this space, but it is not the most likely site of free fluid accumulation in this patient.

The splenorenal angle (Koller pouch) is an anatomic space between the spleen and the left kidney. It is a common site of fluid accumulation in a recumbent patient with intra-abdominal bleeding or ascites. Rupture of a large hemorrhagic ovarian cyst could cause a hemoperitoneum with collection of blood in the splenorenal angle, but it is not the most likely site of free fluid accumulation in this patient.

The rectovesical pouch is an anatomic space between the rectum and the bladder in males. It is the lowest point of the peritoneal cavity and a common site of intrapelvic free fluid accumulation in men. Women do not have a rectovesical pouch because the uterus is located between the rectum and the bladder.
