question_text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the patient's right forearm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the patient's right forearm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with the most common elbow injury in children < 5 years of age. It is caused by sudden axial traction on the pronated and extended forearm.
learning_objective: Recognize radial head subluxation.

answers.explanation_why: A proximal ulnar fracture (Monteggia fracture) can occur alongside this patient's condition. This fracture is typically caused by either a fall on an outstretched arm or a direct forceful blow to the elbow. Considering the history of this patient, this fracture is unlikely. The clinical presentation would also be more severe.

An anterior shoulder dislocation causes severe shoulder pain. Unlike in this patient, it usually occurs when falling on an outstretched arm, and the arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Common complications are axillary nerve and rotator cuff injury.

Supracondylar humerus fractures are the most common pediatric fractures. These fractures mainly occur in the age group of 5–8 years. This fracture is unlikely to occur from pure traction on an arm. Additionally, we would expect local swelling and potentially a lesion of the median nerve with loss of wrist flexion, thumb opposition, and loss of thenar sensation.
An olecranon fracture occurs through direct hits to the elbow or falls, which did not happen to this patient. Examination would show local elbow swelling and maybe dislocation of the olecranon.

Radial head subluxation (also referred to as “pulled elbow” or “nursemaid elbow”) describes the slipping of the annular ligament over the radial head that results in partial dislocation of the radial head at the level of the radio-humeral joint. This injury most commonly occurs in children < 5 years of age due to sudden tugging of the outstretched and pronated arm (e.g., pulling of a child's arm to keep them from falling). Clinical features include painful and limited movement of the upper extremity without swelling; the injured individual typically holds their forearm in a flexed and pronated position. The diagnosis is made clinically based on characteristic history and clinical features; radiologic confirmation is usually not required.

Management is conservative and involves closed, manual reduction of the radial head; the radial head can be relocated by hyperpronation of the forearm or supination of the forearm with the elbow in flexion.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of cramps in her left leg. Physical examination shows flexion of the left hip and increased tone in the thigh muscles. A local anesthetic block of which of the following nerves would most likely improve this patient's condition the most?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of cramps in her left leg. Physical examination shows flexion of the left hip and increased tone in the thigh muscles. A local anesthetic block of which of the following nerves would most likely improve this patient's condition the most?
hint: This patient is showing signs of spasticity, a common clinical feature of multiple sclerosis, of the hip flexors. The nerve that innervates these muscles originates from spinal roots L2–L4 and lies below the inguinal ligament.
learning_objective: Recall the innervation of the hip flexors and the effects of femoral nerve block.

answers.explanation_why: The obturator nerve (L2–L4 nerve roots) primarily innervates most of the hip adductors. Blocking it would not improve this patient's spastic hip flexion.

The sciatic nerve (L4–S3 nerve roots) innervates much of the lower extremity musculature directly (the adductor magnus and the hamstring muscles: biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus) or via the common peroneal nerve and its subsequent branches. The hamstring muscles function as flexors and rotators of the knee and extensors of the hip. Blocking the sciatic nerve would decrease countering hip extension and thus exacerbate this patient's spastic hip flexion.

The inferior gluteal nerve (L5–S2 nerve roots) primarily innervates the gluteus maximus, which functions as a hip extensor and external rotator. Blocking it would decrease countering hip extension and thus exacerbate spastic hip flexion.

Motor fibers of the femoral nerve (L2–L4 nerve roots) innervate the hip flexors. Selectively blocking the femoral nerve would improve hip flexor spasticity. One adverse effect, though, would be a loss of knee extension because the nerve also innervates the quadriceps femoris muscles. Since the femoral nerves also provide sensory-only fibers, another adverse effect would be a loss of feeling of her anteromedial thigh via blocking of the anterior cutaneous branches, as well as the medial lower leg and foot via a saphenous nerve deficit, respectively.

The superior gluteal nerve (L4–S1 nerve roots) innervates the gluteus minimus and gluteus medius, which function primarily as hip abductors, internal rotators, and external rotators of the thigh (if the hip is extended). The nerve also innervates the tensor fascia latae, which does indeed participate in hip flexion. Although blocking the superior gluteal nerve could minimally improve this patient's spastic hip flexion, blocking another nerve would improve this patient's condition more since the nerve plays a much more dominant role in hip flexion.

question_text: A 62-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease and osteoarthritis is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe, stabbing epigastric pain. For the last 6 months, he has had progressively worsening right knee pain, for which he takes ibuprofen several times a day. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia without ST-segment elevations or depressions. This patient is most likely to have referred pain in which of the following locations?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease and osteoarthritis is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe, stabbing epigastric pain. For the last 6 months, he has had progressively worsening right knee pain, for which he takes ibuprofen several times a day. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia without ST-segment elevations or depressions. This patient is most likely to have referred pain in which of the following locations?
hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for peptic ulcer disease, including smoking, NSAID use, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The sudden onset of pain is concerning for a perforated peptic ulcer.
learning_objective: Recognize a perforated peptic ulcer, and recall the pattern of referred pain.

answers.explanation_why: The right arm is not a typical location of referred pain. Although radiation of pain to the left arm is seen in myocardial infarction, the right arm is not a typical location of referred pain in any condition. This patient's risk factors and symptoms are consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer, which typically manifests with referred pain to a different region of the body.

This patient's history of smoking and chronic NSAID use put him at increased risk of developing peptic ulcers. Perforated gastric ulcers can manifest with the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, as seen in this patient, and referred pain to the left shoulder due to irritation of the left hemidiaphragm. Both the phrenic nerve (C3-5), which innervates the diaphragm, and the supraclavicular nerves (C3-4), which innervate the shoulder, share sensory fibers from the C3-4 nerve roots.

Periumbilical pain is seen in conditions that cause irritation of the T10 dermatome, such as in the early stages of appendicitis. This patient's risk factors and symptoms are more consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer, which is associated with referred pain in a different region of the body.

Referred pain to the jaw can occur in a myocardial infarction and is caused by irritation of nerves of the cervical plexus, which innervate the neck and the jaw. Although this patient's smoking history is a risk factor for coronary artery disease, his normal ECG makes this diagnosis less likely.

Referred pain to the groin can occur in conditions that cause irritation to the L1 dermatome, including nephrolithiasis, hip arthritis, and testicular pathology. This patients risk factors and symptoms are more consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer, which is associated with referred pain to a different region of the body.

question_text: A 78-year-old right-handed man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of nausea and vertigo 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows 5/5 strength in all extremities. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is decreased in the right arm and leg. A CT scan of the brain shows an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 78-year-old right-handed man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of nausea and vertigo 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows 5/5 strength in all extremities. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is decreased in the right arm and leg. A CT scan of the brain shows an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior cerebral artery infarction, and recall the expected visual field deficit.

answers.explanation_why: Left-sided hemineglect would be consistent with damage to the right parietal lobe (e.g., due to a right middle cerebral artery stroke), which is usually associated with contralateral motor and sensory deficits. In this patient, a posterior cerebral artery stroke was diagnosed and no motor deficits are present.

answers.content: Right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
answers.explanation_why: The posterior cerebral artery supplies parts of the thalamus and the visual cortex within the occipital lobe. In addition to contralateral hemisensory loss due to lateral thalamic infarction (as seen in this patient), occlusion to the posterior cerebral artery causes damage to the visual cortex that results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Central vision is not impaired in posterior cerebral artery infarction since the corresponding cortical area of the macula is supplied by the middle cerebral artery.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Gaze deviation towards the side of infarction (in this case: left-sided gaze deviation) combined with contralateral sensory loss, as seen in this patient, would be consistent with infarction of the left middle cerebral artery, which supplies the frontal eye field. Affected patients are also likely to present with right-sided motor dysfunction and aphasia. This patient, however, presents with posterior cerebral artery stroke.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: Prosopagnosia is most commonly seen with right posterior cerebral artery strokes (e.g., infarction of the right occipitotemporal lobe). This would not be an expected finding in a patient with a left posterior cerebral artery stroke, as seen here.

Right upper homonymous quadrantanopia would suggest a lesion in the left optic radiation and can be seen in strokes involving the left middle cerebral artery. This finding would not be expected in a patient with a posterior cerebral artery stroke.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headache and impaired vision. She says that she frequently misses turns while driving and hurts herself by accidentally bumping into objects. Confrontational visual field testing shows decreased vision in the left side of both visual fields. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a lesion in which of the following locations?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headache and impaired vision. She says that she frequently misses turns while driving and hurts herself by accidentally bumping into objects. Confrontational visual field testing shows decreased vision in the left side of both visual fields. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a lesion in which of the following locations?
hint: A visual deficit involving homologous sides of both visual fields is known as homonymous hemianopsia.
learning_objective: Recognize homonymous hemianopsia, and recall neuroanatomy of the visual pathway.

answers.explanation_why: The cranial nerve II (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the right CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (right anopsia) as well as a right relative afferent pupillary defect. A lesion here would not be expected as the cause of this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

The x-shaped optic chiasm is the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure would cause bitemporal hemianopsia in both visual fields, as opposed to this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

images.title: Heteronymous bitemporal hemianopsia
images.description: Simulation of right and left visual fieldLoss of vision in the temporal half of both the right and left visual fields can be seen. This can occur when the optic chiasma is compressed, often due to tumors of the pituitary gland or craniopharyngioma.

answers.explanation_why: The cranial nerve II (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the left CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (left anopsia) as well as a left relative afferent pupillary defect. A lesion here would not be expected to cause this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia

The optic tracts relay visual information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus, from where it continues to the occipital lobe and primary visual cortex. Each tract contains fibers from both the ipsilateral temporal hemiretina and the contralateral nasal hemiretina. The right optic tract, therefore, transmits visual information from the left visual field and vice versa. A right optic tract lesion (e.g., due to compression by an aneurysm, multiple sclerosis, infection, or stroke) has likely caused this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

images.title: Overview of visual field defects
images.description:
(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

answers.explanation_why: A left optic tract lesion would cause right homonymous hemianopsia (i.e., on the right side of both visual fields). However, this patient has left homonymous hemianopsia.

The cranial nerve III (CN III) innervates four of six extraocular muscles and provides parasympathetic stimulation to the ipsilateral eye. Damage to the right oculomotor nerve would cause monocular diplopia of the right eye, resulting in blurring of the visual field rather than vision loss. CN III palsy does not cause homonymous hemianopsia.

The cranial nerve III (CN III) innervates four of six extraocular muscles and provides parasympathetic stimulation to the ipsilateral eye. Damage to the left oculomotor nerve would cause monocular diplopia of the left eye, resulting in blurring of the visual field rather than vision loss. CN III palsy does not cause homonymous hemianopsia.

(C) Left optic nerve

(E) Left optic tract

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of acute left-sided chest pain and dyspnea following a motor vehicle accident. His pulse is 122/min and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins and tracheal displacement to the right side. The left chest is hyperresonant to percussion and there are decreased breath sounds. This patient would most benefit from needle insertion at which of the following anatomical sites?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of acute left-sided chest pain and dyspnea following a motor vehicle accident. His pulse is 122/min and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins and tracheal displacement to the right side. The left chest is hyperresonant to percussion and there are decreased breath sounds. This patient would most benefit from needle insertion at which of the following anatomical sites?
hint: This pediatric patient presents with acute respiratory distress, hemodynamic instability, a hyperresonant chest with reduced ipsilateral expansion, contralateral tracheal deviation, and distended neck veins after sustaining trauma, which is consistent with a tension pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize tension pneumothorax, and choose the correct anatomical site for needle decompression.

answers.content: 2nd left intercostal space along the midclavicular line
answers.explanation_why:
The 2^nd left intercostal space along the midclavicular line is the recommended needle insertion site for emergency decompression of a tension pneumothorax in a child. The patient here is unstable with hypotension and tachycardia, so the pneumothorax should be decompressed as quickly as possible. Since the neurovascular bundle runs below each rib, the upper edge of the rib is the preferred puncture site to help mitigate the risk of excessive bleeding and nerve damage. Emergency needle thoracostomy should be followed by chest tube placement in the 5^th intercostal space along the midaxillary line.

According to the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines, the 2^nd left intercostal space along the midclavicular line is no longer the preferred needle insertion site for emergency decompression of a tension pneumothorax in adults. This location is associated with high failure rates because of increased anterior chest wall thickness. Instead, placing the needle in the 5^th left intercostal space along the midaxillary line is preferable.

images.title: Thoracostomy sites
images.description: The 2^nd intercostal space, located at the midclavicular line (1; orange marker), can be used in both adults and children for emergency needle thoracostomy to decompress a tension pneumothorax.The 4^th or 5^th intercostal space, between the anterior and midaxillary lines (2; blue marker), is the standard site for tube thoracostomy in both adults and children and in adults may also be used for needle thoracostomy.

answers.content: 5th left intercostal space along the midaxillary line
answers.explanation_why: The 5^th left intercostal space along the midaxillary line is a common site for a chest tube placement to treat pleural effusions, hemothorax, or pneumothorax in both children and adults. Although the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines also recommend this insertion site for emergency needle decompression of a tension pneumothorax in adults, a different site is recommended in children.

answers.content: 8th left intercostal space along the posterior axillary line
answers.explanation_why: The 8^th left intercostal space along the posterior axillary line is a possible location to perform a thoracocentesis, which may be necessary in patients with pleural effusion. Although pleural effusion also manifests with acute respiratory distress, reduced ipsilateral chest expansion, and contralateral tracheal deviation as seen here, it causes dullness to percussion, not hyperresonance.

answers.content: Subxiphoid space in the left sternocostal margin
answers.explanation_why: The subxiphoid space in the left sternocostal margin is the typical puncture site for performing a pericardiocentesis. Tachycardia, hypotension, and distended neck veins can also be seen in pericardial tamponade. However, decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion of the left lung are not features of pericardial tamponade.

answers.content: 5th left intercostal space along the midclavicular line
answers.explanation_why: The apex of the heart is located behind the 5^th left intercostal space along the midclavicular line. This puncture site is not recommended because of the high risk of damaging the heart. In addition, needle insertion at this site does not provide decompression of a tension pneumothorax.

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of right shoulder pain that began after he repainted his house 1 week ago. Physical examination shows right subacromial tenderness. The pain is reproduced when the patient is asked to abduct the shoulder against resistance with the arm flexed forward by 30° and the thumb pointing downwards. The tendon of which of the following muscles is most likely to be injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of right shoulder pain that began after he repainted his house 1 week ago. Physical examination shows right subacromial tenderness. The pain is reproduced when the patient is asked to abduct the shoulder against resistance with the arm flexed forward by 30° and the thumb pointing downwards. The tendon of which of the following muscles is most likely to be injured in this patient?
hint: Physical examination shows a positive empty can test, a maneuver that specifically assesses one of the rotator cuff muscles.
learning_objective: Recognize injury to the supraspinatus tendon.

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the supraspinatus tendon and/or muscle manifests with pain triggered by overhead motion (e.g., when painting a house). Pain during the empty can test suggests injury to the supraspinatus tendon and/or muscle. In this test, forward flexion and internal rotation of the arm enables isolated examination of the supraspinatus muscle, independent of the deltoid muscle.

images.title: Jobe test
images.description: In Jobe test, the examiner applies downward pressure (red arrow) onto the abducted, horizontally flexed, and internally rotated arm of the patient. The patient is asked to resist the downward pressure (green arrow). The supraspinatus muscle, in particular, is required to maintain the arm's position. If there is pain or if the patient is unable to maintain this position against resistance exerted by the examiner, this indicates a functional disorder of the supraspinatus muscle (e.g., rupture, tendinopathy, or subacromial bursitis). If an impairment is present, Jobe's test is considered positive.

answers.explanation_why: Injury of the subscapularis muscle manifests with shoulder pain and/or weakness but it is not associated with subacromial tenderness or a positive empty can test. Injury of the subscapularis muscle can be clinically assessed using the lift-off test.

Injury of the infraspinatus muscle manifests with shoulder pain but it is not associated with subacromial tenderness or a positive empty can test. It can be clinically assessed using the infraspinatus test.

images.title: Infraspinatus test
images.description: The patient's arm is abducted to 90° and the humerus is medially rotated to 30° (green arrow around the arm). The examiner applies resistance (red arrow) to the back of the patient's hand (green arrow), while the patient is asked to maintain his/her position. The examiner should ensure that the patient's elbow is not be positioned against the chest, which would prevent abutment in external rotation (line outlined in red).

answers.explanation_why: Injury of the teres minor muscle manifests as shoulder pain and/or weakness but it is not associated with subacromial tenderness or a positive empty can test. Instead, injury of the teres minor muscle causes a positive hornblower's sign.

Injury of the deltoid muscle manifests with shoulder pain and/or weakness but it is not associated with subacromial tenderness or a positive empty can test. Injury of the deltoid muscle can be clinically assessed using the akimbo test.

question_text: A previously healthy 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of a painless mass in his left groin that has been gradually increasing in size. Physical examination shows a 3 x 3 cm oval, nontender left inguinal mass and a fluctuant, painless left scrotal swelling that increases in size with coughing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A previously healthy 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of a painless mass in his left groin that has been gradually increasing in size. Physical examination shows a 3 x 3 cm oval, nontender left inguinal mass and a fluctuant, painless left scrotal swelling that increases in size with coughing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: In a young patient, inguinal swelling and signs of hydrocele (fluctuant, painless swelling of the scrotum that increases with coughing) suggest an indirect inguinal hernia.
learning_objective: Recognize indirect inguinal hernia due to processus vaginalis patency.

answers.content: Failure of processus vaginalis to close
answers.explanation_why: The processus vaginalis descends anterior to the testis via the gubernaculum during embryonic development. Failure of this conduit to obliterate after testicular descent into the scrotum causes outpouching of the parietal peritoneum (and bowel) through the deep inguinal ring, the inguinal canal, and the superficial inguinal ring, leading to an indirect inguinal hernia. These hernias are located outside the Hesselbach triangle, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, and can manifest with a communicating hydrocele, as seen in this patient.

Obstruction of the left spermatic vein would lead to a left-sided varicocele. Although a varicocele can also manifest as a painless enlargement of the scrotum that increases in size with standing or coughing, an inguinal mass would not be expected.

images.title: Varicocele
images.description: Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.

answers.explanation_why: Incomplete descent of the left testicle is seen in cryptorchidism, which can manifest with a mass in the inguinal region (between the external and internal inguinal ring). However, cryptorchidism is usually identified early in life and treated with orchiopexy around 6–18 months of age. It would therefore be unlikely in this 20-year-old patient.

answers.content: Reduced fluid reabsorption at tunica vaginalis
answers.explanation_why: Reduced fluid reabsorption in the tunica vaginalis can lead to a non-communicating hydrocele. Although this patient has clinical evidence of a hydrocele (a fluctuant painless swelling of the scrotum), the increase in swelling when coughing indicates that it is a communicating hydrocele, which implies a different mechanism.

Widening of the femoral ring is the mechanism underlying femoral hernias. Although femoral hernias manifest with an inguinal mass, the mass would be inferior to the inguinal ligament and would not cause a hydrocele. Furthermore, femoral hernias most commonly develop in older women (∼ 40–70 years of age).

images.title: Femoral hernia
images.description:
Sagittal view of the male inguinal region at the level of the superior pubic ramus, medial to the epigastric vessels

There is a protruding hernial sac (comprised of the transversalis fascia and parietal peritoneum) below the inguinal ligament but above the pubic bone, which, in the example shown, contains intestine.

answers.explanation_why: Weakening of the transversalis fascia can lead to a direct inguinal hernia. Although direct inguinal hernias also manifest with an inguinal mass, a hydrocele would not be expected. This type of hernia is located within the Hesselbach triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels, and only protrudes through the superficial (external) inguinal ring without involvement of the spermatic cord.

images.title: Direct inguinal hernia
images.description: Illustration depicting the inguinal area, medial to the inferior epigastric blood vessels (sagittal plane; male patient)1: internal oblique; 2: transversus abdominis; 3: external oblique aponeurosis; 4: transversalis fascia; 5: parietal peritoneum; 6: intestine; 7: inguinal ligament; 8: lacunar ligament; 9: superior pubic ramus; 10: spermatic cord

question_text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after undergoing right-sided radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer. She says that she has been unable to comb her hair with her right hand since the surgery. Physical examination shows shoulder asymmetry. She is unable to abduct her right arm above 90 degrees. When she pushes against a wall, there is protrusion of the medial aspect of the right scapula. Injury to which of the following nerves is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after undergoing right-sided radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer. She says that she has been unable to comb her hair with her right hand since the surgery. Physical examination shows shoulder asymmetry. She is unable to abduct her right arm above 90 degrees. When she pushes against a wall, there is protrusion of the medial aspect of the right scapula. Injury to which of the following nerves is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This woman has a winged scapula caused by paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize winged scapula, and recall the nerve that innervates the serratus anterior muscle.

answers.content: Upper trunk of the brachial plexus
answers.explanation_why: The upper trunk of the brachial plexus can be injured by trauma (e.g., shoulder dystocia during labor) but is at low risk for injury during axillary lymph node dissection. This nerve injury manifests with an adducted, extended, pronated, and medially rotated arm (Erb palsy). It does not cause a winged scapula.

The axillary nerve can be injured by trauma (e.g., anterior shoulder dislocation) or iatrogenic damage (e.g., rotator cuff surgery) but is at low risk for injury during axillary lymph node dissection. Axillary nerve injury impairs arm abduction due to paralysis of the deltoid muscle. However, it also impairs external rotation of the arm (due to paralysis of the teres minor muscle) and leads to a sensory deficit over the lower half of the deltoid region (due to injury to the superior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm). It does not cause a winged scapula.

This patient has evidence of a long thoracic nerve injury, which is a common complication of axillary lymph node dissection. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle; injury to the nerve typically results in medial winging of the scapula and impaired abduction of the arm beyond 90°.

images.title: Medial winging of the scapula
images.description: When the patient is asked to place both palms against a wall and push, the medial border of the right scapula is abnormally prominent.This is the characteristic appearance of scapular winging. It indicates a palsy of the serratus anterior, which is most commonly due to an injury of the long thoracic nerve.

answers.explanation_why: The suprascapular nerve is not located in the axillary region and thus is at low risk for injury during axillary lymph node dissection. Suprascapular nerve injury causes paralysis of the infraspinatus and supraspinatus muscles, which limits adduction, abduction, and external rotation of the arm and causes shoulder instability (due to paralysis of rotator cuff muscles). It does not cause a winged scapula.

The thoracodorsal nerve, which innervates the latissimus dorsi and teres major muscles, can also be injured during axillary lymph node dissection. However, this nerve injury impairs shoulder retraction and adduction and internal rotation of the arm. It does not cause a winged scapula.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Pelvic examination shows a pink, 2 x 2 cm, fluctuant swelling at the right posterior vaginal introitus. The swelling is most likely derived from which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Pelvic examination shows a pink, 2 x 2 cm, fluctuant swelling at the right posterior vaginal introitus. The swelling is most likely derived from which of the following structures?
hint: A mass located posterolaterally at the vaginal introitus suggests a Bartholin cyst.
learning_objective: Recognize a Bartholin cyst, and recall its anatomical origin.

answers.explanation_why: Squamous cell carcinoma, which is the most common type of vulvar carcinoma (90% of cases), arises from the epithelium of the vulva. The most common sites for vulvar carcinoma are the anterior two-thirds of the labia major, followed by the clitoris. The lesion typically presents as an indurated white patch (leukoplakia) or an ulceroproliferative lesion. A pink fluctuant swelling in the posterior introitus is not consistent with vulvar carcinoma.

Obstruction of the orifice of the paraurethral glands (Skene glands) results in the formation of Skene ducts cysts, which are typically small (< 1 cm) and do not cause any symptoms. Unlike this patient's palpable mass in the area of the posterior vaginal introitus, skene glands are located on the anterior vaginal wall, close to the opening of the urethra.

This woman in the reproductive age group most likely has a cystic dilatation of the greater vestibular glands (Bartholin glands), which are located at the posterior vaginal introitus in the superficial perineal pouch. Obstruction of the orifice of the Bartholin gland duct by inflammation or trauma results in the formation of a Bartholin cyst. Infection of the Bartholin cyst (Bartholin abscess) would result in a tender swelling and severe dyspareunia.

A Gartner duct cyst originates from a vestigial remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) and can present as a palpable vaginal mass. However, a Gartner duct cyst is typically found in the anterolateral wall of the superior part of the vagina, unlike this patient's swelling, which is located in the posterior vaginal introitus.

Occlusion of the orifices of the sebaceous glands results in Fordyce spots, which are pinhead-sized, yellowish-white spots distributed symmetrically on the labia. The finding in this patient is not consistent with Fordyce spots.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the obstetrician for a prenatal visit. She has had a tingling pain in the thumb, index finger, and middle finger of her right hand for the past 6 weeks. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick touch on the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger of the right hand. The pain is reproduced when the dorsal side of each hand is pressed against each other. Without treatment of her current condition, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the obstetrician for a prenatal visit. She has had a tingling pain in the thumb, index finger, and middle finger of her right hand for the past 6 weeks. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick touch on the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger of the right hand. The pain is reproduced when the dorsal side of each hand is pressed against each other. Without treatment of her current condition, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
hint: A positive Phalen test (pain or tingling with passive flexion of wrists) suggests median nerve impingement in the carpal tunnel.
learning_objective: Recognize carpal tunnel syndrome, and recall its potential complications.

answers.explanation_why: Nodules in the palmar fascia suggest Dupuytren contracture. This condition often results in thickened, cord-like palmar fascial bands, which lead to flexion contractures of the MCPs and PIPs. Patients may also have manifestations of fibroproliferative disease elsewhere in the body, such as in the plantar fascia. This patient has pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, suggesting carpal tunnel syndrome, which is not associated with Dupuytren contracture.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is the most common upper extremity neuropathy and is especially prevalent in pregnant women due to hormone-associated weight gain and peripheral edema compressing the median nerve. The thenar muscles (opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, and flexor pollicis brevis) are innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve; compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel can therefore cause thenar atrophy. Branches of the median nerve also provide sensory innervation to the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral (radial) half of the ring finger, which is why CTS causes pain and paresthesias in this distribution.

Other conditions associated with CTS include hypothyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis, and acromegaly.

images.title: Thenar atrophy secondary to median nerve injury
images.description: Atrophy of the left and right thenars (abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis muscles) secondary to bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome

answers.explanation_why: The interosseous muscles are intrinsic muscles of the hand that perform finger abduction (dorsal interosseous muscles) and adduction (palmar interosseous muscles). Because they are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, interosseous wasting can occur if the ulnar nerve is compressed or entrapped. The most common site of ulnar nerve entrapment is the cubital tunnel in the elbow, followed by the ulnar tunnel (Guyon's canal) in the hand.

Wrist drop occurs as a result of injury to the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), a branch of the radial nerve. Radial nerve injury can occur following mid-shaft humerus fracture, as the radial nerve runs in the spiral groove along the posterior humerus, as well as fracture or dislocation of the radius, which can cause direct injury to the PIN. Other common causes of radial nerve injury include the use of axillary crutches and saturday night palsy.

The hypothenar muscles include the opponens digiti minimi, the abductor digiti minimi, and the flexor digiti minimi, which are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. Hypothenar weakness can occur in ulnar nerve entrapment, which occurs most frequently at the cubital tunnel in the elbow, followed by the ulnar tunnel (Guyon's canal) in the hand.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of difficulty swallowing, a foreign body sensation at the back of his throat, and trouble breathing at night. He has just recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection that began 5 days ago. On questioning, he reports that he has had similar symptoms in the past each time he has had an upper respiratory tract infection. Physical examination shows a 3 cm x 2-cm, nontender, rubbery midline mass at the base of the tongue. His skin is dry and cool. An image of his technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of difficulty swallowing, a foreign body sensation at the back of his throat, and trouble breathing at night. He has just recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection that began 5 days ago. On questioning, he reports that he has had similar symptoms in the past each time he has had an upper respiratory tract infection. Physical examination shows a 3 cm x 2-cm, nontender, rubbery midline mass at the base of the tongue. His skin is dry and cool. An image of his technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
hint: The technetium-99m thyroid scan shows radioisotope uptake at the base of the tongue and the hyoid region, but no uptake in the normal location of the thyroid on the anterior neck, findings which suggest an ectopic thyroid gland.
learning_objective: Recognize ectopic thyroid tissue, and recall its developmental origin.

answers.content: Ductal obstruction of the sublingual salivary glands
answers.explanation_why: Ductal obstruction of the sublingual salivary glands would cause backup of secretions, resulting in a mucocele on the floor of the mouth (i.e., a ranula). While this could theoretically cause this patient's dysphagia and dyspnea, it would not explain his abnormal technetium-99m scan.

answers.content: Chronic infection of the palatine and lingual tonsils
answers.explanation_why: Chronic tonsillitis of the palatine and lingual tonsils would cause adenotonsillar hypertrophy. This could be exacerbated by URIs and cause dysphagia and dyspnea, all of which would apply to this patient. However, adenotonsillar hypertrophy does not explain the mass at the base of the tongue or the abnormal uptake on this patient's technetium-99m scan.

answers.content: Arrested endodermal migration from pharyngeal floor
answers.explanation_why: Arrested endodermal migration of the thyroid gland from the pharyngeal floor describes the process by which a thyroglossal duct cyst or ectopic thyroid can arise. This patient's technetium-99m scan shows thyroid tissue within the tongue, the most common location of ectopic thyroid tissue. As in this case, enlargement of ectopic thyroid is common with URIs due to the thyroid's lymphoid tissue and can cause dysphagia and dyspnea. Surgical removal of a lingual thyroid may result in hypothyroidism if there is no other site of thyroid tissue. Some patients with thyroid ectopia develop symptoms of hypothyroidism, which could explain this patient's dry and cool skin.

answers.content: Persistent epithelial tract between the foramen cecum and thyroid isthmus
answers.explanation_why: A persistent epithelial tract between the foramen cecum (tongue) and thyroid isthmus describes the thyroglossal duct. A thyroglossal duct cyst can arise anywhere along this tract and may become enlarged or inflamed after a URI, like with this patient. However, inflammation would be expected at the anterior neck (i.e., midline mass), rather than the tongue. Furthermore, a technetium-99m scan in a patient with a thyroglossal duct cyst would show uptake at the normally positioned thyroid gland, which is not the case here.

answers.content: Failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft
answers.explanation_why: Failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft describes the cause of a branchial cleft cyst. While branchial cleft cysts can result in neck masses, which this patient has, they are usually located laterally and inferior to the pharynx, and also do not typically enlarge following URIs. Furthermore, a branchial cleft cyst does not contain thyroid tissue or explain this patient's abnormal technetium-99m scan.

images.title: Ectopic thyroid tissue
images.description: Nuclear medicine thyroid scan (technetium-99m pertechnetate radioisotope; anterior and lateral views)Increased uptake of radiotracer is visible in the hyoid region and lingual or sublingual regions. There is no uptake in the normal location of the thyroid gland in the anterior neck.The findings indicate two sites of ectopic thyroid tissue. The possibility of ectopic tissue in a thyroglossal duct cyst would also be a consideration for the hyoid region uptake.

question_text: Two days after undergoing abdominal surgery for lysis of adhesions, a 52-year-old man has nausea and one episode of bilious vomiting. The patient's nausea is somewhat alleviated in the prone position. The patient has had a 70-kg (154-lb) weight loss since undergoing bariatric surgery 1 year ago. Physical examination shows abdominal distention. Sudden movement of the patient elicits a sloshing sound on auscultation of the abdomen. An upper gastrointestinal series of the abdomen with oral contrast shows no passage of contrast past the third segment of the duodenum. The obstruction in this patient is most likely caused by which of the following structures?
content_preview: Two days after undergoing abdominal surgery for lysis of adhesions, a 52-year-old man has nausea and one episode of bilious vomiting. The patient's nausea is somewhat alleviated in the prone position. The patient has had a 70-kg (154-lb) weight loss since undergoing bariatric surgery 1 year ago. Physical examination shows abdominal distention. Sudden movement of the patient elicits a sloshing sound on auscultation of the abdomen. An upper gastrointestinal series of the abdomen with oral contrast shows no passage of contrast past the third segment of the duodenum. The obstruction in this patient is most likely caused by which of the following structures?
hint: The structure in question can compress the part of the duodenum lying between it and the aorta, leading to features of small bowel obstruction such as nausea, bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and succussion splash (a sloshing sound heard on abdominal auscultation after moving the patient suddenly).
learning_objective: Recognize superior mesenteric artery syndrome, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why:
The superior mesenteric artery passes anterior to the third segment of the duodenum (transverse duodenum), and the aorta is located directly posterior to this part of the intestine. Compression of the duodenum by this artery is called superior mesenteric artery syndrome. The classic presentation includes postprandial pain and bilious emesis following extreme weight loss.

Rapid weight loss causes shrinkage of the fat pad between the superior mesenteric artery and the duodenum, leading to compression of the intestinal lumen. Pediatric patients with congenitally abnormal arterial anatomy or those undergoing corrective surgery for scoliosis are also at risk.

images.title: Superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMAS)
images.description: Narrowing of the angle between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the aorta (aortomesenteric angle) may result in the third portion of the duodenum being compressed between the two vessels, and subsequently small bowel obstruction.Note: This pathogenic mechanism may also cause nutcracker syndrome, in which the left renal vein (instead of the duodenum) is compressed between the SMA and the aorta.

answers.explanation_why: The distal second and proximal third segments of duodenum curve around the pancreas. Inflammation of the pancreas, e.g., in severe pancreatitis, or pancreatic mass effect, e.g., from a tumor, could lead to duodenal obstruction. However, this would be expected from a process involving the head of the pancreas. Because the body of the pancreas is not in close contact with the duodenum, a pathology in this area would be very unlikely to account for an obstruction of the intestinal lumen.

images.title: Pancreatic regional anatomy
images.description: The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary

answers.explanation_why: The gallbladder empties into the second segment of the duodenum. Direct obstruction of the duodenum by an enlarged gallbladder is very unlikely and would not cause third segment obstruction. In the very rare event of a fistula between the gallbladder and the duodenum, a gallstone can enter the intestinal lumen and cause an obstruction, which is known as gallstone ileus. However, gallstone ileus most often manifests with obstruction at the ileocecal valve.

images.title: Extrahepatic biliary tree
images.description: The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct drains into the common bile duct. The common bile duct opens into the descending part of the duodenum.

answers.explanation_why: The common bile duct enters the second segment of the duodenum. Cholangiocarcinoma of the bile duct at its junction with the duodenum can cause obstruction of the duodenum. However, this would result in second segment obstruction, not the third segment obstruction seen in this patient. Additionally, bilious emesis would not be expected, as bile flow through the common bile duct would be severely reduced or blocked entirely.

images.title: Extrahepatic biliary tree
images.description: The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct drains into the common bile duct. The common bile duct opens into the descending part of the duodenum.

answers.explanation_why: The portal vein arises from the confluence of the superior mesenteric and splenic vein posterior to the pancreas. It then travels superolaterally to the liver. It does not have contact with the duodenum and is not known to cause duodenal obstruction.

The inferior vena cava is located in the retroperitoneum where it passes posterior to the second and third segments of the duodenum and the pancreas. The inferior vena cava can easily be compressed due to its low intravascular pressure but is unlikely to cause obstruction of adjacent structures such as the duodenum.

question_text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of difficulty swallowing, low-grade fever, and weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an esophageal mass just distal to the upper esophageal sphincter. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of locally invasive squamous cell carcinoma. A surgical resection is planned. Which of the following structures is at greatest risk for injury during this procedure?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of difficulty swallowing, low-grade fever, and weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an esophageal mass just distal to the upper esophageal sphincter. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of locally invasive squamous cell carcinoma. A surgical resection is planned. Which of the following structures is at greatest risk for injury during this procedure?
hint: This patient presents with squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical portion of the esophagus.
learning_objective: Recall the blood supply of the cervical esophagus.

answers.explanation_why: The esophageal branch of thoracic aorta supplies the thoracic portion of the esophagus, which extends between the thoracic inlet and the gastroesophageal junction. A different structure is at higher risk of injury given the location of the mass.

The left inferior phrenic artery originates from the aorta and supplies the abdominal portion of the esophagus, which is located below the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm. A different structure is at higher risk of injury given the location of the mass.

images.title: Branches of the abdominal aorta
images.description:
There are:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)Note that the superior suprarenal artery originates from the inferior phrenic artery, while the inferior suprarenal artery originates from the renal artery.

answers.explanation_why: The inferior thyroid artery originates from the thyrocervical trunk, a branch of the subclavian artery. It supplies the cervical portion of the esophagus, which is 6–8 cm long and extends between the hypopharynx (lower border of the cricoid cartilage) and the thoracic inlet (suprasternal notch). Since this tumor is located in the cervical portion of the esophagus, care should be taken to avoid injuring this artery during the surgery.

images.title: Blood supply of the esophagus
images.description: The three different portions of the esophagus are supplied and drained by different vessels:The cervical esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches of the inferior thyroid artery and drains via esophageal veins into the inferior thyroid vein.The thoracic esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches from the thoracic aorta and drains via esophageal veins into the azygos and hemiazygos veins.The abdominal esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches of the left gastric artery and drains via the esophageal veins into the left gastric vein.

answers.explanation_why: The left gastric artery originates from the celiac trunk and supplies the abdominal portion of the esophagus, which is located below the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.

images.title: Branches of the celiac trunk
images.description: The celiac trunk and its three major branches: the left gastric artery, the splenic artery, and the common hepatic artery

answers.explanation_why: The bronchial branch of the thoracic aorta supplies parts of the trachea, bronchi, and thoracic portion of the esophagus, which extends between the thoracic inlet and the gastroesophageal junction. A different structure is at higher risk of injury given the location of the mass.

question_text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. Physical examination shows a deep laceration on the volar surface of the distal left forearm. Neurological examination shows loss of abduction and opposition of the left thumb. The radial and ulnar pulses are palpable. Based on these findings, which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. Physical examination shows a deep laceration on the volar surface of the distal left forearm. Neurological examination shows loss of abduction and opposition of the left thumb. The radial and ulnar pulses are palpable. Based on these findings, which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
hint: If this same nerve were injured more proximally (e.g., at or above the elbow), examination would show the hand of benediction sign.
learning_objective: Recognize median nerve injury.

answers.explanation_why: The posterior interosseous nerve is a terminal branch of the radial nerve located deep in the dorsal forearm, making it very unlikely to be injured by a volar laceration. Injury to this nerve typically causes extension deficits at the wrist and fingers. Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve does not affect abduction or opposition of the thumb.

The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor as well as the skin overlying the lateral shoulder. Injury to this nerve classically occurs with anterior shoulder dislocations or fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus and causes weak arm abduction and a characteristically flattened shoulder. Injury to the axillary nerve does not affect the thumb.

The radial nerve courses along the dorsal aspect of the forearm and thus is very unlikely to be injured by a volar laceration. Patients with radial nerve injuries typically have extension deficits at the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Injury to the radial nerve does not affect abduction or opposition of the thumb.

Laceration of the median nerve at the wrist causes loss of thumb abduction and opposition, as seen in this patient. Additional deficits include reduced or absent sensation in the thumb, index, middle, and radial-sided ring fingers. The laceration could be through the median nerve proper or through the recurrent branch of the median nerve. The presence of sensory disturbances would be the determining factor, as the recurrent branch solely provides motor innervation.

images.title: Proximal and distal median nerve lesions
images.description: AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

answers.explanation_why: The musculocutaneous nerve is not typically affected by distal forearm injuries. Injury to this nerve (e.g., from upper trunk compression) causes loss of forearm flexion and supination as well as loss of sensation over the lateral forearm. Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve does not affect abduction or opposition of the thumb.

Distal injuries to the ulnar nerve typically cause sensory deficits in the ulnar-sided ring and small fingers. Motor deficits manifest with hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints when the patient is asked to make a fist (ulnar claw). Injury to the ulnar nerve does not affect the thumb.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
hint: Impaired horizontal eye movements with weak adduction of one eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye are indicative of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which results from a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. In this young woman with a previous episode of neurologic dysfunction, the most likely cause of the lesion is multiple sclerosis.
learning_objective: Recognize internuclear ophthalmoplegia, and recall neuroanatomy of the midbrain.

answers.explanation_why: The right superior colliculus integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information with motor signals. This structure allows the orientation of the head towards stimuli. However, injury of the right superior colliculus would result in the inability to turn the head reflexively towards the left upon sensory stimulation from that side; it would not result in the impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

The left superior colliculus integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information with motor signals. This structure allows the orientation of the head towards stimuli. However, injury of the left superior colliculus would result in the inability to turn the head reflexively towards the right upon sensory stimulation from that side; it would not result in the impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) connects the nucleus of the CN VI (which controls ocular abduction) to the contralateral nucleus of the CN III (which controls ocular adduction). This connection allows for the coordination of both eyes during lateral gaze. Lesions in the MLF, such as those found in multiple sclerosis, disrupt adduction of the eye ipsilateral to the lesion, causing nystagmus in the contralateral eye as diplopia causes it to readjust.
Lesions in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus would cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia. However, double vision would occur on right lateral gaze, not left lateral gaze as seen in this patient.

The red nucleus is a large structure within the rostral midbrain that receives input from various motor areas, particularly the deep cerebellar nuclei. Lesions of the red nucleus can result in extensor posturing, with extension of both upper and lower extremities. However, lesions of the red nucleus do not cause an impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

The red nucleus is a large structure within the rostral midbrain that receives input from motor areas, particularly the deep cerebellar nuclei. Lesions of the red nucleus can result in extensor posturing, with the extension of both upper and lower extremities. However, lesions of the red nucleus do not cause an impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

Lesions of the right oculomotor nerve would impair the function of the medial rectus, which would, in turn, impair the adduction of the right eye, similar to this patient. However, complete palsy of the nerve would mean that the right eye would be in a down-and-out position and would fail to converge. Thus, nystagmus would not be found.

Lesions of the left oculomotor nerve would impair the function of the medial rectus, impairing adduction of the ipsilateral left eye. However, palsy of the left CN III would leave the left eye in a down-and-out position, without the ability to converge and with no nystagmus. Adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze would not be impaired.

images.title: Midbrain
images.description:
Cross section(A) Right superior colliculus
(B) Left superior colliculus
(C) Right medial longitudinal fasciculus
(D) Left medial longitudinal fasciculus
(E) Right red nucleus
(F) Left red nucleus
(G) Right oculomotor nerve
(H) Left oculomotor nerve

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Visual field testing shows the inability to see the right visual field in either eye (right homonymous hemianopia) with macular sparing, which most commonly results from decreased blood flow to the left occipital lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery.

answers.explanation_why: Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD types and causes a gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in the affected eyes, unlike what is seen in this patient.

Impaired perfusion of the retina has been observed in central retinal artery occlusion, which is caused by cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in old patients. It presents with an acute painless visual loss in the affected eye; it is usually unilateral and does not spare the macula, unlike in this patient.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.content: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery, usually due to emboli from the vertebral vessels, aorta, or heart, results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The macula is spared because the macular tracts have additional blood supply from the middle cerebral arteries.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral pontine syndrome. It manifests with vomiting, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner syndrome, facial muscle paralysis (lower motor neuron lesion type), and sensorineural hearing loss as well as contralateral hemisensory loss, none of which is seen in this patient.

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the most commonly occluded artery in ischemic strokes. Embolic occlusion of the MCA can occasionally lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, the other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be present. Isolated visual field defects are highly unlikely to occur in MCA embolism.
answers.explanation_but: The contralateral homonymous hemianopia in MCA occlusion rarely exhibits macular sparing. This is because the MCA supplies an extensive area of the brain and, thus, occlusion of the MCA affects not only the occipital visual cortex but also the visual pathways.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery does not affect the visual cortex but causes contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss affecting the lower limb more prominently than the upper limb. Primitive reflexes, like grasp reflexes and rooting reflexes, are also likely to re-emerge. This patient has none of these symptoms.

images.title: Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
images.description: Visual field test (perimetry)There is a bilateral loss of right lateral visual fields (black areas) with sparing of the macula (hatched overlay). Bilateral impairment of a unilateral visual field in each eye is known as homonymous hemianopia.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset, severe right flank pain. She was in her aerobics class when the pain started but denies any trauma to the region. She has a history of recurrent ovarian cysts. Menses occur regularly at 28-day intervals. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding. Pelvic ultrasound shows a large simple cyst on the right ovary. Right ovarian artery flow is detectable on Doppler, but there is no flow detected in the right ovarian vein. Which of the following ligaments is most likely to have been involved?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset, severe right flank pain. She was in her aerobics class when the pain started but denies any trauma to the region. She has a history of recurrent ovarian cysts. Menses occur regularly at 28-day intervals. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding. Pelvic ultrasound shows a large simple cyst on the right ovary. Right ovarian artery flow is detectable on Doppler, but there is no flow detected in the right ovarian vein. Which of the following ligaments is most likely to have been involved?
hint: This patient's sudden onset of severe right flank pain, history of recurrent ovarian cysts, and lack of ovarian venous flow on Doppler are consistent with ovarian torsion.
learning_objective: Recognize ovarian torsion, and recall the anatomy of the infundibulopelvic ligament.

answers.explanation_why: The broad ligament is a fold of peritoneum that is divided into three parts: mesosalpinx, mesometrium, and mesovarium. It connects the lateral uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries with the lateral pelvic wall. Although it is in close relation to the ovaries, the ligament does not contain the ovarian vessels and is not primarily affected during ovarian torsion.

The round ligament of the uterus connects the labia majora to the uterine horns. It is a remnant of the gubernaculum and does not contain any vessels. The ligament's main function is to maintain anteversion of the uterus in the pelvic cavity. It is not affected during ovarian torsion.

The ovarian ligament is an embryonic remnant of the gubernaculum and connects the medial pole of the ovary to the uterine horns. It contains the ovarian branches of the uterine vessels, not the ovarian vessels themselves, and is not primarily affected by ovarian torsion.

The cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the uterine vessels and the ureter, not the ovarian vessels. Furthermore, the cardinal ligament is not affected during ovarian torsion.

The infundibulopelvic ligament (suspensory ligament of the ovary) is a fold of peritoneum that connects the ovaries to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the ovarian artery, vein, nerves, and lymphatics, and is affected during ovarian torsion, which requires surgical management. If the ovary is deemed nonviable, the infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during oophorectomy. During this procedure, care must be taken not to damage the ureter, which is located directly posterior to the ligament in the retroperitoneum.

images.title: Ovarian torsion
images.description: In ovarian torsion, the ovary twists around the adnexal ligaments, resulting in compression of the ovarian veins and lymphatics, consequently causing venous congestion and edema. The most important risk factor is ovarian enlargement, which can occur (e.g., due to ovarian cysts).

question_text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of disorientation and slurred speech. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His blood pressure is 210/110 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. Once the patient is stabilized, an MRI of the brain is performed, which shows an infarct of the left precentral gyrus involving the region that supplies the facial nerve. Given the MRI findings, which of the following neurological findings would most be expected?
content_preview: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of disorientation and slurred speech. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His blood pressure is 210/110 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. Once the patient is stabilized, an MRI of the brain is performed, which shows an infarct of the left precentral gyrus involving the region that supplies the facial nerve. Given the MRI findings, which of the following neurological findings would most be expected?
hint: A lesion of the corticobulbar tract between the precentral gyrus and the brainstem nuclei of the facial nerve causes central facial nerve palsy.
learning_objective: Recognize central facial nerve palsy, and recall its characteristic neurological findings.

answers.content: Loss of taste in the posterior third of the right half of the tongue
answers.explanation_why: Taste to the posterior third of the tongue is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve and would therefore not be impaired in central facial nerve palsy. Facial nerve palsy may affect taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, since this region is innervated by the parasympathetic fibers supplied by the chorda tympani. However, central facial nerve palsy causes contralateral deficits, and a lesion to the precentral gyrus, the location of the primary motor cortex, does not affect taste.

answers.content: Flattening of the right nasolabial fold
answers.explanation_why: Flattening of the right nasolabial fold would be expected in central facial nerve palsy. The facial motor nucleus has two regions: one that supplies the muscles of the forehead and a second that supplies the rest of the face. The branches of the facial nerve that innervate the forehead are activated by both cerebral hemispheres, whereas the branches innervating the lower portion of the face are only activated by the contralateral cerebral hemisphere. As a result, the forehead is spared with unilateral infarction of the precentral gyrus, while the contralateral lower face becomes paralyzed.

images.title: Examination findings in facial nerve palsy
images.description: Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

answers.content: Decreased lacrimation of the left eye
answers.explanation_why: Lacrimation of the eye is modulated by the greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve that carries parasympathetic fibers, and could therefore be impaired by peripheral facial nerve palsy. Decreased lacrimation of the left eye would be expected in left-sided peripheral facial palsy. However, central facial nerve palsy causes contralateral deficits, and a lesion to the precentral gyrus, the location of the primary motor cortex, does not affect lacrimation.

Drooping of the ipsilateral eyelid is seen in third nerve palsy, which may be caused by trauma, ischemia, migraine (cranial neuralgia), intracranial aneurysm or is idiopathic (Bell palsy). In central facial nerve palsy, drooping of the eyelid would not be expected, since the forehead is innervated by fibers from both cerebral hemispheres.

Hyperacusis of the left ear would be a result of paralysis of the stapedius muscle. The stapedius muscle is supplied by the nerve to stapedius, a branch of the facial nerve, and could therefore be impaired in facial nerve palsy. Hyperacusis of the left ear would be expected in left-sided peripheral facial palsy. However, since central facial nerve palsy causes contralateral lesions, in this patient hyperacusis of the right ear would be expected.

answers.content: Inability to raise the right eyebrow
answers.explanation_why: Inability to raise the right eyebrow is seen in ipsilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, which is commonly caused by trauma (e.g., zygomatic fractures, lacerations), infection (e.g., herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus), tumors (e.g., neuromas, parotid gland tumors), or is idiopathic (Bell palsy). In central facial nerve palsy, drooping of the eyebrow would not be expected, since the forehead is innervated by fibers from both cerebral hemispheres.
