question_text: A 78-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of abdominal pain. Abdominal examination shows guarding with diffuse rebound tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm that extends down to the level of the L4 vertebra and a partial filling defect in the anterior wall of the aneurysm. Which of the following bowel regions is at greatest risk for requiring resection?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of abdominal pain. Abdominal examination shows guarding with diffuse rebound tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm that extends down to the level of the L4 vertebra and a partial filling defect in the anterior wall of the aneurysm. Which of the following bowel regions is at greatest risk for requiring resection?
hint: The renal arteries originate from the lateral surface of the aorta at the level of the L2 vertebra. The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) arises from the anterior surface of the aorta at the level of the L3 vertebra. Occlusion at the opening of the IMA by a thrombus within an aortic aneurysm (suggested by the filling defect) would cause acute mesenteric ischemia and, potentially, necrosis of the bowel segments supplied by this artery.
learning_objective: Recognize acute mesenteric ischemia, and recall the vascular supply of the colon.

answers.content: Splenic flexure, descending colon, and sigmoid colon
answers.explanation_why: The splenic flexure, descending colon, and sigmoid colon, which are supplied by the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA), are most at risk for requiring surgical resection in this patient's case. The IMA also supplies the rectum and the region of the anal canal above the pectinate line via the superior rectal artery.

images.title: Watershed areas in colon ischemia
images.description: The watershed areas of the colon are the splenic flexure (Griffiths point) and the rectosigmoid junction (Sudeck point).The splenic flexure is supplied by the ascending branch of the left colic artery (from the inferior mesenteric artery) and the marginal artery of Drummond (an anastomosis between terminal branches of the superior and the inferior mesenteric arteries).The rectosigmoid junction is supplied by an anastomosis between the last sigmoid branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and the terminal branches of the superior rectal artery (also from the inferior mesenteric artery).

answers.content: Hepatic flexure, transverse colon, and splenic flexure
answers.explanation_why: The hepatic flexure, transverse colon, and splenic flexure are predominantly supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) via the middle colic artery and the left colic branch of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). The SMA arises anteriorly at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the level of the renal arteries. Although this patient is likely to have an occlusion of the IMA, the SMA would not be affected because his aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal. Therefore, this combination of bowel regions is less likely to be affected in this patient's case.

The cecum, ileum, and distal jejunum are supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which arises anteriorly from the aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the level of origin of the renal arteries. As this patient's aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal, this combination of bowel regions would not be affected.

answers.content: Cecum, ascending colon, and hepatic flexure
answers.explanation_why: The cecum, ascending colon, and hepatic flexure are supplied by the right colic branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). The SMA arises anteriorly from the aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the origin of the renal arteries. As this patient's aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal, this combination of bowel regions would not be affected.

answers.content: Ascending colon, cecum, and distal ileum
answers.explanation_why: The ascending colon, cecum, and distal ileum are supplied by the ileocolic and right colic branches of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which arises anteriorly from the aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the level of origin of the renal arteries. As this patient's aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal, this combination of bowel regions would not be affected.

question_text: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Initial examination shows a distended abdomen and a flat perineal region without an opening. A dark green discharge is coming out of the vulva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Initial examination shows a distended abdomen and a flat perineal region without an opening. A dark green discharge is coming out of the vulva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This newborn's findings indicate a diagnosis that is commonly part of a constellation of congenital birth defects known as the VACTERL association.
learning_objective: Recognize imperforate anus in a newborn.

answers.explanation_why: Meconium ileus classically presents as abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium within the first 24–48 hours after birth and is commonly observed in patients with cystic fibrosis. However, the absence of an anal opening is inconsistent with meconium ileus. Also, an association of fistula formation with meconium ileus has not been described.

Hirschsprung disease is due to an aganglionic segment leading to uncoordinated peristalsis and spastic contraction of the rectum. It causes functional intestinal obstruction, which results in abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium as seen in this patient. However, examination of affected individuals shows merely an extremely tight sphincter, not the total absence of an anal opening. Also, rectovaginal fistula formation is not a feature of Hirschsprung disease.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

answers.explanation_why: Imperforate anus generally manifests with a poorly developed midline groove between the buttocks and absence of an anal opening. It is commonly associated with fistula formation, which may lead to meconium excretion through a rectovaginal fistula, all of which is observed in this patient. This patient should be closely examined for other possible features of VACTERL association.

images.title: Imperforate anus
images.description: X-ray abdomen (invertogram view) of a newbornA coin has been placed over the anus and the patient has been turned upside down. Multiple dilated gas-filled loops of bowel (examples indicated by green line) are seen proximal to a point of abrupt termination of the distal colon. Beyond this (double arrow), no gas continues to the anus.The appearance is consistent with imperforate anus (anal atresia). The distance between the gas column and the coin can be measured to determine the length of the atretic segment. Imperforate anus can be associated with other congenital abnormalities, among them esophageal atresia, VACTERL association, caudal regression syndrome, trisomy 21, and Currarino triad.

answers.explanation_why: Colonic atresia is a rare congenital malformation that results in colonic obstruction with ensuing abdominal distention. Some patients may also present with delayed passage of meconium after birth as seen in this patient. However, affected individuals have a normal anal opening without fistula formation.

Meconium plug syndrome is a temporary form of intestinal obstruction that manifests with delayed passage of meconium (> 24–48 hours) in combination with abdominal distention. The absence of an anal opening and fistula formation is incompatible with meconium plug syndrome.

question_text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the emergency room because of 4 episodes of bilious vomiting and inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. An upper GI contrast series shows the duodenojejunal junction to the right of the vertebral midline; an air-filled cecum is noted in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the emergency room because of 4 episodes of bilious vomiting and inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. An upper GI contrast series shows the duodenojejunal junction to the right of the vertebral midline; an air-filled cecum is noted in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: The duodenojejunal junction normally lies to the left of the midline, adjacent to the vertebral bodies.
learning_objective: Recognize incomplete intestinal rotation.

answers.explanation_why: Defective neural crest migration to the distal colon results in Hirschsprung disease. The aganglionic segment of the colon fails to relax, which causes functional intestinal obstruction. Although Hirschsprung disease would manifest with bilious vomiting, it also causes significant abdominal distension. Moreover, it typically manifests right after birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours or later in childhood with constipation and abdominal distention.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease in a 5-day-old male newborn
images.description: Distended, bulging abdomen that is tender on palpation. Diagnosis performed by rectal suction biopsy: Hirschsprung's disease

answers.explanation_why: Failure of duodenal recanalization results in duodenal atresia, which would manifest with complete intestinal obstruction at birth. Hallmark imaging findings are the double bubble sign as well as a completely gasless distal small bowel, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, duodenal atresia is associated with maternal polyhydramnios.

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.explanation_why: With complete nonrotation of the intestine, the cecum usually remains in the left lower quadrant. However, this patient's GI series shows a cecum located in the right upper quadrant. Patients with nonrotation may be asymptomatic or present with varying degrees of small bowel obstruction. Radiologically, the small bowel is seen to occupy the right side of the abdomen, with the colon predominantly on the left.

Incomplete intestinal rotation, indicated by a malpositioned duodenojejunal junction (usually located to the left of the midline) and cecum (normally located in the right lower quadrant), can manifest as duodenal obstruction, causing bilious vomiting without abdominal distension. Obstruction is due to extrinsic duodenal compression by peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) that cross over the duodenum to fix the abnormal cecum to the liver or peritoneum.

images.title: Types of volvulus
images.description: The types of volvulus are classified by anatomical location as illustrated here.- Midgut volvulus: A malrotated midgut causing mechanical bowel obstruction, mostly in neonates and infants. Fibrous peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) attaching the cecum to the retroperitoneum are a common pathological finding in midgut volvulus.- Cecal volvulus: The cecum rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.- Sigmoid volvulus: The sigmoid colon rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

answers.content: Arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud
answers.explanation_why: An arrested ventral pancreatic bud rotation causes annular pancreas, which can result in extrinsic compression of the duodenum, usually proximal to the major duodenal papilla. Unlike this patient, neonates with annular pancreas typically present with nonbilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Findings on an upper GI series include eccentric or concentric narrowing of the second portion of the duodenum, double bubble sign, and symmetrical dilatation of the proximal duodenum. Moreover, annular pancreas is associated with maternal polyhydramnios.

images.title: Duodenal stenosis from annular pancreas
images.description: Upper GI series (single contrast; lateral view)Narrowing of the second (descending) portion of the duodenum (white arrow) remained fixed during fluoroscopy. A CT scan (not shown) revealed an annular pancreas as the cause.DB: duodenal bulb; S: stomach

answers.content: Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter
answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter lead to pyloric stenosis, which can cause gastric outlet obstruction. Unlike this patient, infants with pyloric stenosis typically present at 2–6 weeks of age with nonbilious vomiting. Other symptoms include early satiety, progressive gastric dilation, weight loss, a succussion splash, and/or hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

images.title: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
images.description: In newborns with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, an enlarged, thickened, olive-shaped, nontender pylorus may be palpable in the epigastrium. The primary symptom of the condition is projectile, nonbilious vomiting immediately after feeding.

answers.content: Resorption of a small bowel segment
answers.explanation_why: Jejunal atresia and ileal atresia occur as a result of resorption of a small bowel segment thought to be caused by an in-utero vascular disruption that leads to ischemic necrosis of the fetal intestine. The necrotic tissue is resorbed, leaving blind proximal and distal ends, often with a gap in the mesentery. Although neonates may present with bilious vomiting as in this case, jejunal/ileal atresia would also cause a distension of the upper abdomen, delayed meconium passage, and a triple bubble sign on x-ray. Moreover, jejunal/ileal atresia has been associated with maternal polyhydramnios.

images.title: Triple bubble sign in jejunal atresia
images.description: X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomitingDilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level

question_text: Six days after falling in the shower, a 75-year-old man with COPD is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased fremitus over the left lung base. There are faint expiratory wheezes throughout the lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: Six days after falling in the shower, a 75-year-old man with COPD is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased fremitus over the left lung base. There are faint expiratory wheezes throughout the lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
hint: The chest x-ray shows a left-sided opacity, blunting of the costophrenic angles, and mild tracheal deviation to the right.
learning_objective: Recognize hemothorax as a cause of pleural effusion.

answers.content: Air between the pleura and chest wall
answers.explanation_why: Trapped air between the pleura and chest wall is the underlying pathophysiology of pneumothorax. Given this patient's history of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath, pneumothorax should be considered as a possible diagnosis. A tension pneumothorax can cause tracheal deviation away from the affected side, due to increased intrathoracic pressure. However, x-ray findings in pneumothorax would include absent lung markings and areas of increased radiolucency rather than the large opacity and air-fluid level seen here.

Bacteria in the pulmonary parenchyma (e.g., due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) would be consistent with bacterial pneumonia. Expected chest x-ray findings in bacterial pneumonia would also include a lobar opacity, but tracheal deviation and an air-fluid level, as seen here, would be unusual. Furthermore, this patient does not have fever or symptoms of pneumonia, making this unlikely.

Symptoms of pulmonary edema may include dyspnea and low oxygen saturation due to impaired oxygenation. While both are seen in this patient, pulmonary edema alone would not cause such a pronounced air-fluid level on x-ray. Instead, it would appear as bilateral, patchy, confluent opacification, as the fluid is trapped inside the alveoli.

Neoplastic cells in the bronchi would be consistent with lung cancer, which this patient has risk factors for (smoking, age). An obstructive lung cancer could also cause tracheal deviation but would cause tracheal deviation towards the affected side, due to lung collapse, unlike what is seen here. This patient's large left-sided pleural effusion in the setting of recent fall make a different diagnosis more likely.

This patient's history of recent fall and x-ray findings of a large left pleural effusion with tracheal deviation are consistent with hemothorax. Trauma to the chest can cause the ribs to pierce the pleura and damage intrathoracic vessels, which can lead to accumulation of blood in the pleural space. There is tracheal deviation to the opposite side due to the increasing volume in the pleural space. A hemothorax cannot be diagnosed with x-ray alone (diagnosis usually requires CT imaging or thoracentesis) but given the patient's recent trauma, this is the most likely etiology.

images.title: Hemothorax following rib fracture
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopneaThe margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib

question_text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for grossly bloody diarrhea for 2 days. The girl has had a few episodes of blood-tinged stools over the past 3 weeks. She has not had pain, nausea, or vomiting. She is at the 55th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a small amount of dark red blood in the diaper. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 68 μm^3, and platelet count is 300,000/mm^3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for grossly bloody diarrhea for 2 days. The girl has had a few episodes of blood-tinged stools over the past 3 weeks. She has not had pain, nausea, or vomiting. She is at the 55th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a small amount of dark red blood in the diaper. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 68 μm3, and platelet count is 300,000/mm3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This young girl presents with painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding and resultant microcytic anemia (likely due to iron deficiency from chronic blood loss), which is the characteristic presentation of Meckel diverticulum.
learning_objective: Recognize Meckel diverticulum, and recall its diagnostic finding on imaging.

answers.content: Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Plain abdominal x-ray showing double bubble sign is suggestive of duodenal atresia. This girl does not present with bilious vomiting or abdominal distention, which would be expected in this condition. Additionally, she is 15 months old and therefore past the window in which duodenal atresia would manifest (24–48 hours after birth).

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.explanation_why: Cobblestone mucosa (due to linear ulcerations of the mucosa) is a classical colonoscopic finding of Crohn disease (CD). Although intestinal blood loss in CD can cause iron deficiency anemia and a low MCV, as seen in this patient, this condition is associated with further symptoms such as nonbloody chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and growth faltering. Moreover, since the peak incidence of CD is 15–35 years, it is unlikely in this 15-month old patient.

answers.content: Neutrophil infiltrated crypts on colonic biopsy
answers.explanation_why: A colonic biopsy showing neutrophil infiltrated crypts can be seen in ulcerative colitis (UC). This disease can manifest with lower gastrointestinal bleeding and subsequent microcytic anemia, as seen in this patient. However, UC is also associated with abdominal pain, tenesmus, growth faltering, and extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum). Furthermore, the peak incidence of UC is 15–35 years; and therefore, it is unlikely in this 15-month-old patient.

answers.content: Absent ganglionic cells on rectal suction biopsy
answers.explanation_why: Rectal suction biopsy showing absent ganglionic cells is diagnostic of Hirschsprung's disease. This disease can manifest in neonates with bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and delayed meconium passage, or at a later stage of childhood with chronic or recurrent constipation. However, it is not associated with the painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding seen in this girl.

In young children, abdominal ultrasound showing a target sign is suggestive of intussusception. While intussusception can cause lower gastrointestinal bleeding, it usually presents with acute cyclical colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal tenderness. This patient has a benign abdominal exam and no concomitant symptoms, making intussusception unlikely.
answers.explanation_but: Meckel diverticulum can act as a pathological lead point and therefore predisposes to intussusception.

images.title: Target sign in intussusception
images.description: Ultrasound abdomen (bowel; transverse plane)Concentric alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings are visible. The hyperechoic rings (green overlay) are formed by mucosa and the hypoechoic rings (red overlay) by submucosa. Together the alternating layers produce a target-like appearance (target sign; bull's eye sign).

answers.content: Ectopic gastric mucosa on Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan
answers.explanation_why:
Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan showing ectopic gastric mucosa in the small bowel is diagnostic of Meckel diverticulum in children. Meckel diverticulum is a true diverticulum that may contain ectopic gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue. Acid-secretion by gastric mucosa within the diverticulum results in ileal ulceration and subsequent bleeding. Consequently, chronic blood loss can lead to iron deficiency anemia, and thus a low MCV, as seen in this patient.

The sensitivity of technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is lower in adults because the adult population tends to have a higher percentage of Meckel diverticulum that lacks ectopic gastric mucosa. False positives may be seen in intussusception and inflammatory bowel disease.

images.title: Meckel diverticulum
images.description: The Meckel diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct. The omphalomesenteric duct connects the yolk sac to the alimentary tract in the embryo (left image). The duct is normally obliterated by the 6^th week of intrauterine life. However, incomplete obliteration leads to the development of a diverticulum located approx. 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve (right image). The Meckel diverticulum is often connected to the navel via a fibrous cord, which is the obliterated part of the omphalomesenteric duct (middle image).

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left wrist pain and swelling that started immediately after a fall. She was walking her dog when the dog abruptly pulled away, causing her to fall forward onto both hands. Physical examination shows left wrist pain with pinching and grasping, moderate swelling, and mild tenderness. Her left thumb is placed in a thumb immobilization splint. An x-ray of the wrist 2 days later is shown. The most likely cause of these findings is a fracture of which of the following bones?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left wrist pain and swelling that started immediately after a fall. She was walking her dog when the dog abruptly pulled away, causing her to fall forward onto both hands. Physical examination shows left wrist pain with pinching and grasping, moderate swelling, and mild tenderness. Her left thumb is placed in a thumb immobilization splint. An x-ray of the wrist 2 days later is shown. The most likely cause of these findings is a fracture of which of the following bones?
hint: This type of fracture is typically associated with tenderness to palpation of the anatomical snuffbox.
learning_objective: Recognize a scaphoid fracture.

answers.explanation_why: The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. Fracture results from an axial load injury onto a hyperextended and radially deviated wrist and manifests with mild wrist pain, swelling, and painful pinching and grasping, as seen in this patient. Although many scaphoid fractures can be treated conservatively with immobilization, proximal pole fractures carry a high risk of avascular necrosis and often require surgical fixation.

images.title: Anatomical snuff box
images.description: A triangular depression over the dorsal aspect of the base of the thumb that becomes prominent when the thumb is extended or abducted.Boundaries: tendon of the extensor pollicis longus (on the ulnar side) and the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus (radial side)The scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Tenderness on application of pressure to the anatomical snuffbox is a clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture.

answers.explanation_why: A fracture of the ulna is often caused by a direct blow to or a fall onto a pronated forearm. These fractures result in localized pain, swelling, and often gross deformation and/or loss of range of motion at the forearm or wrist. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling, the mechanism of injury makes an ulnar fracture less likely. Furthermore, the x-ray does not show an ulnar fracture.

images.title: Ulnar shaft fracture
images.description: X-ray forearm (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a childAn isolated fracture of the mid ulnar diaphysis is accompanied by displacement of the distal fragment (indicated by arrows). There is no disruption of the distal radioulnar joint.This type of fracture has been termed a “parry” or “nightstick fracture.” It occurs when the ulna is more exposed than the radius to injury. It may be the result of direct trauma (forearm raised in self-defense) or indirect trauma (fall).Arrowheads: bracelet; R: radius; U: ulnar

answers.explanation_why: A fracture of the distal radius (e.g., Colles fracture) can be caused by an axial load injury onto a hyperextended wrist, particularly in patients with osteoporosis or those who have sustained a high-energy trauma. Distal radius fractures manifest with wrist pain, swelling, and grasp deficits. However, this patient's young age and low-energy mechanism of injury make a Colles fracture less likely. Furthermore, the x-ray shows no fracture at the distal radius.

images.title: Colles fracture
images.description: X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view) after a fall onto an outstretched handA metaphyseal fracture of the distal radius (green line) shows dorsal angulation of the distal fragment and impaction. (The vertical white line represents the axis of the radius. The horizontal white line represents the right angle that the radial articular surface physiologically stands at. The dotted white line illustrates the dorsal angulation of the distal fragment.) This type of fracture has been termed a Colles fracture. The pronator quadratus fat pad is displaced and seen as a convex lucency (red curved line). A fracture of the ulnar styloid is also present (white arrow).

answers.explanation_why: Lunate fractures and perilunate dislocations are rare injuries resulting from high-energy trauma to a hyperextended and ulnar deviated wrist. Patients present with wrist pain, swelling, and occasionally median nerve injuries such as acute carpal tunnel syndrome. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling after an axial load injury, the low-energy mechanism of injury makes a lunate fracture or dislocation less likely. Moreover, the x-ray is inconsistent with a lunate fracture.

images.title: Bones of the hand and wrist

answers.explanation_why: A fracture of the hamate body is a rare carpal bone injury that is usually sustained from direct axial load onto a clenched wrist. It manifests with wrist swelling, ulnar wrist pain, and tenderness over the hamate. Although this patient has wrist pain and swelling after an axial load injury, the fact that her injury involved hyperextension makes a hamate fracture less likely. Moreover, the x-ray shows no fracture at the hamate.

images.title: Bones of the hand and wrist
Scaphoid fracture
images.description: X-ray of the left hand (PA view)A distinct radiolucent fracture line (green overlay) is visible across the mid-portion of the scaphoid (white dashed outline).

question_text: A 45-year-old man undergoes elective vasectomy for permanent contraception. The procedure is performed under local anesthesia. There are no intraoperative complications and he is discharged home with ibuprofen for postoperative pain. Which of the following conditions should the patient be counseled on the risk of developing over the next 3 months?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man undergoes elective vasectomy for permanent contraception. The procedure is performed under local anesthesia. There are no intraoperative complications and he is discharged home with ibuprofen for postoperative pain. Which of the following conditions should the patient be counseled on the risk of developing over the next 3 months?
hint: Vasectomies are surgical procedures that divide and occlude the vas deferens. The entire procedure takes approximately 15 minutes.
learning_objective: Choose the condition to counsel a patient on post-vasectomy to prevent complications.

answers.explanation_why:
Because there can still be motile, viable sperm in the vas deferens lumen distal to the site of occlusion, patients undergoing vasectomy are advised to use an alternative method of contraception during the first 3 months after the procedure to avoid an unplanned pregnancy. Three months post-vasectomy, a follow-up examination is conducted to test semen samples for azoospermia to determine the success of the procedure before ceasing to use alternative methods of contraception. Patients should also be counseled about the small risk of post-vasectomy pregnancy (approximately 1 in 2000 cases) due to recanalization.

Other complications of a vasectomy include surgical site infection, sperm granulomas, post-vasectomy pain syndrome, hematomas, and failure of the procedure (persistence of sperm in the ejaculate).

Seminomas are true germ cell tumors and the most common testicular tumor. They are associated with painless testicular enlargement, late metastasis, and an excellent prognosis. Risk factors include undescended testis, a previous tumor of the contralateral testis, and a family history of testicular cancer, but not vasectomy.

Risk factors for testicular torsion include inadequate fixation of the testicle's lower pole to the tunica vaginalis (congenital “bell clapper” deformity), enlargement of the testes (e.g., testicular tumor), and acute groin injury. A vasectomy involves very small incisions in the scrotal skin to localize the vas deferens; such incisions do not predispose patients to testicular torsion.

Inguinal hernias are abnormal protrusions of intra-abdominal contents either through the deep inguinal ring (indirect inguinal hernia) or through the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal (direct inguinal hernia). Risk factors include old age, chronic cough, chronic constipation, and abdominal surgery. A vasectomy involves very small incisions in the scrotal skin to localize the vas deferens; such incisions do not predispose patients to inguinal hernias.

Prostatitis is caused primarily by infections of urogenital origin. Catheter-associated urinary tract infections are a surgery-associated risk for prostatitis due to impeded urinary flow. However, vasectomies are performed under local anesthesia and do not require patient catheterization.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of left-sided body weakness and involuntary urinary leakage. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia treated with metformin and atorvastatin. He reports having experienced a similar episode two years ago. Neurologic examination shows left-sided hemiparesis and decreased sensation. The neurologic abnormalities are more prominent in the left lower than in the left upper extremity. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following labeled vessels in the MR angiography image of a normal brain is most likely occluded in this patient?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of left-sided body weakness and involuntary urinary leakage. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia treated with metformin and atorvastatin. He reports having experienced a similar episode two years ago. Neurologic examination shows left-sided hemiparesis and decreased sensation. The neurologic abnormalities are more prominent in the left lower than in the left upper extremity. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following labeled vessels in the MR angiography image of a normal brain is most likely occluded in this patient?
hint: Sudden onset of urinary incontinence in conjunction with sensory and motor loss predominantly affecting the left lower extremity should raise concern for cortical injury in the region of the anterior cerebral artery.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior cerebral artery stroke, and recall the anatomy of the circle of Willis.

answers.explanation_why: The right anterior cerebral artery (structure A) supplies the right anteromedial cortex including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes. ACA occlusion causes loss of contralateral motor and sensory function, particularly of the lower extremities. The ACA also supplies the medial frontal micturition center, the part of the brain responsible for bladder control.

The left anterior cerebral artery (structure B) supplies the left anteromedial cortex including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes. Occlusion would cause the symptoms of motor and sensory loss of the lower extremity seen in this patient, albeit on the right (i.e., contralateral) rather than the left side.

The right middle cerebral artery (structure C) supplies the right lateral cortex including the temporal lobe and the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobe. Although occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery can manifest with left-sided sensorimotor deficits, the face and upper extremities are typically affected rather than the lower extremities. Moreover, it also causes gaze deviation and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), which are absent in this patient.

The left middle cerebral artery (structure D) supplies the left lateral cortex including the temporal lobe and the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobe. Although occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery can manifest with sensorimotor deficits, symptoms would be expected on the right (i.e., contralateral) rather than the left side. Moreover, unlike this patient, the face and upper extremities are typically affected rather than the lower extremities. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of MCA occlusion such as gaze deviation and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: The right posterior cerebral artery (structure E) supplies most parts of the right occipital cortex, the posteromedial aspects of the temporal lobe, and the thalamus. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) typically manifests with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Occlusion of the right PCA may also cause visual recognition deficits (prosopagnosia). Although this patient has left-sided sensory deficits, PCA occlusion would not explain his hemiparesis or incontinence. He also lacks the visual deficits and vertigo typically seen in PCA strokes.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: The left posterior cerebral artery (structure F) supplies most parts of the left occipital cortex, the posteromedial aspects of the temporal lobe, and the thalamus. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) typically manifests with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Occlusion of the PCA can also cause language deficits (alexia, anomic aphasia). Although this patient does have sensory deficits, a PCA occlusion would not explain his hemiparesis and incontinence. His symptoms are also left-sided, as opposed to the right-sided deficits expected in an occlusion of the left PCA.

The basilar artery (structure G) is formed by the confluence of the two vertebral arteries at the central groove of the pons and supplies the lower half of the cerebellum, the lower midbrain, the lower pons, the medulla, and the corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. Basilar artery occlusion can present with vertigo, tinnitus, visual deficits, gait ataxia, and ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits with paresthesias and hemiplegia. Rarely, it can cause locked-in syndrome. Although this patient presents with sensorimotor deficits, there is no evidence of cranial nerve or cerebellar involvement. Moreover, basilar artery occlusion would not explain the urinary incontinence seen in this patient.

images.title: Circle of Willis
images.description:
Cranial MRI angiography (maximum intensity projection; dorsal view)This image shows the circle of Willis and its branches.A: right ACA
B: left ACA
C: right MCA
D: left MCA
E: right PCA
F: left PCA
G: basilar arteryNo significant pathologies are visible.

question_text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. He was not wearing a helmet. Physical examination shows left periorbital ecchymosis. A CT scan of the head shows a fracture of the greater wing of the left sphenoid bone with compression of the left superior orbital fissure. Physical examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. He was not wearing a helmet. Physical examination shows left periorbital ecchymosis. A CT scan of the head shows a fracture of the greater wing of the left sphenoid bone with compression of the left superior orbital fissure. Physical examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The superior orbital fissure contains CN III, CN IV, CN V_1, and CN VI.
learning_objective: Recognize a superior orbital fissure syndrome, and recall the associated cranial nerve deficits.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased sense of smell would be an indication that there is an injury to the olfactory nerve (cranial nerve I). This nerve passes through the cribriform plate so it is vulnerable with fractures of this bone. Pathologies of the superior orbital fissure would not be expected to affect this nerve.

The sensory innervation of the left cheek is carried out by the maxillary nerve (cranial nerve V2), which exits the cranium via the foramen rotundum. Injury to this nerve would not be expected with a sphenoid bone fracture with compression of the left superior orbital fissure, but rather as a result of an inferior orbital rim or maxillary fracture.

A fixed, miotic pupil would not be an expected finding in this patient. Fractures impinging on the superior orbital fissure can lead to fixed, dilated pupils as a result of damage to the parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). Miosis is seen in other nervous system conditions such as Horner syndrome and lateral pontine strokes.

Lateral gaze is achieved via contraction of the lateral rectus muscle. This muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), which passes through the superior orbital fissure. Fractures that impinge on this bony cleft, as in this patient, are likely to interfere with the function of the nerves that pass through. Thus, the expected finding would be abducens nerve palsy and loss of lateral gaze on the left.

The corneal reflex requires uninterrupted signal transmission via the ophthalmic nerve (CN V_1). Since this structure passes through the superior orbital fissure, it is likely to be disrupted in this patient with a compressive fracture through the superior orbital fissure. Without the afferent limb of the reflex pathway (cranial nerve V1), there is no motor response (cranial nerve VII).

images.title: Apertures of the bony orbit
images.description: Frontal view of the left orbit showing the nerves and vessels that enter the orbital cavity.The common tendinous ring is the origin of all the rectus muscles and of the superior oblique muscle; it encloses all the structures that enter through the optic canal and four of the cranial nerve branches passing through the superior orbital fissure (nasociliary nerve, abducens nerve, and the superior and inferior branch of the oculomotor nerve).

answers.content: Complete loss of vision of the left eye
answers.explanation_why: Complete loss of vision in the left eye would be a result of injury to the optic nerve (cranial nerve II). This nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure, but rather it enters the orbit via the optic canal.

question_text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of numbness in his left lower extremity. One month ago, he sustained a fracture of the neck of the left fibula during soccer practice that was treated with immobilization in a plaster cast. Physical examination of the left lower extremity is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of numbness in his left lower extremity. One month ago, he sustained a fracture of the neck of the left fibula during soccer practice that was treated with immobilization in a plaster cast. Physical examination of the left lower extremity is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The common peroneal nerve runs in close proximity to the lateral aspect of the fibular head, which makes it susceptible to damage or compression due to fracture of the fibular neck, tight casts, crossing of the legs, or protracted squatting.
learning_objective: Recognize common peroneal nerve injury, and recall its effect on foot dorsiflexion.

answers.explanation_why:
Dorsiflexion of the foot is accomplished through contraction of muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg, including the tibialis anterior (main dorsiflexor), extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and peroneus tertius. These muscles are innervated by the deep peroneal nerve, which branches from the common peroneal nerve. Injury to the common peroneal nerve, either from the initial fibula fracture or, more likely, compression from the plaster cast, explains this patient's numbness and would result in impaired dorsiflexion and eversion on motor examination. Patients with injury to the common peroneal nerve typically present with steppage gait.

The common peroneal nerve gives rise to the superficial peroneal nerve, which innervates the dorsum of the foot, and the deep peroneal nerve, which innervates the web space between the first two toes.

answers.content: Loss of sensation over the medial calf
answers.explanation_why: Loss of sensation over the medial calf occurs in cases of injury to the saphenous nerve. These injuries typically arise following saphenous vein harvest for cardiac surgery or trauma to the posterior leg, not from fibular fracture.

Standing on one's tiptoes requires contraction of the muscles in the superficial posterior compartment of the leg, gastrocnemius, and soleus. Direct injury to these muscles or damage to the tibial nerve, which innervates these muscles, would make it impossible to stand on one's tiptoes, but this patient's history of isolated fracture of the fibular neck does not suggest these pathologies.

The ankle reflex is diminished in patients with spinal cord, spinal root, and peripheral nerve conditions. Specifically, processes affecting the sacral spinal cord, S_1/S_2 roots, or tibial nerve would be expected to manifest with reduced ankle reflexes. This patient does not have a history to suggest injury or damage to any of these structures.

answers.content: Loss of sensation on the sole of the foot
answers.explanation_why: The sole of the foot is innervated by the tibial nerve. Tibial nerve injury is typically a result of deep lacerations to the posterior leg or severely posteriorly displaced tibia fracture. Fibular fractures do not commonly affect this nerve.

An inability to invert the foot would be the result of an injury affecting the tibialis posterior muscle, which is innervated by the tibial nerve. This patient has no history to suggest injury to this nerve (e.g., deep laceration to the posterior leg).

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and weakness in her right forearm and hand for several months. Two years ago, she sustained a fracture of her ulnar shaft with dislocation of the radial head that was treated surgically. Physical examination shows mild tenderness a few centimeters distal to the lateral epicondyle. She has marked weakness when attempting to extend her right middle finger. There is radial deviation on extension of the wrist. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and weakness in her right forearm and hand for several months. Two years ago, she sustained a fracture of her ulnar shaft with dislocation of the radial head that was treated surgically. Physical examination shows mild tenderness a few centimeters distal to the lateral epicondyle. She has marked weakness when attempting to extend her right middle finger. There is radial deviation on extension of the wrist. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?
hint: This patient's weakness in her wrist extensor muscles with intact cutaneous sensation suggests a pure motor neuropathy that is sometimes associated with dislocation of the radial head.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior interosseous nerve neuropathy.

answers.explanation_why: Injuries to the ulnar nerve can manifest in a number of ways depending on the location of the lesion. The vast majority of injuries, however, include sensory defects in the small and ring fingers, as well as weakness in the intrinsic hand muscles, neither of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with ulnar nerve dysfunction are unable to cross their fingers and may have an ulnar claw sign on examination.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.explanation_why: The anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) is a motor branch of the median nerve. Damage to it would not result in changes in cutaneous sensation, which is consistent with this patient's symptoms. However, weakness with finger extension would not be expected in an injury to this nerve, either. The classic physical examination finding in patients with AIN injuries is an inability to make the “A-OK” sign with the thumb and index finger, although injury to this branch alone is rare.

The superficial radial nerve is a distal branch of the radial nerve. It is a purely sensory nerve and provides cutaneous innervation to the radial half of the dorsal hand, the thumb, the index finger, and the radial half of the dorsal long finger (except for the tips of the fingers, which are innervated by the median nerve). However, this patient has no cutaneous sensory symptoms. Furthermore, injury to this nerve would not account for her motor changes.

The posterior interosseous nerve is a motor nerve that branches off from the radial nerve in close proximity to the radial head, which makes it susceptible to injury due to radial head dislocation or subluxation. Occasionally, posterior interosseous neuropathy can develop years after a fracture of the forearm or elbow. Compression of this nerve frequently impairs extension of the fingers (more than the wrist) because function of the extensor carpi radialis longus, which is innervated directly by the radial nerve, is preserved. The unopposed action of this muscle further explains the radial deviation seen on examination. Finally, this patient's normal sensory examination is one of the hallmarks of posterior interosseous neuropathy because this nerve does not provide cutaneous innervation.

The posterior interosseous nerve can also be compressed within the radial tunnel (radial tunnel syndrome).
The musculocutaneous nerve is responsible for elbow flexion, forearm supination, and sensation over the lateral, volar forearm. None of these functions are affected in this patient.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, ventral view)

question_text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 months after undergoing a total hip replacement surgery. She reports that she has persistent difficulty in walking since the surgery despite regular physiotherapy. Examination of her gait shows sagging of the left pelvis when her right leg is weight-bearing. Which of the following nerves is most likely to have been injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 months after undergoing a total hip replacement surgery. She reports that she has persistent difficulty in walking since the surgery despite regular physiotherapy. Examination of her gait shows sagging of the left pelvis when her right leg is weight-bearing. Which of the following nerves is most likely to have been injured in this patient?
hint: Examination in this patient shows a positive Trendelenburg sign, which is caused by weakness of the hip abductors (i.e., the gluteus medius and minimus).
learning_objective: Recognize injury to the right superior gluteal nerve.

answers.explanation_why: The left superior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus medius and minimus, which are responsible for abducting the left hip. Neurological weakness of these muscles would lead to a positive Trendelenburg sign or downward tilting of the pelvis toward the right side when the patient stands on her left leg.

The right femoral nerve innervates the right quadriceps, sartorius, pectineus, and iliopsoas, which control knee extension and thigh flexion. Femoral nerve injury would cause knee buckling (from quadriceps weakness), difficulty lifting up the thigh (problem climbing stairs), and dragging of the leg (from iliopsoas weakness); it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Sensory loss would also be seen over the medial and anterior thigh as well the medial calf, which is not present in this patient.

The right inferior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus maximus muscle. As this muscle is the primary right thigh extensor, inferior gluteal nerve damage would lead to impairment of this function. Although rare, injuries to this nerve may occur due to misdirected intramuscular injections and operations (e.g., posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

The left inferior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus maximus muscle. As this muscle is the primary left thigh extensor, inferior gluteal nerve damage would lead to impairment of this function. This nerve is rarely injured, but possible reasons are misdirected intramuscular injections and operations (e.g. posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

The left femoral nerve innervates the left quadriceps, sartorius, pectineus, and iliopsoas, which control knee extension and thigh flexion. Femoral nerve injury would cause knee buckling (from quadriceps weakness), difficulty lifting up the thigh (problem climbing stairs), and dragging of the leg (from iliopsoas weakness), it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Sensory loss would also be seen over the medial and anterior thigh as well the medial calf, which is not present in this patient.

The right obturator nerve innervates the right obturator externus, pectineus, gracilis, and adductors magnus, longus and brevis. Damage to the obturator nerve results in weakness of adduction, external rotation of the thigh, and a tendency for the thigh to abnormally abduct while walking; it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Damage to this nerve would also cause sensory loss in the mid and lower thirds of the right medial thigh, which is not present in this patient.

The right superior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus medius and minimus, which are responsible for abducting the right hip. Damage of the right superior gluteal nerve results in lowering of the left hip while standing on the right foot (positive Trendelenburg sign). This patient's symptoms suggest that she suffered damage to the right superior gluteal nerve during total hip replacement surgery.

images.title: Trendelenburg and Duchenne signs
images.description:
The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops toward the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

answers.explanation_why: The left obturator nerve innervates the left obturator externus, pectineus, gracilis, and adductors magnus, longus, and brevis. Damage to the obturator nerve results in weakness of adduction, external rotation of the thigh, and a tendency for the thigh to abnormally abduct while walking; it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Damage to this nerve would also cause sensory loss in the mid and lower thirds of the left medial thigh, which is not present in this patient.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent tingling of his hand. He is an avid cyclist and has recently started training for a cycle marathon. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength in the right hand and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. On asking the patient to grasp a piece of paper between his right thumb and right index finger in the first web space, there is hyperflexion of the right thumb interphalangeal joint. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent tingling of his hand. He is an avid cyclist and has recently started training for a cycle marathon. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength in the right hand and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. On asking the patient to grasp a piece of paper between his right thumb and right index finger in the first web space, there is hyperflexion of the right thumb interphalangeal joint. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
hint: A positive Froment sign (hyperflexion of the thumb due to paralysis of the adductor pollicis and unopposed action of flexor pollicis longus) and wasting of the hypothenar eminence are suggestive of ulnar nerve entrapment.
learning_objective: Recognize ulnar nerve entrapment at Guyon canal, and recall its associated hand muscle dysfunctions.

answers.content: Loss of sensation over dorsal aspect of 1^st web space
answers.explanation_why: Sensation in the dorsal web space between the thumb and index finger is often examined to assess intact radial nerve sensation. It would not be affected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.content: Inability to flex the index finger at the interphalangeal joints
answers.explanation_why: Flexion of the index finger at either the proximal or distal interphalangeal joints requires the action of the flexor digitorum superficialis (proximal joint) or flexor digitorum profundus (proximal and distal joints). The flexor digitorum superficialis and the lateral aspect of the flexor digitorium profundus (which flexes the index and middle finger) are innervated by the median nerve and would be unaffected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

answers.content: Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the medial half of the hand
answers.explanation_why: The dorsum of the medial half of the hand (ring and small fingers) is innervated by the dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve, which arises in the forearm proximal to the passage of the ulnar nerve through Guyon canal. As this patient exhibits nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal, the sensory innervation to the medial half of the dorsum of the hand will remain intact.

answers.content: Inability to extend the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint
answers.explanation_why: Extension of the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint is mediated by the action of the extensor digitorum muscle, which is innervated by the radial nerve. The function of this muscle would not be affected by ulnar nerve compression.

answers.content: Inability to extend the little finger at the proximal interphalangeal joints
answers.explanation_why:
This patient's physical examination is suggestive of long-term ulnar nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal (Guyon canal syndrome), which is common in avid cyclists due to long-term pressure of the wrist against bike handlebars. This compression disrupts innervation to the ulnar innervated intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbricals, which are responsible for little finger extension at the proximal interphalangeal joint. Additional physical exam findings typically seen in this syndrome include numbness of the palmar surface of the small and ring fingers.

While splinting, cortisone injections, and NSAIDs may improve this patient's complaints, surgical release of the volar carpal ligament is required in refractory cases.

images.title: Ulnar nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4^th and 5^th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1^st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3^rd and 4^th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingersProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

question_text: A 69-year-old right-handed man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, he has had some difficulty speaking for 3 months. During a conversation, he often has difficulty repeating what his interlocutor has said. He has hypertension and takes hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient speaks fluently in full sentences and demonstrates normal comprehension. When asked to say the word “kindergarten,” he replies with, “Sintelmarvin… no, that's wrong…kinterflargin, no that isn't it either...kantolargen...no? How about, kindergarten?” The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is occlusion of a branch of which of the following arteries?
content_preview: A 69-year-old right-handed man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, he has had some difficulty speaking for 3 months. During a conversation, he often has difficulty repeating what his interlocutor has said. He has hypertension and takes hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient speaks fluently in full sentences and demonstrates normal comprehension. When asked to say the word “kindergarten,” he replies with, “Sintelmarvin… no, that's wrong…kinterflargin, no that isn't it either...kantolargen...no? How about, kindergarten?” The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is occlusion of a branch of which of the following arteries?
hint: The patient's impaired repetition with paraphasia, together with preserved comprehension, is called conduction aphasia. Lesions in the supramarginal gyrus can cause this syndrome, which often presents without other neurologic symptoms.
learning_objective: Recognize conduction aphasia, and recall its associated cerebral artery.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the right posterior cerebral artery would cause left-sided weakness and left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing; it would not cause conductive aphasia.
In a right-handed person, the supramarginal gyrus is supplied by a branch of the left middle cerebral. A lesion to this area can disrupt the arcuate fasciculus and result in conductive aphasia.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: In a right-handed person, occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery would cause left-sided weakness and hemineglect; it would not cause conductive aphasia. In some left-handed individuals, the language center is located in the right hemisphere. In these patients, a lesion to the right middle cerebral artery could cause conductive aphasia.
Ischemia to the right posterior limb of the internal capsule due to occlusion of right penetrating arteries would cause left-sided weakness; it would not cause conductive aphasia.

Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Conduction aphasia is not seen in lateral medullary syndrome.
Occlusion of the right vertebral artery can cause dizziness along with other neurologic signs such as diplopia, hemiparesis, or numbness. It would not manifest with conductive aphasia.

Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Conduction aphasia is not seen in lateral medullary syndrome.
Occlusion of the left posterior cerebral artery would cause right-sided hemiparesis and a right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing; it would not cause conductive aphasia.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left vertebral artery can cause dizziness along with other neurologic signs such as diplopia, hemiparesis, or numbness. It would not manifest with conductive aphasia.
Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule would result in right-sided weakness; it would not cause conductive aphasia.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressively worsening lower back pain and weakness in the lower extremities. The pain is worse with movement and improves with lying down on a flat surface. She was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis 6 months ago and is currently taking isoniazid and rifampin. Physical examination shows sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the lower-thigh, patella, and medial aspect of the right lower leg. Strength is 2/5 with knee extension and the patellar reflex is absent. An x-ray of the spine shows a paravertebral opacity with anterior wedging of the vertebral body. Which of the following nerve roots is most likely to be affected in this patient?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressively worsening lower back pain and weakness in the lower extremities. The pain is worse with movement and improves with lying down on a flat surface. She was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis 6 months ago and is currently taking isoniazid and rifampin. Physical examination shows sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the lower-thigh, patella, and medial aspect of the right lower leg. Strength is 2/5 with knee extension and the patellar reflex is absent. An x-ray of the spine shows a paravertebral opacity with anterior wedging of the vertebral body. Which of the following nerve roots is most likely to be affected in this patient?
hint: A history of radiculopathy symptoms in a patient with primary tuberculosis and x-ray findings of anterior wedging of the vertebral bodies and paravertebral opacity is suggestive of spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease).
learning_objective: Recognize L4 radiculopathy in spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease).

answers.explanation_why: L5 radiculopathy typically manifests with diminished sensation extending diagonally from the dorsolateral thigh over the lateral knee and the anterior leg to the dorsomedial side of the foot, including the medial toes. This pattern is inconsistent with this patient's sensory deficits. In addition, an impinged L5 nerve root would not affect knee extension or the patellar reflex but would instead lead to impaired dorsiflexion of the foot due to impaired innervation of the tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis longus muscles.

S2 radiculopathy is relatively rare compared to other radiculopathies and may manifest with diminished sensation affecting the posterior aspect of the thigh, partly extending down to the posterior leg and the perineum. Moreover, affected individuals often have urinary or fecal incontinence and sexual dysfunction.

S1 radiculopathy typically manifests with sensory deficits involving the posterolateral aspect of the thigh, anterolateral as well as the posterolateral lower leg, and the lateral foot, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. Moreover, an impinged S1 nerve root would not affect the patellar reflex but would instead lead to diminished ankle jerk reflex in combination with difficulty walking on toes due to impaired innervation of the gastrocnemius, peroneus longus, and peroneus brevis muscles.

L3 radiculopathy typically manifests with impaired sensation extending from the mid-anterolateral thigh to the medial thigh just above the patella, unlike the deficits seen in this patient. While affected individuals may present with a reduced adductor reflex and/or a mildly reduced patellar reflex along with mild impairment of knee extension, impaired hip flexion and adduction is more characteristic of L3 radiculopathy.

L4 radiculopathy characteristically manifests with sensory loss or paresthesia extending from the distal anterolateral thigh over the patella to the medial lower leg, as seen in this patient. Diminished knee extension would also be expected since innervation of the quadriceps is impaired. This patient's reduced patellar reflex further supports the diagnosis of impingement of the L4 nerve root as the underlying cause.

images.title: Dermatome map
images.description: Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a tingling sensation in his right forearm. He reports that his symptoms started after he lifted heavy weights at the gym. Physical examination shows loss of sensation on the lateral side of the right forearm. Sensation over the thumb is intact. Range of motion of the neck is normal. His symptoms do not worsen with axial compression or distraction of the neck. Further examination of this patient is most likely to show weakness of which of the following actions?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a tingling sensation in his right forearm. He reports that his symptoms started after he lifted heavy weights at the gym. Physical examination shows loss of sensation on the lateral side of the right forearm. Sensation over the thumb is intact. Range of motion of the neck is normal. His symptoms do not worsen with axial compression or distraction of the neck. Further examination of this patient is most likely to show weakness of which of the following actions?
hint: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, which innervates the lateral surface of the forearm, is a branch of the musculocutaneous nerve.
learning_objective: Recognize musculocutaneous nerve injury, and recall the actions it controls.

answers.explanation_why: Shoulder abduction is predominantly controlled by the deltoid muscle, which is innervated by the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve also controls sensation over the distal half of the deltoid region. Given this patient's sensory changes over the lateral forearm, it is unlikely that he has an axillary nerve injury.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.explanation_why:
Elbow flexion is controlled by the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles, which are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve injury can result from lifting heavy weights as seen in this case. This injury also impairs forearm supination and the biceps tendon reflex. The normal range of motion in the neck and negative Spurling sign indicate that this patient has a peripheral nerve lesion.

Some symptoms of musculocutaneous nerve injury may be masked by the fact that the supinator muscle (innervated by the radial nerve) can at least partially compensate for the supination deficit; in addition, the brachioradialis muscle (also innervated by the radial nerve) is an elbow flexor.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.explanation_why: Forearm pronation is controlled by the pronator teres and pronator quadratus muscles, which are innervated by the median nerve. The median nerve also controls sensation on the lateral aspect of the palm, including the thumb. Given this patient's symptoms of primarily lateral forearm sensory loss without involvement of the thumb or hand, it is unlikely that he has a median nerve injury.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, ventral view)

answers.explanation_why: Index finger flexion is controlled by the median nerve. Median nerve injury leads to sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the palm, including the thumb. Though the median nerve controls many of the muscles of the forearm, it does not control sensation of the forearm. Given this patient's symptoms of primarily lateral forearm sensory loss without involvement of the thumb or hand, it is unlikely that he has a median nerve injury.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, ventral view)

answers.explanation_why: Wrist extension is controlled by the radial nerve, which also controls sensation over the posterior surface of the forearm extending to the dorsolateral hand. Since this patient's sensory loss is over the lateral portion of the forearm without any hand involvement, it is unlikely that he has a radial nerve injury.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.explanation_why: The pinch grip is controlled by the anterior interosseous nerve, a purely motor branch of the median nerve. Distal lesions can lead to loss of flexion in the distal joints of the thumb and index finger due to impaired innervation of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles. Because this patient has sensory loss over the lateral forearm without hand involvement, it is unlikely that he has a median nerve injury.

images.title: Pinch sign (anterior interosseous syndrome)
images.description: The anterior interosseous nerve is a pure motor branch of the median nerve. It supplies the flexor pollicis longus, the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (and the pronator quadratus).Pinch sign: an inability to flex the DIP of the index finger and IP joint of the thumb when asked to make an “OK” sign that is caused by a lesion or entrapment of the anterior interosseous nerve
