question_text: A 64-year-old man with osteoarthritis of the knee comes to the physician for evaluation of weakness in his foot. Physical examination shows a swelling in the popliteal fossa. There is marked weakness when attempting to invert his right foot. He is unable to curl his toes. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show decreased sensation over which of the following locations?
content_preview: A 64-year-old man with osteoarthritis of the knee comes to the physician for evaluation of weakness in his foot. Physical examination shows a swelling in the popliteal fossa. There is marked weakness when attempting to invert his right foot. He is unable to curl his toes. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show decreased sensation over which of the following locations?
hint: Swelling of the popliteal fossa can lead to compression of the inlying structures, including the tibial nerve. Compression of the tibial nerve can result in neurapraxia, causing marked motor weakness of foot inversion and toe plantarflexion, as well as sensory deficits in the tibial nerve distribution.
learning_objective: Recognize tibial nerve compression, and recall its sensory distribution.

answers.explanation_why: The second dorsal web space, the anterolateral inferior third of the leg, and most of the foot dorsum (except for the first web space) receive sensory innervation from the superficial peroneal nerve. The motor portion of this nerve supplies the lateral compartment of the leg, allowing for foot eversion. Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve occurs secondary to entrapment at the lateral ankle or via fibular fracture, not as a result of the popliteal swelling seen in this patient. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with a superficial peroneal nerve injury.

The sole of the foot, lateral foot, and posterolateral leg are innervated by sensory branches of the tibial nerve (nerve stem from L4–S3). The posterior compartment of the leg, responsible for foot inversion and plantarflexion of the toes and ankle, is innervated by motor branches of the tibial nerve. This patient's neurapraxia of the tibial nerve secondary to popliteal swelling would diminish the sensory and motor functions of these regions.

images.title: Innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (leg, dorsal view)

answers.explanation_why: The sensory branch of the deep peroneal nerve provides sensation to the first web space, while the motor portion supplies the anterior compartment of the leg, which is responsible for foot and toe dorsiflexion. Injury is usually the result of anterior compartment compression or ski boot syndrome, not the popliteal swelling seen in this patient. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with deep peroneal nerve injury.

The medial plantar arch and the medial leg and foot are innervated by the saphenous nerve, which has a purely cutaneous sensory function. Therefore, this patient's motor deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with saphenous nerve injury. The saphenous nerve would also not be injured by popliteal swelling.

The lateral border of the foot is innervated by the sural nerve, which provides a purely cutaneous sensory function to the inferior portion of the posterolateral leg. Injury to the sural nerve is often secondary to calcaneal fracture or trauma, not popliteal swelling as this patient has. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with sural nerve injury.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 1-hour history of severe groin pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has had a groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining for the past 3 months. Her pulse is 120/min. Examination shows pallor; there is swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation of the right groin that is centered below the inguinal ligament. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is entrapment of an organ between which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 1-hour history of severe groin pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has had a groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining for the past 3 months. Her pulse is 120/min. Examination shows pallor; there is swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation of the right groin that is centered below the inguinal ligament. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is entrapment of an organ between which of the following structures?
hint: A groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining is suggestive of a hernia. In a patient with a hernia, severe pain and features of bowel obstruction (e.g., nausea, vomiting) indicate strangulation. As the swelling is located below the midpoint of the inguinal canal, a femoral hernia is the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize a femoral hernia, and recall its anatomical boundaries.

answers.explanation_why: The linea alba is a longitudinal band in the anterior abdomen extending from the xiphoid process to the pubic symphysis. The conjoint tendon lies in the inferior quadrant of the abdomen, attached medially to the pubic tubercle. Ventral hernias (e.g., epigastric hernias) occur when intra-abdominal contents herniate through the linea alba. This patient, however, presents with pain and swelling below the inguinal ligament.

images.title: Rectus sheath and linea alba
images.description: Transverse section of the abdominal wall above (a) and below (b) the arcuate lineThe fibrous rectus sheath is formed of the aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles. It encloses the rectus abdominal muscle. The exact composition of the anterior and posterior part of the rectus sheath depends on the relation to the arcuate line (above or below, a or b). The aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles fuse in the middle of the abdominal wall to form a fibrous line termed linea alba.

answers.content: Inferior epigastric artery and rectus sheath
answers.explanation_why: The inferior epigastric artery and the lateral edge of the rectus sheath form the lateral and medial borders of the Hesselbach triangle. Contents of a direct inguinal hernia pass between these two structures. A direct inguinal hernia would appear as a mass above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass below the inguinal ligament seen here. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias are less prone to strangulation or incarceration when compared to other hernias because the neck of a direct hernia is wide.

images.title: Direct inguinal hernia
images.description: Illustration depicting the inguinal area, medial to the inferior epigastric blood vessels (sagittal plane; male patient)1: internal oblique; 2: transversus abdominis; 3: external oblique aponeurosis; 4: transversalis fascia; 5: parietal peritoneum; 6: intestine; 7: inguinal ligament; 8: lacunar ligament; 9: superior pubic ramus; 10: spermatic cord

answers.explanation_why: The inguinal canal is bounded superiorly by the conjoint tendon and inferiorly by the inguinal ligament. In the case of an indirect inguinal hernia, intra-abdominal contents pass through the deep inguinal ring and lie within the inguinal canal. However, an indirect inguinal hernia would appear as a mass above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass below the inguinal ligament seen here. Moreover, indirect inguinal hernias occur typically among men; they are uncommon among women.

The supravesical fossae lie between the median umbilical ligament and medial umbilical ligaments on either side. Rarely, bowel may herniate into the supravesical fossae (internal hernia), in which case, examination would show tenderness in the suprapubic region, usually without a palpable mass. This patient, however, presents with a tender mass below the inguinal ligament.

answers.content: Transversalis fascia and internal oblique aponeurosis
answers.explanation_why: The transversalis fascia and internal oblique aponeurosis contribute to the formation of the rectus sheath, the fascial covering of the spermatic cord, and the conjoint tendon, which forms the medial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. Weakness of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal results in a direct inguinal hernia, which would appear as a mass above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass below the inguinal ligament seen here. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias are less prone to strangulation or incarceration when compared to other hernias because the neck of a direct hernia is wide.

images.title: Rectus sheath and linea alba
images.description: Transverse section of the abdominal wall above (a) and below (b) the arcuate lineThe fibrous rectus sheath is formed of the aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles. It encloses the rectus abdominal muscle. The exact composition of the anterior and posterior part of the rectus sheath depends on the relation to the arcuate line (above or below, a or b). The aponeuroses of the lateral abdominal muscles fuse in the middle of the abdominal wall to form a fibrous line termed linea alba.

answers.explanation_why: In the case of a femoral hernia, intra-abdominal contents (e.g., bowel, mesentery) pass into the femoral canal, which is bounded medially by the lacunar ligament and laterally by the femoral vein. Femoral hernias are more common in women and are likely to strangulate because the femoral canal is narrow.

images.title: Femoral canal
images.description: Topographic anatomy of the femoral canal region and surrounding regions. The femoral ring (yellow outline) forms the base of the femoral canal and is bounded by the inguinal ligament (anteriorly), lacunar ligament (medially), pectineal ligament (posteriorly), and fibrous septum of the femoral vein (laterally). The canal is wider in women. The cribriform fascia is not depicted in order to better visualize the saphenous opening.

question_text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain and swelling in his right knee that began 3 days ago when he fell during football practice. He fell on his flexed right knee as he dove to complete a pass. He felt some mild knee pain but continued to practice. Over the next 2 days, the pain worsened and the knee began to swell. Today, the patient has an antalgic gait. Examination shows a swollen and tender right knee; flexion is limited by pain. The right knee is flexed and pressure is applied to proximal tibia; 8 mm of backward translation of the foreleg is observed. Which of the following is most likely injured?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain and swelling in his right knee that began 3 days ago when he fell during football practice. He fell on his flexed right knee as he dove to complete a pass. He felt some mild knee pain but continued to practice. Over the next 2 days, the pain worsened and the knee began to swell. Today, the patient has an antalgic gait. Examination shows a swollen and tender right knee; flexion is limited by pain. The right knee is flexed and pressure is applied to proximal tibia; 8 mm of backward translation of the foreleg is observed. Which of the following is most likely injured?
hint: Flexion of the quadriceps of the right thigh would translate the tibia forward; this is called a positive quadriceps active test and it is another sign of the patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior cruciate ligament injury.

answers.explanation_why: Medial meniscus injury is a common cause of knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.

Posterior cruciate ligament injury (PCL injury) can occur when the flexed knee is subjected to excessive posterior force, as in the case of this patient. He has a positive posterior drawer sign on the affected side, which is highly suggestive of PCL injury. PCL injury is confirmed by MRI and can be treated conservatively (in the case of isolated injury) or surgically (in the case of multi-ligament injury or chronic symptoms).

images.title: Posterior cruciate ligament tear
images.description: MRI knee (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) appears thickened and heterogeneous with an irregular and ill-defined contour (green overlay). It contains multiple areas of intermediate signal intensity, indicating tearing. A joint effusion is demonstrated by the hyperintense signal in the suprapatellar pouch (red overlay).A ligament tear does not always appear as a discrete defect and may be demonstrated by the features in this example. A normal PCL should appear as hypointense on all conventional MRI sequences and have smooth margins.

answers.explanation_why: Anterior cruciate ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. Instead, ACL injury would present with a positive anterior drawer sign and a positive Lachman sign.
answers.explanation_but: Patients with PCL injury can sometimes appear to have a positive anterior drawer sign if the examiner is not careful. If a patient has a posterior sag sign from their PCL injury, then the affected tibia is posteriorly displaced when the knee is flexed (as when performing an anterior drawer test). If the examiner is not aware of the posterior sag and performs an anterior drawer test, the affected knee will feel as though it has significantly more anterior movement compared to the unaffected knee (because the affected knee started from a posteriorly displaced position) and may be mistaken for a positive anterior drawer test. The result of this mistake is a misdiagnosis of ACL injury when, in fact, it is the PCL that is injured!

answers.explanation_why: Medial collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's posterior drawer sign. MCL injury frequently occurs after valgus stress and presents with medial joint line tenderness and valgus stress laxity.

Lateral collateral ligament injury causes knee pain but would not explain the patient's positive posterior drawer test. Isolated LCL injury is rare; it would present with lateral joint line tenderness with varus stress laxity.
Lateral meniscus injury causes knee pain but would not explain this patient's positive posterior drawer test. Instead, McMurray test would be positive.

question_text: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for left hip pain 30 minutes after she fell while walking around in her room. Examination shows left groin tenderness. The range of motion of the left hip is limited because of pain. An x-ray of the hip shows a linear fracture of the left femoral neck with slight posterior displacement of the femur. Which of the following arteries was most likely damaged in the patient's fall?
content_preview: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for left hip pain 30 minutes after she fell while walking around in her room. Examination shows left groin tenderness. The range of motion of the left hip is limited because of pain. An x-ray of the hip shows a linear fracture of the left femoral neck with slight posterior displacement of the femur. Which of the following arteries was most likely damaged in the patient's fall?
hint: The artery that courses posterior to the femoral neck is at greatest risk of injury in this case. Damage to this artery can cause avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
learning_objective: Recognize femoral neck fracture complications, and recall the associated vascular anatomy.

answers.explanation_why: The lateral circumflex femoral artery arises from the profunda femoris distal to the greater trochanter. This structure supplies blood to muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the thigh and is at risk in femoral shaft or intertrochanteric fractures. Although they are small, variable branches off of the lateral femoral circumflex can supply a minority of the femoral head's blood supply. However, this vessel is unlikely to have been damaged in this patient with posterior displacement because of its location anterior to the femoral head.

The deep femoral artery, also known as the profunda femoris, is one of two major divisions of the femoral artery (the other being the superficial femoral artery). It typically branches off the femoral artery near the greater trochanter, distal to the site of a femoral neck fracture. Rarely, open reduction and internal fixation of a femoral neck fracture may lead to injury of this vessel, but this patient's fracture in itself would be unlikely to pose a risk.

The medial circumflex femoral artery is a major branch of the profunda femoris. It courses medioposteriorly to the neck of the femur, where it supplies blood to the head and neck of the femur. A minority of femoral neck fractures will go on to develop osteonecrosis of the femoral head stemming from injuries to this artery and its small branches to the bone.

images.title: Arteries of the femoral head with watershed zone

answers.explanation_why: The deep circumflex iliac artery resides on the medial aspect of the iliac crest. Because of its intrapelvic course, it is not at risk in cases of femoral neck fractures.

The obturator artery supplies muscles in the medial compartment of the thigh, including gracilis, the leg adductors, and external obturator. Other smaller divisions provide blood to the inferior ramus of the ischium and the head of the femur (via the ligamentum teres femoris). This blood supply can be disrupted in the femoral head and acetabular fractures but would very likely be spared in a femoral neck fracture, as in this patient.

The superior gluteal artery exits the pelvis posteriorly and supplies all three gluteal muscles as well as the tensor fasciae latae. It also has branches that supply the ischium. This structure is not vulnerable to injury in femoral neck fractures such as this patient experienced.

question_text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being attacked with a knife. Physical examination shows a 4-cm laceration in the midline of the right forearm. An MRI of the right arm shows damage to a nerve that runs between the superficial and deep flexor digitorum muscles. Loss of sensation over which of the following areas is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being attacked with a knife. Physical examination shows a 4-cm laceration in the midline of the right forearm. An MRI of the right arm shows damage to a nerve that runs between the superficial and deep flexor digitorum muscles. Loss of sensation over which of the following areas is most likely in this patient?
hint: The median nerve, which originates from the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus, passes down the arm into the cubital fossa and runs in the midline of the ventral compartment of the forearm between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus.
learning_objective: Recognize injury to the median nerve, and recall its sensory distribution.

answers.explanation_why: The dorsal aspect of the forearm is innervated by a branch of the radial nerve called the posterior antebrachial cutaneous nerve, which lies in the extensor compartment of the forearm. A different nerve lies between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus.

answers.content: Palmar surface of the little finger
answers.explanation_why: The palmar surface of the little finger is innervated by palmar branches of the ulnar nerve, which enters the anterior compartment of the forearm between the two heads of flexor carpi ulnaris and lies between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus. However, the ulnar nerve is located medially; it is less likely to be affected by a laceration in the midline of the forearm.

The lateral aspect of the forearm is innervated by a branch of the musculocutaneous nerve called the lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve. Neither the musculocutaneous nerve nor the lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve lies between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus.

The median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel into the hand. Within the hand, the median nerve motor branch innervates the thenar muscles and the lateral two lumbricals. The median nerve also provides sensory innervation to the thenar eminence as well as the dorsal and palmar aspect of the lateral 3½ fingers including the fingertips. Note that the lateral border of the thenar eminence is innervated by the radial nerve.

images.title: Proximal and distal median nerve lesions
images.description: AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

answers.explanation_why: The medial aspect of the forearm is innervated by the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve. A different nerve lies between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus.

The dorsum of the thumb is innervated by the superficial branch of the radial nerve, which travels through the forearm under the brachioradialis. A different nerve lies between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus.

question_text: A 3629-g (8-lb) newborn is examined shortly after spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother is concerned because she is not moving her left arm as much as her right arm. Physical examination shows her left arm to be adducted and internally rotated, with the forearm extended and pronated, and the wrist flexed. The Moro reflex is present on the right side but absent on the left side. Which of the following brachial plexus structures is most likely injured in this infant?
content_preview: A 3629-g (8-lb) newborn is examined shortly after spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother is concerned because she is not moving her left arm as much as her right arm. Physical examination shows her left arm to be adducted and internally rotated, with the forearm extended and pronated, and the wrist flexed. The Moro reflex is present on the right side but absent on the left side. Which of the following brachial plexus structures is most likely injured in this infant?
hint: This infant's left arm is in a “waiter's tip” position, which suggests impaired shoulder abduction and lateral rotation, as well as impaired elbow flexion and forearm supination. This injury is common in neonates who require lateral neck traction during vaginal delivery and is associated with shoulder dystocia.
learning_objective: Recognize Erb palsy presentation, and recall the affected brachial plexus structure.

answers.explanation_why: Erb palsy is due to injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which contributes to the motor and sensory function of the suprascapular nerve, musculocutaneous nerve, and axillary nerve. Erb palsy most commonly occurs secondary to shoulder dystocia or other birth trauma but can arise in adults as a result of neck and/or upper arm trauma.

images.title: Brachial plexus injuries: Erb palsy and Klumpke palsy

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the long thoracic nerve, which receives nerve fibers from the C5–C7 nerve roots, classically manifests with impaired abduction of the arm above 90° and winging of the scapula (due to innervation of the serratus anterior muscle). An isolated long thoracic nerve injury due to birth trauma would be very unusual. This patient's examination findings are consistent with injury to a different structure.

Injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus results in Klumpke palsy. Klumpke palsy commonly occurs secondary to birth trauma. It typically manifests as paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles and forearm flexors, resulting in the characteristic “claw hand” and absent grasp reflex. Horner syndrome may also be present. This patient's “waiter's tip” position is not consistent with a lower trunk injury.
Injury to the axillary nerve would result in the inability to externally rotate and abduct the arm above 15°. An isolated axillary nerve injury would not explain this patient's other findings.

images.title: Clinical features of axillary nerve injury

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the posterior cord classically results in wrist drop (loss of radial nerve innervation of forearm extensors) and inability to externally rotate or abduct the arm (loss of axillary nerve innervation of deltoid muscle). Isolated damage to the posterior cord during birth is extremely rare and would not be consistent with the examination findings in this patient.

images.title: Radial nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP jointsSensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2^nd and 3^rd fingers. The 1^st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumbProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her period for 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. A home pregnancy test was negative. She also reports recurrent headaches and has noticed that when she goes to the movies she cannot see the outer edges of the screen without turning her head to each side. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by abnormal growth of which of the following?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her period for 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. A home pregnancy test was negative. She also reports recurrent headaches and has noticed that when she goes to the movies she cannot see the outer edges of the screen without turning her head to each side. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by abnormal growth of which of the following?
hint: A cranial contrast MRI would reveal an intrasellar mass.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation of a pituitary adenoma, and recall its associated cellular origin.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of astrocytes is the underlying pathology of astrocytomas. While low-grade astrocytomas commonly manifest during childhood with a benign course, high-grade astrocytomas (e.g., glioblastoma multiforme) occurs in older individuals and manifests in rapidly progressive symptoms that depend upon the location of the lesion but may include headaches. This patient's prolonged course of symptoms and secondary amenorrhea is not suggestive of glioblastoma multiforme.

Abnormal growth of the adenohypophysis is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms, which are consistent with a pituitary adenoma. Adenomas of the pituitary gland are most commonly due to aberrant proliferation of lactotroph cells in the adenohypophysis. The resulting hyperprolactinemia eventually causes suppression of gonadotropins and subsequent secondary amenorrhea. Bitemporal hemianopsia (due to compression of the optic chiasm) and headaches may develop as the adenoma grows.

Her symptoms could also be explained by a large nonsecreting pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm (bitemporal hemianopsia) and the pituitary stalk or the gonadotropic cells (secondary amenorrhea), but the absence of other symptoms of hypopituitarism makes prolactinoma more likely.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of arachnoid cap cells is the underlying pathology of meningiomas. Even though this patient's recurrent headaches could be attributed to a meningioma, this tumor would not explain this patient's secondary amenorrhea or her visual disturbances.

Abnormal growth of ependymal cells is the underlying pathology of ependymomas, most of which arise close to the fourth ventricle. Ependymomas commonly cause obstructive hydrocephalus, which may manifest as recurrent headaches. However, ependymomas typically develop during childhood and are not associated with menstrual irregularities or visual disturbances.

Abnormal growth of Schwann cells leads to the development of a schwannoma, which typically arises near the cerebellopontine angle. Large tumors may lead to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, e.g., recurrent headache. However, in the case of a schwannoma, other features would likely be present, including tinnitus, vertigo, and hearing loss. Moreover, menstrual irregularities or bitemporal hemianopia would not be expected in the case of a Schwannoma.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of the pineal gland leads to the development of a pinealoma, which generally manifests during childhood. Symptoms of pinealomas include visual disturbances and dizziness or recurrent headaches (due to hydrocephalus). However, pinealomas are associated with vertical gaze palsy rather than the bitemporal hemianopsia observed in this patient. Moreover, menstrual disturbances would not be expected, as pinealomas are hormonally inactive.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe right shoulder pain and inability to move the shoulder after a fall while climbing outdoors. Examination shows the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. There is loss of the normal rounded appearance of the shoulder. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. Sensation to pinprick over which of the following skin areas is most likely to be reduced?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe right shoulder pain and inability to move the shoulder after a fall while climbing outdoors. Examination shows the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. There is loss of the normal rounded appearance of the shoulder. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. Sensation to pinprick over which of the following skin areas is most likely to be reduced?
hint: A combination of external rotation and abduction of the arm, flattening of the shoulder contour, and palpation of the humeral head below the coracoid process is indicative of anterior shoulder dislocation. The axillary nerve is stretched over the displaced head of the humerus (neurapraxia), making it especially prone to injury.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior shoulder dislocation, and recall the dermatome of the axillary nerve.

answers.explanation_why: The nerve most commonly damaged as a result of anterior shoulder dislocation is the axillary nerve, which has a dermatome over the lateral shoulder. This injury thus often causes loss of sensation in this area.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, ventral view)

answers.explanation_why: Musculocutaneous nerve injury would affect sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. These injuries are uncommon and would not be affected by an anterior shoulder dislocation.

answers.content: Dorsal aspect of forearm and hand
answers.explanation_why: The dorsal aspect of the forearm and hand are innervated by the radial nerve. While radial nerve injuries may occur in anterior shoulder dislocations, they are less common than axillary nerve injuries. Radial nerve palsy is usually due to its compression in the axilla or upper arm ('Saturday night palsy') and fractures of the humeral midshaft.

The thenar eminence and radial-sided fingers are innervated by the median nerve. Median nerve injuries can arise as a result of supracondylar humeral fractures, carpal tunnel syndrome, or lacerations at the wrist. The median nerve is unaffected by anterior shoulder dislocations.

The hypothenar eminence and ulnar-sided fingers are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Injuries to this nerve can be seen with fractures of the medial condyle of the humerus or the hamate. The ulnar nerve is unaffected by anterior shoulder dislocations.

The skin above the clavicle is innervated by the supraclavicular nerve, along with the skin of the posterior shoulder and the anterolateral chest wall. The supraclavicular nerve runs superior to the humeral head and is unaffected by an anterior dislocation.

answers.content: Medial aspect of the upper arm
answers.explanation_why: The medial aspect of the upper arm is supplied by the medial brachial cutaneous nerve, a direct branch of the brachial plexus. Injuries are rare but can occur as a result of surgical error or with trauma to the brachial plexus itself.

question_text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being hit by a car while crossing the street. He had a left-sided tonic-clonic seizure and one episode of vomiting while being transported to the hospital. On arrival, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis of all extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of a hemorrhage in which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being hit by a car while crossing the street. He had a left-sided tonic-clonic seizure and one episode of vomiting while being transported to the hospital. On arrival, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis of all extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of a hemorrhage in which of the following structures?
hint: This type of intracranial hemorrhage can also occur in the absence of trauma in individuals with ruptured saccular aneurysms.
learning_objective: Recognize subarachnoid hemorrhage, and recall its location within the meningeal layers.

answers.explanation_why: Intraventricular hemorrhage typically occurs secondary to intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage but can arise from rare vascular malformations. As with other intracranial bleeds, the characteristic presentation involves sudden onset of headache, vomiting, and altered level of consciousness. However, imaging of the head would show accumulation of blood within the ventricular system, which is not seen on this patient's head CT.

images.title: Basal ganglia and intraventricular hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A large hematoma (red overlay) accompanied by edema (green overlay) and mild mass effect involves the right basal ganglia and cerebral parenchyma. A small left basal ganglia hemorrhage (blue overlay) is also present. Hemorrhage has extended into the ventricular system (yellow overlay). Portions of a right ventricular stent (white arrows) are visible.

answers.content: Between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater
answers.explanation_why: Shearing of bridging veins causes subdural hemorrhage, which is characterized by bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater. Patients may present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma, as is the case here. However, head CT would show a high-density crescent-shaped collection (in acute cases) or a hypodense crescent-shaped collection (in chronic and subacute cases) across the hemispheric convexity, which crosses the suture lines.

images.title: Subdural hematoma and cerebral edema
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of traumaA large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

answers.content: Between the skull and the dura mater
answers.explanation_why: Bleeding between the dura mater and the skull is known as epidural hemorrhage and is often due to traumatic injury to the middle meningeal artery. Epidural hemorrhage should be suspected in any patient with head trauma that causes loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval, and subsequent worsening with signs of increased ICP. CT scan of the head would show a characteristic lentiform (lens-shaped) hemorrhagic collection that does not cross suture lines. While this patient does have signs of increased ICP following a trauma, his CT findings suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

answers.explanation_why: Bleeding directly into the cerebral parenchyma, known as intracerebral hemorrhage, is typically caused by a spontaneous rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls (e.g., chronic hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy). Patients often present with headache and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis. However, head trauma rarely leads to intracerebral hemorrhage, and signs of increased ICP are uncommon. Moreover, this patient's head CT is not consistent with intracerebral hemorrhage.

images.title: Intracerebral hematoma
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).ROH: right occipital horn

answers.content: Between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater
answers.explanation_why: Traumatic brain injury can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is characterized by bleeding between the arachnoid mater and pia mater. Patients classically present with a sudden, severely painful headache, vomiting, loss of consciousness, and, in cases of severe hemorrhage, seizures. Head CT shows hyperdense signals in the area of the hemorrhage, which are seen in the basal cistern in this patient.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: A nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage in the basal cisterns
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Hyperdensity (green overlay) in the basal cisterns indicates the presence of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being hit in the head with a baseball bat. Physical examination shows swelling and bruising around the left temple and eye. A CT scan of the head shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone and blood in the sphenoid sinus. Neurological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being hit in the head with a baseball bat. Physical examination shows swelling and bruising around the left temple and eye. A CT scan of the head shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone and blood in the sphenoid sinus. Neurological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Blood in the sphenoid sinus and a transverse fracture on imaging are indicative of an anterior fracture of the middle cranial fossa. Anterior middle cranial fossa fractures may involve the orbital apex, superior orbital fissure, and clinoid processes.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior middle cranial fossa fracture, and recall the associated cranial nerve injuries.

answers.explanation_why: Left homonymous hemianopia would be seen with damage to the visual pathways at the level of the right occipital lobe (e.g., due to right posterior cerebral artery stroke). This young patient does not have any known risk factors for CVA and given the mechanism of injury and imaging findings, a different finding is more likely.
answers.explanation_but: Severe head trauma can result in a skull base fracture extending through the floor of the sella turcica and sphenoid sinus to injure the crossing fibers at the optic chiasm, which would cause a bitemporal hemianopia.

answers.content: Inward deviation of the left eye
answers.explanation_why: Inward deviation of the eye (esotropia) can result from fractures of the sphenoid bone that extend anteriorly through the superior orbital fissure to damage the abducens nerve (CN VI). Other nerves that can be injured in skull base fractures involving the superior orbital fissure are the oculomotor nerve (ptosis with a fixed and dilated pupil), trochlear nerve (ocular extorsion and vertical diplopia), and ophthalmic nerve (absent corneal reflex). CN VI palsy is the most common cranial nerve palsy because of the long and tortuous route that CN VI takes intracranially, along which the nerve is vulnerable to injury by trauma (as in this patient), neoplasms (e.g., sphenoid ridge meningiomas), increased ICP (e.g., pseudotumor cerebri, SAH), neurovascular pathologies (e.g., cavernous sinus thrombosis, carotid-cavernous fistulas), and infection (e.g., syphilis).

images.title: Canals and foramina of base of skull
images.description: Superior view of internal surface

answers.explanation_why: Left facial paralysis would indicate facial nerve palsy. The facial nerve (CN VII) is commonly injured in fractures of the petrous part of the temporal bone (e.g., transverse temporal bone fractures) that extend from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen. Although this patient has bruising around his left temple, his CT scan shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone, for which left facial paralysis is not typical.

images.title: Examination findings in facial nerve palsy
images.description: Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

answers.content: Decreased hearing in the left ear
answers.explanation_why: Decreased hearing in the left ear would suggest vestibulocochlear nerve injury, which can result from skull base fractures extending from the petrous pyramid of the temporal bone into the internal acoustic meatus. Other typical findings associated with this type of injury include signs of fluid accumulation in the middle ear, CSF otorrhea, hemotympanum, and mastoid ecchymosis. Vertigo and horizontal nystagmus may be present as well. This patient's CT scan shows a fracture through the sphenoid bone rather than the temporal bone, making this finding unlikely.

answers.content: Deviation of uvula to the right
answers.explanation_why: Deviation of the uvula to the right would be consistent with a left vagus nerve palsy. CN X can be injured in posterior cranial fossa fractures that extend into the jugular foramen., which is located between the temporal bone and occipital bone. However, this patient's CT scan shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Her pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 141/98 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. A CT angiogram of the abdomen confirms an acute occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery. Which of the following structures of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be affected in this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Her pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 141/98 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. A CT angiogram of the abdomen confirms an acute occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery. Which of the following structures of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be affected in this patient?
hint: Given this patient's acute presentation, history of atrial fibrillation, and severe abdominal pain, she most likely has colonic ischemia due to an embolism. Ischemia is most likely to occur in the watershed areas of the colon.
learning_objective: Recognize that the rectosigmoid colon is affected by inferior mesenteric artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: The rectosigmoid colon is supplied by the sigmoid artery and the superior rectal artery, which are branches of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). The effects of reduction or cessation of blood flow to the colon are particularly prominent at the watershed areas of the colon (i.e., rectosigmoid colon and splenic flexure), where collateral blood flow is limited. During acute ischemic events, the lack of collateral blood supply renders these regions particularly prone to ischemia.

images.title: Watershed areas in colon ischemia
images.description: The watershed areas of the colon are the splenic flexure (Griffiths point) and the rectosigmoid junction (Sudeck point).The splenic flexure is supplied by the ascending branch of the left colic artery (from the inferior mesenteric artery) and the marginal artery of Drummond (an anastomosis between terminal branches of the superior and the inferior mesenteric arteries).The rectosigmoid junction is supplied by an anastomosis between the last sigmoid branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and the terminal branches of the superior rectal artery (also from the inferior mesenteric artery).

answers.explanation_why: The terminal ileum is predominantly supplied by the ileocolic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) and would, therefore, not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

The hepatic flexure, which is located between the ascending and the transverse colon, is supplied by branches of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). It would therefore not be affected by an occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).

The lower rectum (below the pectinate line) has an extensive blood supply by the middle rectal artery (arises from the internal iliac artery) and inferior rectal artery (arises from the internal pudendal artery). The lower rectum would not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

The ascending colon is predominantly supplied by the right colic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) and would, therefore, not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

The transverse colon is predominantly supplied by the middle colic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) and would, therefore, not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

question_text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four days ago, he injured his right knee while playing soccer. Increased laxity of the right knee joint is noted when the knee is flexed to 30° and an abducting force is applied to the lower leg. The examination finding in this patient is most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four days ago, he injured his right knee while playing soccer. Increased laxity of the right knee joint is noted when the knee is flexed to 30° and an abducting force is applied to the lower leg. The examination finding in this patient is most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
hint: The patient's injury is likely to be one of the injuries that comprise the unhappy triad.
learning_objective: Recall the structures tested by the valgus stress test of the knee.

answers.explanation_why: A posterior cruciate ligament tear would cause increased joint laxity when the knee is flexed and a posterior translating force is applied to the lower leg (posterior drawer sign), unlike the findings in this patient.
A tear in the medial meniscus would cause knee pain when the knee is flexed and the lower leg is externally rotated, unlike the findings in this patient.
answers.explanation_but: The medial meniscus is often injured along with the structure that is injured in this patient.

answers.explanation_why: A tear in the lateral collateral ligament would cause increased joint laxity when the knee is flexed and an adducting force is applied to the lower leg (varus stress test), unlike the findings in this patient.
A tear in the lateral meniscus would cause knee pain when the knee is flexed and the lower leg is internally rotated, unlike the findings in this patient.

Injury to the medial collateral ligament would cause increased laxity of the knee joint when the knee is flexed and an abducting force is applied to the lower leg (valgus stress test). Medial collateral ligament injury is often associated with injury to the anterior cruciate ligament and medial meniscus (unhappy triad).

An anterior cruciate ligament tear would cause increased joint laxity when the knee is flexed and an anterior translating force is applied to the lower leg (anterior drawer sign and Lachman sign), unlike the findings in this patient.
answers.explanation_but: The anterior cruciate ligament is often injured along with the structure that is injured in this patient.

question_text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after falling while mountain biking and hitting his head. Initially, he refused treatment, but an hour ago he began to develop a severe headache, nausea, and left leg weakness. He has no visual changes and is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm bruise on the right side of his skull. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Muscle strength is 0/5 in his left knee and foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
content_preview: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after falling while mountain biking and hitting his head. Initially, he refused treatment, but an hour ago he began to develop a severe headache, nausea, and left leg weakness. He has no visual changes and is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm bruise on the right side of his skull. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Muscle strength is 0/5 in his left knee and foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
hint: Focal deficits involving the lower limbs indicate involvement of the superior segment of the motor cortex.
learning_objective: Recognize subfalcine herniation.

answers.explanation_why: Upward brainstem herniation is rare and usually results from a brainstem mass (e.g., tumor), rather than intracranial hemorrhage, which is suspected in this patient. Typical findings include miosis, decerebrate posturing, doll's eyes, and altered mental status. This patient has pupils that appear normal, normal mental status, and no abnormal posturing, making upward brainstem herniation unlikely.

Uncal herniation leads to compression of the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (causing a fixed and dilated pupil), the ipsilateral posterior cerebral artery (causing cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia), and the contralateral cerebral peduncle (causing ipsilateral paralysis). While this patient is at risk of uncal herniation and has hemiplegia, he has a normal pupillary exam and has no visual symptoms.

Tonsillar herniation can occur due to any mass effect in the superior part of the skull (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage) and presents with symptoms of cerebellar and medullary compression (e.g., altered mental status, cardiorespiratory depression). While this patient likely has intracranial hemorrhage, he has a normal mental and cardiorespiratory status. Moreover, his hemiplegia suggests an alternative diagnosis.

Subfalcine herniation is the most common cerebral herniation syndrome and is usually due to cingulate gyrus herniation under the falx cerebri, causing compression of the foramen of Monro (leading to hydrocephalus and consequent headache) and branches of the anterior cerebral artery (causing infarction in the ACA territory and consequent contralateral lower limb weakness). This patient's herniation is most likely due to traumatic intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., subdural hemorrhage), given his recent fall involving head trauma. Without emergent diagnosis and treatment, expanding intracranial hemorrhage can rapidly progress to brainstem herniation and death.

The next steps would be confirmation of the diagnosis with emergency noncontrast head CT and neurosurgical consultation for likely craniectomy.

images.title: Brain herniation
images.description: Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

answers.explanation_why: Central transtentorial herniation is caused by global cerebral edema and causes herniation of the diencephalon and midbrain. Typical findings include altered mental status, pupillary abnormalities, and extensor posturing. This patient presents with normal mental status and has a normal ocular exam, making central transtentorial herniation unlikely. Moreover, his unilateral motor symptoms suggest an alternative diagnosis.

Extracranial herniation occurs when brain tissue passes through a defect in the skull (e.g., fracture), with neurologic deficits due to compression of the tissue as it passes through the defect. While this patient has a focal neurologic deficit, there is no evidence of skull fracture (e.g., focal tenderness or skull depression) or brain tissue herniating through the skull (e.g., bulge near area of fracture).

question_text: A 66-year-old man undergoes a coronary artery bypass grafting. Upon regaining consciousness, he reports that he cannot see from either eye and cannot move his arms. Physical examination shows bilaterally equal, reactive pupils. A fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain shows wedge-shaped cortical infarcts in both occipital lobes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man undergoes a coronary artery bypass grafting. Upon regaining consciousness, he reports that he cannot see from either eye and cannot move his arms. Physical examination shows bilaterally equal, reactive pupils. A fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain shows wedge-shaped cortical infarcts in both occipital lobes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: This patient's MRI of the brain shows symmetrical infarcts in the watershed regions of the brain. The infarcts occurred occipitally at the border of the posterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery, causing bilateral visual loss.
learning_objective: Recognize systemic hypotension as a cause of watershed infarcts.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is a common cause of spontaneous intracranial hemorrhage in elderly patients. Affected patients may present with recurrent transient ischemic attack-like symptoms and rapidly progressive dementia. However, amyloid angiopathy is not a common cause of watershed infarcts.

A ruptured saccular aneurysm causes subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can manifest with thunderclap headaches, nonreactive pupils, unconsciousness, rapidly worsening nausea, vomiting, and cardiovascular deterioration. A ruptured aneurysm is not, however, a common cause of watershed infarcts.

Lipohyalinosis of the cerebral vessel walls can lead to lacunar strokes within the basal ganglia. The most important predisposing factor for lipohyalinosis is chronic hypertension. A common risk factor for chronic hypertension is atherosclerosis, which this patient who received a bypass graft likely has. However, lipohyalinosis is not a common cause of watershed infarcts.

Cardiac embolism can cause ischemic stroke that affects watershed areas. Although these emboli often lodge in the small leptomeningeal arteries over the watershed areas, it is highly unlikely that multiple microemboli concurrently block the same vessels bilaterally. Therefore, watershed infarcts caused by cardiac embolisms and their consequent associated symptoms are overwhelmingly unilateral.

Atherothrombosis that affects an entire area supplied by a cerebral blood vessel can manifest with unilateral stroke-like symptoms (e.g., vision loss, weakness, numbness, slurred speech). In the rare cases that atheromatous microemboli cause a watershed infarct, the infarct is typically unilateral, not bilateral.

The most common cause of a watershed infarct is systemic hypotension, which results in decreased perfusion to the terminal areas of the vascular fields supplied by the cerebral arteries (watershed areas). Strokes with a watershed distribution are more prevalent in patients undergoing cardiac surgery as a result of global systemic hypoperfusion (especially while on cardiopulmonary bypass). These strokes are associated with poor short-term outcomes.

question_text: One day after undergoing surgery for a traumatic right pelvic fracture, a 73-year-old man has urinary incontinence and pain over his buttocks and scrotum. Physical examination shows right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absence of anal sphincter contraction when the skin around the anus is touched. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional neurological deficits?
content_preview: One day after undergoing surgery for a traumatic right pelvic fracture, a 73-year-old man has urinary incontinence and pain over his buttocks and scrotum. Physical examination shows right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absence of anal sphincter contraction when the skin around the anus is touched. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional neurological deficits?
hint: The history of a recent pelvic trauma, symptoms of perineal hypesthesia, and pain in the pelvis and genitals, as well as an absent sphincter reflex and urinary incontinence, indicate a pudendal nerve injury.
learning_objective: Recognize pudendal nerve injury, and recall its effects on reflexes.

answers.explanation_why: Paralysis of hip adductors is seen in damage to the obturator nerve, which could be caused by hip or pelvic trauma. However, symptoms would include a sensory deficit on the medial surface of the anterior thigh. Right-sided perineal hypesthesia, absent anal sphincter contraction, and urinary incontinence would not be expected.

The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the perineum, external genitalia, and external urethral and anal sphincter muscles. A reflex erection occurs on tactile stimulation of the genital area, which stimulates the afferent fibers of the pudendal nerve. This activates a reflex arc with the parasympathetic nervous system at the sacral roots originating at S2 to S4, forwarding the stimulus to the inferior hypogastric plexus. This, in turn, leads to relaxation of the cavernous smooth muscle, which causes vasodilation (mediated by nitric oxide) and erection. The pudendal nerve may be injured in pelvic fractures or pelvic surgeries.

Impaired hip flexion would be consistent with damage to the femoral nerve (paralysis of iliopsoas, pectineus, rectus femoris, and sartorius muscles). The femoral nerve can also be damaged by pelvic trauma. However, it would manifest with further motor deficits, including impaired knee extension and a decreased patellar tendon reflex (paralysis of quadriceps femoris muscle). Additionally, sensory deficits of the anteromedial thigh (anterior cutaneous branches), medial lower leg, and medial edge of the foot (saphenous nerve lesion) would be expected instead of perineal hypesthesia, an absent sphincter reflex, and urinary incontinence.

Psychogenic erection is caused by cortical stimulation with visual, aural, and sensory stimuli or fantasy, which activates the thoracolumbar erection center T11–L2 via fibers from the brain to the spine. These fibers can be damaged by spinal cord injury but are unlikely to be impaired by pelvic trauma or surgery. Furthermore, unilateral perineal hypesthesia, an absent sphincter reflex, and urinary incontinence would not be expected.

An absent cremasteric reflex can be seen in patients with damage to the ilioinguinal nerve (sensory innervation to the proximal medial aspect of the thigh) or the genitofemoral nerve (motor innervation to the cremaster muscle). However, damage to the ilioinguinal nerve results in sensory loss in the root of the penis and the anterior scrotum, and damage to the genitofemoral nerve results in decreased sensation to the anteromedial thigh, neither of which is seen here. In addition, right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absent anal sphincter contraction would not be expected.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a wellness visit. Physical examination shows an enlarged and nodular prostate. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of prostate-specific antigen. A prostate biopsy confirms the diagnosis of prostate cancer and a radical prostatectomy is planned. This patient should be counseled on the increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a wellness visit. Physical examination shows an enlarged and nodular prostate. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of prostate-specific antigen. A prostate biopsy confirms the diagnosis of prostate cancer and a radical prostatectomy is planned. This patient should be counseled on the increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
hint: Radical prostatectomy involves complete removal of the prostate, including the prostatic capsule, the seminal vesicles, and the vas deferens.
learning_objective: Recall the potential complications of radical prostatectomy.

answers.explanation_why: The cavernous nerve can be injured during radical prostatectomy. The resulting erectile dysfunction is one of the most feared complications of radical prostatectomy, but advances in urological surgery have enabled safer approaches that have significantly reduced the risk of permanent impotence.

The superior vesical artery courses along the upper part of the bladder. This course keeps it safely away from the surgical field typically involved in radical prostatectomy. In modern prostate surgery, the risk of vascular injury is roughly 0.2%, making this a rare complication.

The external anal sphincter is not at risk during radical prostatectomy. This structure can be compromised during traumatic vaginal births that lead to perineal lacerations. Radical prostatectomy can, however, pose a risk to the external urinary sphincter.
Injuries to the hypogastric nerve are very uncommon in radical prostatectomy. The course of this nerve is much too proximal to be compromised in the typical surgical approach to the prostate.

Injury to the ureter is very rare during radical prostatectomy. Published rates of ureter injury are about 0.1% in large studies. Rather, urethral strictures are more likely, resulting from scarring that can occur near the bladder trigone following radical prostatectomy.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pelvic pain and nausea. She was diagnosed with a follicular cyst in the left ovary 3 months ago. The cyst was found incidentally during a fertility evaluation. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler flow shows an enlarged, edematous left ovary with no blood flow. Laparoscopic evaluation shows necrosis of the left ovary, and a left oophorectomy is performed. During the procedure, blunt dissection of the left infundibulopelvic ligament is performed. Which of the following structures is most at risk of injury during this step of the surgery?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pelvic pain and nausea. She was diagnosed with a follicular cyst in the left ovary 3 months ago. The cyst was found incidentally during a fertility evaluation. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler flow shows an enlarged, edematous left ovary with no blood flow. Laparoscopic evaluation shows necrosis of the left ovary, and a left oophorectomy is performed. During the procedure, blunt dissection of the left infundibulopelvic ligament is performed. Which of the following structures is most at risk of injury during this step of the surgery?
hint: This structure passes posterior to the infundibulopelvic ligament at the level of the pelvic brim.
learning_objective: Choose the structure most at risk of injury during blunt dissection of the infundibulopelvic ligament.

answers.explanation_why:
The ureters pass through the pelvic brim within the ureteric fold, which lies posterior and medial, and in close proximity, to the infundibulopelvic ligament. Any dissection of the infundibulopelvic ligament should be performed with great care because of the risk of iatrogenic ureteral injury. Patients with fibrosis or endometriosis are at especially high risk of iatrogenic ureter injury during this surgical step.

Because of their long retroperitoneal course, the ureters are at risk of injury during lower abdominal procedures, such as gonadal vessel ligation, uterine vessel ligation, pelvic dissection, and dissection at the ureterovesical junction.

images.title: Supporting ligaments of the uterus (dorsal view)
images.description:
The uterus is connected to the pelvic walls by ligaments and peritoneal folds. These structures provide support and allow for flexible movement of the uterus between the urinary bladder and the rectum, especially during pregnancy.- The round ligament extends from the lateral horn of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall and via the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
- The largest ligament is the broad ligament of the uterus, a peritoneal fold that connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. The broad ligament can be divided into the mesosalpinx, the mesovarium, and the mesometrium.
- The ovaries are suspended from the uterus by the ovarian ligament and from the lateral pelvic wall by the suspensory (infundibulopelvic) ligament of the ovary.
- The cardinal ligament encloses the uterine artery and vein and connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall.
- The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum.

answers.explanation_why: The bladder trigone is located at the base of the bladder, caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament. This portion of the bladder is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum and provides mechanical support to the uterus. This ligament is located caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament and is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

The kidneys are located retroperitoneally, approximately at the T12–L3 vertebral levels. They are not connected to, nor in the immediate vicinity of, the infundibulopelvic ligament and are, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

The cervical os acts as a passage between the uterus and the vagina. This structure has two major components: an internal cervical os (endocervix) and an external cervical os (ectocervix). The cervical os is located caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament and is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

The uterine artery (and vein) is contained within the cardinal ligament, which forms the inferior portion of the broad ligament. The uterine artery is located caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament and is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

images.title: Blood supply of the female reproductive organs (dorsal view)
images.description: The arterial supply of the female reproductive organs mainly comes from branches of the uterine artery. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery and crosses the ureter anteriorly in the broad ligament at the level of the cervix. The ovary and fallopian tubes are supplied by branches of the ovarian artery that arise from the abdominal aorta and anastomose with the ovarian branches of the uterine artery.Note that the vessels adjacent to the uterus are tortuous to accommodate the massive growth of the uterus during pregnancy.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed with a knife during an altercation. Physical examination shows a 4-cm stab wound on the right lateral border of the T1 spinous process. An MRI of the spinal cord shows damage to the area of the right lateral corticospinal tract at the level of T1. Further evaluation will most likely show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed with a knife during an altercation. Physical examination shows a 4-cm stab wound on the right lateral border of the T1 spinous process. An MRI of the spinal cord shows damage to the area of the right lateral corticospinal tract at the level of T1. Further evaluation will most likely show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's mechanism of injury and imaging findings are consistent with a partial Brown-Sequard syndrome. The lateral corticospinal tract originates at the precentral gyrus and decussates at the level of the medulla.
learning_objective: Recognize partial Brown-Sequard syndrome, and recall the expected motor function findings.

answers.content: Absence of right-sided motor function below T1
answers.explanation_why: A right lateral corticospinal tract injury (e.g., partial Brown-Sequard syndrome) would result in the absence of ipsilateral motor function below injury level. The lateral corticospinal tract decussates at the level of the medulla. An injury distal to the decussation (e.g., at the level of T1) would, therefore, affect ipsilateral motor function below the level of the injury. In a full Brown-Sequard syndrome (e.g., hemisection of the spinal cord), there would also be ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception below T1 (dorsal column), ipsilateral Babinski sign (lateral corticospinal tract), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning two levels below the lesion (lateral spinothalamic tract).

The Babinski sign usually takes 1–2 weeks to appear after an upper motor neuron lesion occurs. This finding would be unlikely immediately following an acute injury. Furthermore, a Babinski sign would be expected ipsilateral to the injury (in this case, on the right side), as the upper motor neuron for the lateral corticospinal tract has been disrupted here and decussation of this tract occurs at a higher level.

answers.content: Absence of left-sided proprioception below T1
answers.explanation_why: An absence of left-sided (contralateral to the injury) proprioception below T1 would be consistent with injury to the left dorsal column, which is unlikely given this patient's imaging findings of lateral corticospinal tract injury on the right side. Proprioception is transmitted via ascending sensory neurons in the dorsal column ipsilaterally, until decussation at the level of the medulla.
answers.explanation_but: An absence of ipsilateral proprioception below the lesion would be expected if the right dorsal column were involved in this patient's injury.

answers.content: Absence of right-sided temperature sensation below T1
answers.explanation_why: An absence of right-sided temperature sensation below T1 would be most consistent with a left lateral spinothalamic tract injury at the level of T1. Sensory fibers from the lateral spinothalamic tract transmit input about pain and temperature and ascend two segments before decussating in the spinal cord and ascending contralaterally until they reach the sensory cortex. However, this patient's MRI shows damage to the right lateral corticospinal tract at T1, making this finding unlikely.

answers.content: Absence of left-sided fine touch sensation below T1
answers.explanation_why: An absence of left-sided fine touch below T1 would be expected with an injury to the left dorsal column, which is unlikely given this patient's imaging findings of lateral corticospinal tract injury on the right side. Fine touch is transmitted via ascending sensory neurons in the dorsal column ipsilaterally, until decussation at the level of the medulla.

question_text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after spilling hot oil on himself in a kitchen accident. Examination shows multiple tense blisters over the abdomen, anterior chest, and entire right leg. Deroofing of the blisters reveals tender and mottled underlying skin that does not blanch with pressure. Examination of the left thigh shows tender and erythematous skin with quick capillary refill after blanching with pressure. Which of the following is the closest estimate of total body surface area affected by second-degree burns in this patient?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after spilling hot oil on himself in a kitchen accident. Examination shows multiple tense blisters over the abdomen, anterior chest, and entire right leg. Deroofing of the blisters reveals tender and mottled underlying skin that does not blanch with pressure. Examination of the left thigh shows tender and erythematous skin with quick capillary refill after blanching with pressure. Which of the following is the closest estimate of total body surface area affected by second-degree burns in this patient?
hint: This patient has first and second-degree burns. The total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns is estimated using the rule of nines.
learning_objective: Calculate the burn surface area using the rule of nines.

answers.explanation_why: Application of the rule of nines estimates 9% of TBSA if only one body segment is affected. Several segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.
Application of the rule of nines estimates 18% of TBSA if only two body segments are affected. Several segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.
If the injury on this patient's left thigh were a second-degree burn rather than a first-degree burn, application of the rule of nines would estimate 45% of TBSA.
Application of the rule of nines estimates 72% of TBSA if eight body segments are affected. Fewer segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.
Application of the rule of nines estimates 54% of TBSA if six body segments are affected. Fewer segments of this patient's body are affected by second-degree burns.

The rule of nines divides the body into 11 regions (head, anterior chest, abdomen, upper back, lower back, right arm, left arm, right thigh, left thigh, right lower leg, left lower leg), each of which is estimated to be 9% of TBSA. This patient has deep second-degree burns (characterized by blisters and nonblanching underlying skin) on his chest, abdomen, and entire right leg, which corresponds to 36% of TBSA. He also has a first-degree burn on his left thigh.

images.title: Rule of nines
images.description: The entire body surface of an adult can be divided into 11 regions, each comprising approximately 9% of the total body surface area. The external genitalia accounts for the remaining 1%. The rule of nines is used to quickly estimate the total body surface area affected by burns in adults.
