question_text: Two weeks after admission to the intensive care unit for a hemorrhagic stroke, a 54-year-old man regains consciousness. At the time of admission, a CT scan of the head showed evidence of intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a ruptured aneurysm. The patient is mechanically ventilated via a tracheostomy tube. Neurologic examination shows quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a Babinski sign in both legs. He responds to questions by blinking, but neck, lingual, and other facial movements are lost. Doll's eye testing shows restricted horizontal movement and preserved vertical movement. On mental status examination, he is alert and comprehends the physician's questions. This patient's condition is most likely caused by bleeding in a region supplied by which of the following arteries?
content_preview: Two weeks after admission to the intensive care unit for a hemorrhagic stroke, a 54-year-old man regains consciousness. At the time of admission, a CT scan of the head showed evidence of intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a ruptured aneurysm. The patient is mechanically ventilated via a tracheostomy tube. Neurologic examination shows quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a Babinski sign in both legs. He responds to questions by blinking, but neck, lingual, and other facial movements are lost. Doll's eye testing shows restricted horizontal movement and preserved vertical movement. On mental status examination, he is alert and comprehends the physician's questions. This patient's condition is most likely caused by bleeding in a region supplied by which of the following arteries?
hint: This patient presents after a period of coma with quadriplegia and anarthria in conjunction with the preservation of consciousness, cognition, vertical eye movements, and blinking, all of which are characteristic of locked-in syndrome. This condition is typically a result of bilateral damage to the ventral pons.
learning_objective: Recognize locked-in syndrome, and recall the artery typically involved.

answers.explanation_why: The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is a paired artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies the occipital lobe, ventral midbrain, thalamus, and inferomedial temporal lobe. Ruptured PCA aneurysms commonly manifest with unilateral findings including contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (due to infarction of the visual cortex in the occipital lobe), contralateral paresis (due to infarction of the corticospinal tract in the midbrain), and contralateral sensory loss (due to infarction of the ventral posterolateral nucleus or the ascending sensory tracts). If damage occurs to the dominant (most commonly left) hemisphere, patients present with alexia without agraphia, anomic aphasia, and visual agnosia. If damage occurs to the nondominant (most commonly right) hemisphere, patients present with prosopagnosia. A PCA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

The anterior communicating artery (ACom) is a single artery that provides the anastomosis between left and right anterior cerebral circulation. This artery gives rise to small and large branches (e.g., median artery of the corpus callosum and subcallosal artery) that supply the anterior columns of the fornix, cingulate gyrus, hypothalamus, lamina terminalis, optic chiasm, and paraolfactory area. The junction between the ACom and one of the paired anterior cerebral arteries (ACAs) is the most common site of cerebral saccular aneurysms, which can manifest with bitemporal hemianopia (due to compression of the optic chiasm). Aneurysm rupture causes findings characteristic of infarction of the arterial territory of the ACA, including contralateral paralysis and sensory deficits more prominent in the lower than the upper extremity (due to infarction of the motor and sensory cortices of the lower extremity) and urinary incontinence. An ACom hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is a paired artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. The PICA supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. PICA aneurysm rupture causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), which manifests with hoarseness, hiccups, decreased gag reflex (due to infarction of the nucleus ambiguus), vertigo, nystagmus, and vomiting (due to infarction of cranial nerve VIII nuclei). Unilateral findings include ipsilateral Horner syndrome (due to infarction of the descending sympathetic nervous system), ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria (due to infarction of the inferior cerebellar peduncle), ipsilateral decreased pain and temperature sensation in the face (due to infarction of the spinal nucleus and descending tract of cranial nerve V), and contralateral decreased pain and temperature sensation in the body (due to infarction of the lateral medullary spinothalamic tract). PICA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a paired artery that contributes to the anterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies a large part of the lateral cortex (including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, temporal lobe, frontal lobe, putamen, globus pallidus, and parts of the internal capsule and caudate nucleus). MCA aneurysm rupture causes contralateral paralysis and sensory deficits more prominent in the face and upper extremity (due to infarction of the motor and sensory cortices of the upper body parts). If damage occurs in the dominant (most commonly left) hemisphere, patients present with aphasia. If damage occurs in the nondominant (most commonly right) hemisphere, patients present with hemineglect. An MCA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

The anterior spinal artery (ASA) is a single artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and the lower medulla at the midline. Bleeding from an aneurysm of the ASA can cause bilateral medial medullary syndrome with quadriplegia (due to bilateral infarction of the corticospinal tract), loss of proprioception (due to bilateral infarction of the medial lemniscus), and anarthria (due to bilateral infarction of the nucleus of cranial nerve XII in the lower medulla). However, ASA hemorrhage would not explain this patient's bulbar palsy, paralysis of the face and neck muscles, or loss of horizontal eye movements.

The basilar artery is located on the ventral surface of the pons and contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. A ruptured basilar artery aneurysm can cause locked-in syndrome by causing bilateral damage to the midbrain, which contains cranial nerve III (CN III) and CN IV nuclei, pons (containing CN V, VI, VII, and VIII nuclei), medulla (containing CN IX, X, XI, and XII nuclei), and corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. Peripheral motor symptoms (e.g., quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and positive Babinski signs in both legs) are caused by bilateral interruption of the corticospinal tracts. Bulbar palsy and paralysis of the face and neck muscles are caused by bilateral interruption of the corticobulbar tracts and damage to the motoric cranial nerve nuclei of CN V, VII, IX, X, XI, and XII. Horizontal gaze palsy is caused by damage to ocular cranial nerve nuclei (CN VI) and associated visual paths in the paramedian pontine reticular formation. Despite the extensive injury, many vital functions persist due to collateral blood supply to the midbrain tectum (preserved blinking and vertical eye movement), reticular activating system (preserved consciousness), cerebral cortex (preserved language comprehension and cognition), and spinothalamic tracts coursing through the dorsal pons (preserved sensation). See “Clinical features of stroke by affected vessel” table.

Management of locked-in syndrome includes physiotherapy, which consists of passive stretching exercises and frequent repositioning to avoid decubitus ulcers. Patients learn to communicate using blinking, vertical eye movements, eye-gaze sensor-controlled computer communication programs, and speech synthesizers. Some patients may recover some motor control, breathing, swallowing, and/or speaking ability.

images.title: Arterial supply of the brain
images.description:
Caudal viewThe circle of Willis is formed around the pituitary stalk by the following paired arteries:
- Anterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the internal carotids)
- Internal carotid arteries (proximal to the origin of the middle cerebral arteries)
- Posterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the vertebral arteries)The anterior communicating artery (ventral to the optic chiasm) connects the anterior cerebral arteries.The posterior communicating artery (a branch of internal carotid artery; lies on the lateral aspect of the pituitary stalk) connects the internal carotid artery and the posterior cerebral artery.The basilar artery, formed by the fusion of the two vertebral arteries, lies in the midline groove of the dorsal aspect of the pons. Pontine and labyrinthine branches arise from the basilar artery.The anterior spinal artery, formed by the fusion of the branches of the vertebral artery, lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of pain in his right arm and numbness and tingling in his right hand. He recently started his job as a painter. One month ago, he had to quit his job because the symptoms worsened whenever he tried to reach above his head. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke and drinks two beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to fine touch in the 4^th and 5^th fingers of his right hand. Radial pulse intensity decreases when the patient's right arm is abducted and externally rotated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of pain in his right arm and numbness and tingling in his right hand. He recently started his job as a painter. One month ago, he had to quit his job because the symptoms worsened whenever he tried to reach above his head. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke and drinks two beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to fine touch in the 4th and 5th fingers of his right hand. Radial pulse intensity decreases when the patient's right arm is abducted and externally rotated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Physical examination shows a positive Adson test (i.e., decreased pulse intensity with arm abduction and external rotation).
learning_objective: Recognize a cervical rib causing thoracic outlet syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) results in median nerve compression and often manifests with paresthesia of the fingers, which can worsen with prolonged overhead hand elevation (positive hand elevation test). However, this paresthesia would be present in the 1^st, 2^nd, and 3^rd digits rather than the 4^th and 5^th digits. Moreover, this patient's arm pain and the positive Adson test are not consistent with CTS.

images.title: Carpal tunnel syndrome
images.description: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).

answers.explanation_why: A cervical rib is a common cause of thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which occurs because of compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (derived from the C8–T1 nerve roots) and/or subclavian vessels in the area of the scalene triangle. Compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus can cause neuropathic pain, paresthesias, and sensory loss in the C8 and T1 dermatomes (i.e., 4^th and 5^th fingers, medial aspect of the arm), as seen here, and possibly weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. The symptoms in the case of a cervical rib are usually exacerbated by overhead arm elevation. Compression of the subclavian vessels is less common; subclavian vein compression results in swelling of the arm, and subclavian artery compression can cause acute or chronic limb ischemia and, possibly, subclavian steal syndrome. A positive Adson test, as seen here, is suggestive of a cervical rib. Other common causes of TOS are Pancoast tumor, muscular anomalies (e.g., supernumerary scalene muscles, neck muscle hypertrophy), and trauma (e.g., clavicle fracture).

images.title: Thoracic outlet syndrome secondary to muscle hypertrophy or cervical rib

answers.explanation_why: Patients with polymyositis have progressive symmetric proximal muscle weakness and report difficulty reaching for objects above their head rather than worsening pain and paresthesia when performing this action. Moreover, this patient's positive Adson test is not consistent with polymyositis.

Compression of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (Erb palsy) can also result in pain and paresthesia. However, the paresthesia would occur in the lateral aspects of the arm, forearm, and/or hand (C5 and C6 dermatomes), not the 4^th and 5^th (medial) digits. In addition, patients with Erb palsy typically present with an internally rotated and adducted arm, extended forearm, and a flexed wrist (“waiter's tip posture”).

images.title: Waiter's tip deformity in Erb palsy

answers.explanation_why: Protrusion of the C7/T1 intervertebral disc can compress the C8 spinal root and cause pain and paresthesia in the 4^th and 5^th digits (C8 dermatome). However, in the case of cervical spinal root compression (radiculopathy), patients usually have neck pain and the paresthesia is relieved by overhead arm elevation, unlike the exacerbation experienced in this patient reaching above the head. Parasthesias in cervical disc protrusion are instead exacerbated by extending the neck to the side and applying downward pressure to the head (Spurling maneuver). Moreover, a positive Adson test is not consistent with a cervical disc protrusion.

images.title: Dermatome map
images.description: Schematic representation of the body's dermatomes (i.e., areas of skin that are innervated by a single sensory spinal root)Note: Nearly all dermatome maps refer to publications by Head and Campbell (1900), Foerster (1933), or Keegan and Garrett (1948), which differ significantly in some areas. After careful review of the current literature, this illustration has been based on Keegan and Garrett's work, as it is most likely to be based on valid methodology and correlates with established clinical findings.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain for 1 hour. She has hypertension and coronary heart disease. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Her pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient is taken to the operating room for emergency open surgery. During the procedure, an artery that branches off from the aorta, just below the renal arteries, at the level of the L2 vertebra is damaged. The arterial supply to which of the following structures is most likely to be impaired by the intraoperative vascular damage?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain for 1 hour. She has hypertension and coronary heart disease. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Her pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient is taken to the operating room for emergency open surgery. During the procedure, an artery that branches off from the aorta, just below the renal arteries, at the level of the L2 vertebra is damaged. The arterial supply to which of the following structures is most likely to be impaired by the intraoperative vascular damage?
hint: The damaged artery passes through the infundibulopelvic ligament.
learning_objective: Recall the origin and distribution of the ovarian artery.

answers.explanation_why: The ascending colon is supplied mostly by the right colic artery, which branches off from the superior mesenteric artery. The superior mesenteric artery is a direct branch of the abdominal aorta and arises suprarenally at the level of the L1 vertebra. The artery in question, however, is located at the level of the L2 vertebra.

images.title: Arterial blood supply of the colon
images.description: The mesenteric arteries and their branches supply parts of the pancreas, the jejunum, the ileum, the cecum, the vermiform appendix, the colon, and the rectum. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the intestine up to the transverse colon, while the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the descending colon, the sigmoid colon, and the upper rectum.Proximal to the Cannon point, parasympathetic innervation is provided by the vagus nerve. Distal to that point, the pelvic splanchnic nerves provide innervation.

answers.explanation_why: The liver receives 40% of its blood supply from the hepatic artery proper, a branch of the common hepatic artery, which is, in turn, a branch of the celiac trunk of the abdominal aorta. The celiac trunk arises suprarenally at the level of the T12 vertebra. The injured artery in this patient, however, arises at the level of the L2 vertebra.

images.title: Branches of the celiac trunk
images.description: The celiac trunk and its three major branches: the left gastric artery, the splenic artery, and the common hepatic artery

answers.explanation_why: Both ovarian arteries branch off directly from the abdominal aorta just below the renal arteries at the level of the L2 vertebra. An injury to one of the ovarian arteries, as seen here, would significantly deprive the respective ovary of its arterial blood supply. The ovarian artery, which forms an anastomosis with the uterine artery, also supplies the lateral two-thirds of the fallopian tube as well as the proximal part of the uterus.

The adrenal glands are supplied by three arteries: the superior suprarenal artery (from the inferior phrenic artery), middle suprarenal artery (from the abdominal aorta), and inferior suprarenal artery (from the renal artery). All of these arteries arise between the T12 and the lower border of the L1 vertebrae. The injured artery in this patient, however, arises at the level of the L2 vertebra.

images.title: Abdominal aorta and inferior vena cava
images.description:
Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veinsNote: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.

answers.explanation_why: The cervix is supplied by the uterine artery, which is a branch of the internal iliac artery. The internal iliac artery branches off in the pelvic region from the common iliac artery, which arises from the abdominal aorta at the level of the L4 vertebra. The artery injured in this patient, however, arises at the level of the L2 vertebra.

images.title: Blood supply of the female reproductive organs (dorsal view)
images.description: The arterial supply of the female reproductive organs mainly comes from branches of the uterine artery. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery and crosses the ureter anteriorly in the broad ligament at the level of the cervix. The ovary and fallopian tubes are supplied by branches of the ovarian artery that arise from the abdominal aorta and anastomose with the ovarian branches of the uterine artery.Note that the vessels adjacent to the uterus are tortuous to accommodate the massive growth of the uterus during pregnancy.

answers.explanation_why: The descending colon is supplied mostly by the left colic artery, which branches off from the inferior mesenteric artery. The inferior mesenteric artery is a direct branch of the abdominal aorta and arises at the level of the L3 vertebra. The artery in question, however, is located at the level of the L2 vertebra.

images.title: Arterial blood supply of the colon
images.description: The mesenteric arteries and their branches supply parts of the pancreas, the jejunum, the ileum, the cecum, the vermiform appendix, the colon, and the rectum. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the intestine up to the transverse colon, while the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the descending colon, the sigmoid colon, and the upper rectum.Proximal to the Cannon point, parasympathetic innervation is provided by the vagus nerve. Distal to that point, the pelvic splanchnic nerves provide innervation.

answers.explanation_why: The spleen receives its arterial blood supply from the splenic artery, which branches off from the celiac trunk. The celiac trunk, in turn, branches off from the aorta suprarenally at the superior border of the T12 vertebra. The artery in question, however, is located at the level of the L2 vertebra.

images.title: Arterial supply of the duodenum, pancreas, and spleen
images.description: Branches arising from the superior pancreaticoduodenal (celiac trunk) and inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery (superior mesenteric artery) supply the pancreatic head and neck. These vessels also supply the duodenum. The dorsal pancreatic artery and the greater pancreatic artery supply the tail of the pancreas. The splenic artery supplies the spleen.

question_text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe groin pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports that he has had a groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining for the past 3 months, but he has not sought medical attention for it. Examination shows a nonreducible bulging mass of the left groin that is severely tender to palpation; the overlying skin is erythematous. Abdominal ultrasound shows protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely site of protrusion of the patient's groin mass?
content_preview: A 79-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe groin pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports that he has had a groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining for the past 3 months, but he has not sought medical attention for it. Examination shows a nonreducible bulging mass of the left groin that is severely tender to palpation; the overlying skin is erythematous. Abdominal ultrasound shows protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely site of protrusion of the patient's groin mass?
hint: A groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining is suggestive of a hernia, and severe pain with features of bowel obstruction (e.g., nausea, vomiting) indicates strangulation of this hernia. The type of hernia seen here typically occurs as a result of weakening of the transversalis fascia.
learning_objective: Recognize a direct inguinal hernia, and recall its anatomical site of protrusion.

answers.explanation_why: The inguinal triangle (Hesselbach triangle) is the site of protrusion of direct inguinal hernias, as seen here. This triangle is bordered laterally by the inferior epigastric vessels, medially by the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis sheath, and inferiorly by the inguinal ligament, and covered anteriorly by the transversalis fascia, conjoined tendon, and the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. Unlike indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through both the superficial and deep inguinal rings and are, therefore, covered by all layers of the spermatic cord, direct inguinal hernias pass only through the superficial inguinal ring and, at this point, are only covered by the external spermatic fascia.

images.title: Direct and indirect inguinal hernias
images.description: Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cordIndirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

answers.explanation_why: The segment of the linea alba between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus is the site of protrusion of epigastric hernias, which cause swelling in the epigastric area rather than the groin.

images.title: Epigastric hernia
images.description: Herniation of intraabdominal contents through the linea alba, between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus.

answers.explanation_why: The hernia in this patient protrudes at a site that is lateral to the rectus abdominis muscle and covered by the transversalis fascia, conjoined tendon, and the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle; it does not protrude through the rectus abdominis.

The deep inguinal ring is the site of protrusion of indirect inguinal hernias, which manifest as a groin mass, like the one seen here. However, the deep inguinal ring is located lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels; this patient, however, has a hernia that protrudes medial to these vessels and does not pass through the deep inguinal ring.

images.title: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord
images.description:
Left illustration: anatomy of the inguinal canal and spermatic cord
The inguinal canal extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.
– Anterior wall: aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique muscle
– Posterior wall: the transversalis fascia
– Roof: the transversalis fascia, transversus abdominis muscles, and the internal oblique muscle
– Floor: inguinal ligament
– Content: in men, the ilioinguinal nerve, genitofemoral nerve, and spermatic cord; in women, the round ligament of the uterus
The spermatic cord contains the vas deferens, three arteries (testicular artery, artery to the ductus deferens, and cremasteric artery), the pampiniform plexus, and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Right illustration: the three coverings of the spermatic cord
From superficial to deep, the coverings are the external spermatic fascia (orange), cremasteric fascia (blue), and internal spermatic fascia (green).

answers.explanation_why: The inferior lumbar triangle is the site of protrusion of inferior lumbar hernias, which cause swelling in the lumbar region rather than the groin.

images.title: Lumbar hernias
images.description: Superior lumbar hernia (Grynfeltt hernia): herniation of intraabdominal contents through the superior lumbar triangle, the boundaries of which are the 12^th rib, the erector spinae muscle, and the internal oblique muscleInferior lumbar hernia (Petit hernia): herniation of intraabdominal contents through the inferior lumbar triangle, the boundaries of which are the iliac crest, the latissimus dorsi, and the external oblique muscle

answers.explanation_why: The femoral ring is the site of protrusion of femoral hernias, which manifest as a groin mass and are prone to strangulation, like the mass seen here. Femoral hernias, however, protrude inferior to the inguinal ligament and medial to the femoral vein rather than medial to the inferior epigastric vessels, and they typically occur in women rather than men.

images.title: Femoral hernia
images.description: Femoral hernia passes through the vascular lacuna (internal hernial orifice), below the inguinal ligament and usually medial to the femoral vein and runs through the femoral canal until it reaches the saphenous opening (external hernial orifice; approx. 2cm caudal).The saphenous opening typically contains loose connective and fatty tissue as well as inguinal lymph nodes.Due to the increased width of the female pelvis, and therefore larger vascular lacuna, femoral hernia occurs predominantly in women.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and progressive headaches. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 38 years. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic lung cancer is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and progressive headaches. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 38 years. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic lung cancer is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
hint: This patient's visual field defects indicate a lesion in the parietal lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia, and recall the associated lesion location in the visual pathway.

answers.explanation_why: The inferior bundle of right optic radiations (right Meyer loop) is located in the right temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the left superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the right lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right Meyer loop would result in left upper homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie in the sky”), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The inferior bundle of left optic radiations (left Meyer loop) is located in the left temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the right superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left Meyer loop would result in right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie in the sky”), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The superior bundle of left optic radiations (left dorsal optic radiation) is located in the left parietal lobe and relays information from the right inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left superior bundle of optic radiations results in right lower homonymous quadrantanopsia, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The left optic tract transmits information from the right half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the temporal half of the left retina and nasal half of the right retina). Therefore, damage to the left optic tract would result in right homonymous hemianopsia, which is not seen here.

The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations. The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field, i.e., from the right superior quadrant of both retinas. Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie on the floor”), as seen here.

images.title: Overview of visual field defects
images.description:
(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

answers.explanation_why: The left macula transmits visual information from the center of the left eye's visual field. Therefore, damage to the left macula (e.g., due to macular degeneration) would result in a left central scotoma, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The right optic tract transmits information from the left half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the nasal half of the left retina and temporal half of the right retina). Therefore, damage to the right optic tract would result in left homonymous hemianopsia, which is not seen here.

The right macula transmits visual information from the center of the right eye's visual field. Therefore, damage to the right macula (e.g., due to macular degeneration) would result in a right central scotoma, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

question_text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of penile pain. The pain has become worse over the past 2 weeks, especially on erection. He says that his penis curves downward and does not stay erect during sexual intercourse. He feels embarrassed about his penis and has avoided dates and sexual relationships. Previously, he was sexually active with multiple female partners. Physical examination shows a palpable plaque in the distal third of the penis. A disorder of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of penile pain. The pain has become worse over the past 2 weeks, especially on erection. He says that his penis curves downward and does not stay erect during sexual intercourse. He feels embarrassed about his penis and has avoided dates and sexual relationships. Previously, he was sexually active with multiple female partners. Physical examination shows a palpable plaque in the distal third of the penis. A disorder of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: The combination of penile pain and a palpable plaque with progressive erectile dysfunction due to penile curvature is consistent with Peyronie disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Peyronie disease, and recall the affected penile structure.

answers.explanation_why: The dartos fascia is a thin layer of connective tissue located just below the skin that surrounds the penis and scrotum. Peyronie disease does not affect this structure.

Peyronie disease is a fibroproliferative disorder that affects the tunica albuginea of the penis. The etiology of Peyronie disease is not well understood but has been associated with penile trauma, including both acute traumatic events and repetitive microtrauma during sexual activity. The consequent wound healing is thought to result in abnormal fibrous plaque formation. Affected patients may experience pain, irregular engorgement, and erectile dysfunction due to an abnormal curvature of the penis. Treatment includes oral pentoxifylline or intralesional collagenase injections; surgical repair may be necessary in refractory cases.

images.title: Peyronie disease
images.description: Photograph of an erect penis showing an abnormal downward curvature.

answers.explanation_why: The preputium penis (the foreskin) is retractable tissue that covers the glans penis. Conditions that affect the foreskin include balanoposthitis and phimosis, not Peyronie disease.

The corpus spongiosum is a sponge-like tissue ventral to the corpus cavernosa. The corpus spongiosum contains the urethra and prevents its collapse during erection. Conditions that affect the corpus spongiosum include priapism, not Peyronie disease.

The glans penis is the distal end of the corpus spongiosum. It is attached to the frenulum, covered by the foreskin, and contains the external urethral meatus. Conditions that affect the glans penis include balanitis and balanoposthitis, not Peyronie disease.

The corpus cavernosum is a paired structure dorsal to the corpus spongiosum and contains the erectile tissue of the penis. Corpus cavernosa (as well as the tunica albuginea) are affected in penile fractures. Peyronie disease does not affect this structure.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset neck pain, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty walking for the past hour. She cannot sit upright without propping herself up on her hands. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation. She does not smoke. She drinks a glass of wine every other evening. Current medications include enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and warfarin. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 205/148 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows nystagmus, neck stiffness, head tilting, and a broad-based gait. She is unable to perform a balance test or Romberg test. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an injury to which of the following areas?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset neck pain, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty walking for the past hour. She cannot sit upright without propping herself up on her hands. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation. She does not smoke. She drinks a glass of wine every other evening. Current medications include enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and warfarin. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 205/148 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows nystagmus, neck stiffness, head tilting, and a broad-based gait. She is unable to perform a balance test or Romberg test. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an injury to which of the following areas?
hint: Sudden-onset headache and nonspecific neurological symptoms (e.g., meningismus, nausea, vomiting) in a hypertensive patient receiving anticoagulation therapy raise suspicion for hemorrhage within the central nervous system.
learning_objective: Recognize cerebellar vermis injury, and recall its associated symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: The posterior spinal cord carries the dorsal column, which is responsible for proprioception and sensation of pressure, vibration, and fine touch. Injury to the posterior spinal cord can, therefore, cause sensory ataxia that is worse in dimly lit settings, where a patient's proprioception cannot compensate for the loss of visual bearings. However, this patient's broad-based gait and inability to perform a Romberg test are not environment-dependent. In addition, there is no indication that she has other sensory deficits. Moreover, posterior spinal cord injury is not associated with nystagmus, head tilting, or truncal ataxia (e.g., inability to sit upright without propping oneself up on the hands).

The pyramidal tracts control voluntary muscular movement to the face via the corticobulbar tract and to the body via the corticospinal tract. Injury to the corticobulbar tract typically results in manifestations of pseudobulbar palsy (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia, lack of facial expression). Injury to the corticospinal tract classically manifests with upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spasticity, hypertonia, hyperreflexia, clonus, Babinski sign) on the contralateral side. This patient's neurologic examination is not consistent with injury to either pyramidal tract.

images.title: Pyramidal tract
images.description: Fibers of the pyramidal tract originate from the primary motor cortex and descend to the brain stem via the internal capsule. Bulbar corticonuclear fibers extend to each of the cranial nerve nuclei, which innervate the facial muscles. The remaining fibers descend from the brainstem as two divisions of the corticospinal tract. Approximately 80% of these fibers decussate at the level of the medulla (pyramidal decussation) to the contralateral side to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They then descend into the spinal cord to innervate the limbs and digits. The remaining approximately 20% of fibers descend from the brainstem ipsilaterally, forming the anterior corticospinal tract. These decussate at the spinal level of the trunk muscles they innervate.

answers.explanation_why: The cerebellar vermis is the midline region of the cerebellum that is involved in the coordination of the vestibular system, eye movements, balance, and complex and sequential movements. This patient's findings of truncal ataxia (evidenced by her inability to sit upright without propping herself up on her hands), nystagmus, and head tilting indicate injury to this region. Lesions of the vermis and corresponding deep nuclei affect medial structures of the body (e.g., axial and proximal limb musculature), resulting in truncal ataxia and nystagmus. Lesions of the lateral hemispheres affect lateral structures of the body (e.g., distal limb musculature), resulting in ipsilateral limb ataxia.

images.title: Cerebellum
images.description: Dorsocaudal view (without brainstem)

answers.explanation_why: The flocculonodular lobe is involved in regulating balance, ocular movements, and gaze stability, and lesions in this region can cause nystagmus. However, this patient presents with truncal ataxia and head bobbing, which do not typically manifest in this type of injury. Additionally, flocculonodular lesions are usually associated with vertigo, which this patient does not have.

The frontal lobe is involved in several processes, including motor function, memory, and attention. Injury to the bilateral parts of the frontal lobe can result in a frontal gait, which manifests with a broad-based gait and difficulty with balance. However, a frontal lobe injury also typically causes problems with initiating gait, slow steps, and inappropriate compensatory mechanisms for changes in posture while walking. In addition, frontal lobe injury is also associated with the reemergence of primitive reflexes and deficits in concentration and judgment. Moreover, conditions that cause bilateral frontal lobe injury, such as Alzheimer dementia, frontotemporal dementia, and normal pressure hydrocephalus, commonly manifest in a more chronic to subacute timeframe.

The right and left cerebellar hemispheres are involved in complex motor functions that involve the limbs. Cerebellar hemisphere injury can cause loss of balance but does not typically result in downbeat nystagmus, head tilting, or truncal ataxia (e.g., inability to sit upright without propping oneself up on the hands). Moreover, this patient does not have other common manifestations of cerebellar hemisphere injury, including limb ataxia (e.g., dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, intention tremor), which typically affects the ipsilateral side, and dysarthria.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling in the groin for the past 4 weeks. The swelling causes discomfort, but no pain. She was treated for pneumonia 6 weeks ago. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and inhaled tiotropium. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. Femoral pulses are 2+. There is a nonpulsatile, soft, and nontender groin mass on the left side. The mass arises below the inguinal ligament and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling in the groin for the past 4 weeks. The swelling causes discomfort, but no pain. She was treated for pneumonia 6 weeks ago. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and inhaled tiotropium. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. Femoral pulses are 2+. There is a nonpulsatile, soft, and nontender groin mass on the left side. The mass arises below the inguinal ligament and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This condition carries a high risk of complications (e.g., obstruction, strangulation) and requires early elective surgical repair.
learning_objective: Recognize femoral hernia due to widening of the femoral ring.

answers.content: Enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes
answers.explanation_why: Enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes (i.e., inguinal lymphadenopathy), which can manifest as a palpable, nonpulsatile groin mass, is commonly caused by an infection or malignancy in the lower extremities or the perineal region. This patient has no evidence of malignancy or a focus of infection in these regions. Moreover, the mass enlarges with coughing, which is not an expected finding in a mass due to enlarged lymph nodes.

answers.content: Accumulation of pus within the iliopsoas muscle
answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of pus within the iliopsoas muscle (i.e., psoas abscess) can manifest with a palpable groin mass. Diabetes mellitus, which this patient has, is a risk factor for developing a psoas abscess. However, this patient does not have the typical features of a psoas abscess, such as fever, lower back or abdominal pain, antalgic gait, flexion of the hip, or restricted hip movement. Although a psoas abscess can extend into the thigh (i.e., below the inguinal ligament), it arises above the inguinal ligament, unlike the mass seen in this patient that arises below the inguinal ligament.

Weakness of the transversalis fascia can lead to the development of a direct inguinal hernia. This weakening is commonly secondary to conditions that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., obesity or coughing in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). However, inguinal hernias arise above the inguinal ligament, not below as seen here.

images.title: Direct and indirect inguinal hernias
images.description: Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cordIndirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

answers.explanation_why: Dilation of the femoral artery leads to a femoral artery aneurysm, which can manifest with a painless groin swelling below the inguinal ligament. However, arterial aneurysms are pulsatile with a palpable thrill, not nonpulsatile like the mass in this patient.

Widening of the femoral ring occurs with increasing age and may result in femoral hernia, which has a higher incidence in women, who have a wider pelvis compared to men and, therefore, a larger vascular lacuna. Typical symptoms include painless groin swelling. They manifest as a palpable mass below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein; an expansive cough impulse is a common finding. In addition to obesity, chronic cough resulting from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease increases intraabdominal pressure, consequently increasing the risk of developing a femoral hernia.

images.title: Femoral hernia
images.description: Femoral hernia passes through the vascular lacuna (internal hernial orifice), below the inguinal ligament and usually medial to the femoral vein and runs through the femoral canal until it reaches the saphenous opening (external hernial orifice; approx. 2cm caudal).The saphenous opening typically contains loose connective and fatty tissue as well as inguinal lymph nodes.Due to the increased width of the female pelvis, and therefore larger vascular lacuna, femoral hernia occurs predominantly in women.

answers.content: Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis
answers.explanation_why: Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis during fetal development is the most common cause of indirect inguinal hernia. Although indirect inguinal hernias can extend below the inguinal ligament into the genital region, inguinal hernias arise above the inguinal ligament, not below as seen here.

images.title: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord
images.description:
Left illustration: anatomy of the inguinal canal and spermatic cord
The inguinal canal extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.
– Anterior wall: aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique muscle
– Posterior wall: the transversalis fascia
– Roof: the transversalis fascia, transversus abdominis muscles, and the internal oblique muscle
– Floor: inguinal ligament
– Content: in men, the ilioinguinal nerve, genitofemoral nerve, and spermatic cord; in women, the round ligament of the uterus
The spermatic cord contains the vas deferens, three arteries (testicular artery, artery to the ductus deferens, and cremasteric artery), the pampiniform plexus, and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Right illustration: the three coverings of the spermatic cord
From superficial to deep, the coverings are the external spermatic fascia (orange), cremasteric fascia (blue), and internal spermatic fascia (green).

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness and weakness in her right hand for the past 4 weeks. During this time, she has also had intermittent pain in her right arm for which treatment with ibuprofen has provided some relief. She is a professional tennis player but has not been able to practice because her symptoms get worse when she swings the racquet overhead. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/73 mm Hg. Physical examination of the right hand shows decreased sensation to light touch in the 4^th and 5^th fingers. Repeated opening and closing of the hands with the arms raised above the shoulder causes pain and a sensation of heaviness in the right arm. Percussion over the right medial epicondyle of the humerus does not reproduce the symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness and weakness in her right hand for the past 4 weeks. During this time, she has also had intermittent pain in her right arm for which treatment with ibuprofen has provided some relief. She is a professional tennis player but has not been able to practice because her symptoms get worse when she swings the racquet overhead. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/73 mm Hg. Physical examination of the right hand shows decreased sensation to light touch in the 4th and 5th fingers. Repeated opening and closing of the hands with the arms raised above the shoulder causes pain and a sensation of heaviness in the right arm. Percussion over the right medial epicondyle of the humerus does not reproduce the symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The distribution of paresthesia and pain in this patient's right hand suggests a lesion involving the C8 and T1 nerves. In addition, the positive Roos stress test (arm heaviness with repeated opening and closing of the hands) is suggestive of neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
learning_objective: Recognize neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Upper trunk decompression is used in the treatment of upper trunk brachial plexus compression, which typically causes Erb palsy and manifests with pain and paresthesia. However, the paresthesia usually develops along the lateral aspects of the arm, forearm, and/or hand (C5–C6 dermatomes), not the 4^th and 5^th digits. Moreover, patients with Erb palsy typically present with an internally rotated and adducted arm, extended forearm, and a flexed wrist (“waiter's tip posture”).

images.title: Waiter's tip deformity in Erb palsy

answers.explanation_why: Epidural glucocorticoid injections can be used to treat cervical radiculopathy, which typically manifests with pain, weakness, and paresthesia in the distribution of affected nerve roots. If the C8–T1 spinal roots are affected, pain and paresthesia develop in the 4^th and 5^th digits. However, patients with cervical radiculopathy will have an improvement in their symptoms with overhead arm elevation, and the Roos stress test is typically negative. Although an epidural glucocorticoid injection might relieve this patient's pain, it is not the next most appropriate step in management.

Elbow immobilization is used in the treatment of cubital tunnel syndrome, which can manifest with paresthesia in the 4^th and 5^th digits. However, patients with cubital tunnel syndrome do not have pain or heaviness in the arm that worsens when raised above the shoulders. In addition, this condition is associated with a positive Tinel test.

Volar splinting can be employed in the treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), which typically manifests with pain and paresthesia in the hand and can worsen with prolonged overhead hand elevation (positive hand elevation test). However, median nerve compression causes paresthesia in the 1^st, 2^nd, and 3^rd digits, rather than the 4^th and 5^th digits. Moreover, this patient's upper arm pain and positive Roos stress test are not consistent with CTS.

images.title: Carpal tunnel syndrome
images.description: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).

answers.explanation_why: Physical therapy is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient with neurogenic TOS. Therapy exercises should focus on strengthening shoulder muscles, stretching, and postural correction while sitting and standing in order to reduce pressure on the neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet. Adjunctive therapies include NSAIDs for analgesia and weight reduction. If conservative treatment fails, thoracic outlet decompression surgery may be considered.

images.title: Thoracic outlet syndrome secondary to hyperabduction
images.description: Hyperabduction of the arm can lead to compression of the neurovascular structures under the coracoid process through the pectoralis minor muscle.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling that developed on her right ear 3 days ago. She is a mixed martial arts athlete and has been training intensively for an upcoming tournament. The pain started soon after she received a blow to the ear during a training fight. She reports taking ibuprofen for the pain and tried “not to pay attention to it,” but the pain has worsened. Her personal and family history is unremarkable and she takes no other medications. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.0°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 113/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm mildly tender, fluctuant mass on the right antihelix with purple skin discoloration; there is a firm, irregular, nontender deformity of the left auricle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling that developed on her right ear 3 days ago. She is a mixed martial arts athlete and has been training intensively for an upcoming tournament. The pain started soon after she received a blow to the ear during a training fight. She reports taking ibuprofen for the pain and tried “not to pay attention to it,” but the pain has worsened. Her personal and family history is unremarkable and she takes no other medications. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.0°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 113/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm mildly tender, fluctuant mass on the right antihelix with purple skin discoloration; there is a firm, irregular, nontender deformity of the left auricle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: A purple, tender, fluctuant mass on the right antihelix is consistent with an auricular hematoma, which is commonly seen following a direct blow to the ear.
learning_objective: Recognize an auricular hematoma, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Needle aspiration is not routinely recommended for the management of auricular hematomas, as it may be difficult to aspirate sufficient fluid and there is a risk of reaccumulation.

While surgical excision of scar tissue could help to cosmetically improve this patient's left cauliflower ear, another intervention is required to prevent the auricular hematoma in the right ear from leading to the development of a cauliflower ear.

Antibiotic therapy with levofloxacin for 7–10 days is indicated in older adolescents and adults undergoing invasive treatment for an auricular hematoma, or in patients with signs of an infected auricular hematoma. This patient has not received any form of invasive treatment and has no signs of infection (e.g., pus, fever, severe tenderness).

Incision and drainage are indicated for auricular hematomas < 7 days old. Timely drainage of the hematoma prevents infection, relieves pressure, and preserves ear function and appearance, preventing the formation of cauliflower ear, which this patient already has in the left ear. Prophylactic antibiotics with coverage against skin flora and P. aeruginosa such as ciprofloxacin should also be considered. Patients should be followed up daily to assess for reaccumulation of the hematoma and/or signs of infection. If the hematoma does not reaccumulate, patients can return to sports after 7 days.

images.title: Auricular hematoma following trauma
images.description: There is swelling and ecchymosis of the auricle. Swelling is most pronounced in the anterosuperior aspect, where it obscures the normal anatomical landmarks.

answers.content: Analgesics, cooling, and close observation only
answers.explanation_why: Analgesics, cooling, and close observation alone are not sufficient for the management of auricular hematomas. As most individuals who develop auricular hematomas are involved in some sort of contact sport and frequently experience injury, they may not see the need to seek medical attention. Untreated auricular hematomas are associated with the formation of cauliflower ears, as the hematoma separates the perichondrium from the cartilage and removes the blood supply, leading to cartilage ischemia and necrosis with subsequent irreversible fibrosis.

question_text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive weakness on the right side of her face. During this time, she has also noticed increased dryness of her right eye. Her medical history is remarkable for migraine headaches for which she takes sumatriptan. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and does not drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows asymmetrical facial expression with a right-sided drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is deeply concerned that her current symptoms are going to be permanent. She asks what her long-term prognosis will be. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concern?
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive weakness on the right side of her face. During this time, she has also noticed increased dryness of her right eye. Her medical history is remarkable for migraine headaches for which she takes sumatriptan. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and does not drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows asymmetrical facial expression with a right-sided drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is deeply concerned that her current symptoms are going to be permanent. She asks what her long-term prognosis will be. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concern?
hint: Acute onset of progressive unilateral facial weakness, decreased lacrimation, drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling are consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.
learning_objective: Recognize the prognosis of Bell palsy, and choose the most appropriate response to a patient's concern about recovery.

answers.content: “I can make an accurate statement about your prognosis only after obtaining imaging studies of your head.”
answers.explanation_why: Facial nerve palsy can be caused by stroke. In patients with suspected stroke, imaging of the head (e.g., CT, MRI) is an important diagnostic tool. However, the palsy in stroke is of central rather than peripheral origin. Although the conditions have similar symptoms (e.g., drooping mouth), the inability to frown and close the eyelid are not features of central facial nerve palsy. Imaging studies are not routinely performed in Bell palsy.

answers.content: ”With oral prednisone therapy, approximately 2 out of 10 patients with your condition will fully recover within 1 year.”
answers.explanation_why: While oral glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) should be initiated within 72 hours of symptom onset to decrease inflammation and compression of the facial nerve in Bell palsy, the vast majority (≥ 80%) of patients recover completely with glucocorticoid treatment.

answers.content: ”Even without treatment, at least 7 out of 10 patients with your condition will fully recover within 1 year.”
answers.explanation_why:
Peripheral facial nerve palsy is most commonly idiopathic (i.e., Bell palsy). The diagnosis is made clinically after conducting a thorough medical history and physical examination. Bell palsy is treated with oral glucocorticoids (preferably within 72 hours of symptom onset) and most cases resolve within three weeks. Even without treatment, this condition resolves spontaneously in the majority of cases (∼ 70 %) in 3–6 months.

Because viral reactivation may be the cause of Bell palsy, antiviral therapy with acyclovir or valacyclovir should be considered in addition to oral glucocorticoids.

answers.content: ”These symptoms are likely to be permanent, as there is currently no effective treatment for your condition.”
answers.explanation_why: Oral glucocorticoids decrease inflammation and compression of the facial nerve and are successfully used in the treatment of Bell palsy. The vast majority of patients recover completely with glucocorticoid treatment.

answers.content: "These symptoms will likely resolve spontaneously within a few months, but almost 9 out of 10 patients with your condition develop facial contractures as a late complication."
answers.explanation_why: Facial synkinesis and contractures are late complications of Bell palsy that are caused by abnormal regrowth of the facial nerve. These complications manifest as the involuntary contraction of facial muscles during voluntary contraction of other facial muscles (e.g., the involuntary elevation of the angle of the mouth during forceful blinking). However, these complications only develop in a minority of patients (approx. 15%).

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 38 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I'm gasping for breath.”
History of Present Illness:

1-month history of progressively worsening breathlessness and nonproductive cough

dyspnea was initially only present during exercise but is now also present at rest 
increasing difficulty swallowing solid food for the past 3 weeks

headache and dizziness for the past week

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory

does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages
Physical Examination

Temp

Ht

BMI

36.8°C
(98.2°F)

89/min
24/min
122/73 mm Hg
95% on RA

164 cm
(5 ft 5 in)
82 kg
(180 lb)
30.5 kg/m^2

Appearance: in respiratory distress; uses accessory muscles of respiration; coughs frequently
Skin: no rash
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness; mild facial plethora
Neck: jugular venous distention 
Pulmonary: expiratory stridor
Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S_1 and S_2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated, normoactive bowel sounds
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits

Diagnostic Studies

chest x-ray: widened upper mediastinum on PA view and an obscured retrosternal airspace on lateral view
chest CT: bulky soft tissue mass with cystic changes in the anterior and superior mediastinum 
direct laryngoscopy: vocal cords are symmetrical and move during attempted phonation; no polyps or nodules

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 38 years Gender: F, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: emergency department History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I'm gasping for breath.” History of Present Illness: 1-month history of progressively worsening breathlessness and nonproductive cough dyspnea was initially only present during exercise but is now also present at rest increasing difficulty swallowing solid food for the past 3 weeks headache and dizziness for the past week Past Medical History: unremarkable Medications: none Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: noncontributory Psychosocial History: does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.8°C(98.2°F) 89/min 24/min 122/73 mm Hg 95% on RA 164 cm(5 ft 5 in) 82 kg(180 lb) 30.5 kg/m2 Appearance: in respiratory distress; uses accessory muscles of respiration; coughs frequently Skin: no rash HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness; mild facial plethora Neck: jugular venous distention Pulmonary: expiratory stridor Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated, normoactive bowel sounds Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits Diagnostic Studies chest x-ray: widened upper mediastinum on PA view and an obscured retrosternal airspace on lateral view chest CT: bulky soft tissue mass with cystic changes in the anterior and superior mediastinum direct laryngoscopy: vocal cords are symmetrical and move during attempted phonation; no polyps or nodules Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has features of airway obstruction (cough, stridor, dyspnea), esophageal obstruction (dysphagia), and superior vena cava syndrome (jugular venous distention, headache) as a result of a mediastinal mass.
learning_objective: Distinguish a mediastinal lymphoma from other causes of mediastinal masses.

answers.explanation_why:
Mediastinal lymphomas, such as nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphomas or primary mediastinal large B-cell lymphomas, appear on imaging as bulky, soft tissue masses with cystic changes. Approx. 50% of patients do not present with B-symptoms. Although mediastinal lymphomas can arise from any mediastinal compartment, airway compression is most commonly associated with superior, anterior, or middle mediastinal masses. Masses that cause superior vena cava syndrome are usually located in the anterior or middle compartments. Esophageal compression typically occurs with superior, middle, or posterior mediastinal masses. While thymoma may also cause anterior and superior mediastinal masses, it usually grows slowly (over several years), in contrast to the rapid development of progressive symptoms in this patient, which is consistent with lymphoma.

See “Compartments of the mediastinum” table.

Bronchial tumors can cause cough and respiratory distress as a result of bronchial obstruction, but they typically manifest with recurrent pneumonia, hemoptysis, and, in rare cases, symptoms of carcinoid syndrome. Moreover, the majority of carcinoid tumors appear on imaging as focal, well-defined round lesions, as opposed to a large mediastinal mass with cystic changes.
Esophageal cancer manifests with dysphagia but an esophageal pathology would be visible in the posterior mediastinum, not the anterior compartment.

Ortner syndrome is vocal cord palsy caused by compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve in the mediastinum. The underlying pathologies include a large left atrium or aortic aneurysm, which can also cause dysphagia due to esophageal compression. This patient does not have laryngoscopic findings of vocal cord palsy. Additionally, the heart is located in the middle mediastinum, while the aorta is located in the middle, superior, and posterior mediastinum. An anterior mediastinal mass would not be expected with a large atrium or aortic aneurysm.

A mediastinal neuroblastoma arises from the paravertebral ganglia and is usually located in the posterior mediastinum, not the anterior and superior compartments. Moreover, neuroblastoma is very rare in adults.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after falling from a ladder and hitting the back of his head on concrete. He was briefly unconscious, but is now alert and answers questions appropriately. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He works as a house painter. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances. On arrival, he is awake and oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 136/80 mm Hg. The patient is unable to place one foot directly in front of the other when asked to walk in a straight line. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus with fast beats toward the right. Right-sided finger-to-nose test shows dysmetria and tremor. Muscle strength and sensation are normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an injury to which of the following areas?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after falling from a ladder and hitting the back of his head on concrete. He was briefly unconscious, but is now alert and answers questions appropriately. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He works as a house painter. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances. On arrival, he is awake and oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 136/80 mm Hg. The patient is unable to place one foot directly in front of the other when asked to walk in a straight line. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus with fast beats toward the right. Right-sided finger-to-nose test shows dysmetria and tremor. Muscle strength and sensation are normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an injury to which of the following areas?
hint: This patient likely has a positive heel-knee-shin test on the right side.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical signs of cerebellar hemorrhage, and localize the lesion based on neurologic findings.

answers.explanation_why: The thalamus acts as a relay center for sensory signals and some motor signals to the cerebral cortex. A lesion in the left thalamus typically manifests with right-sided weakness and sensory loss, and it does not cause ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, or nystagmus.

The pons contains numerous ascending and descending tracts. A pontine lesion could cause ataxia by damaging the cerebellar peduncles. However, this patient does not have other typical signs of a pontine lesion, such as contralateral weakness (from corticospinal tract damage) and cranial nerve palsies (e.g., CN VI or VII). Isolated right-sided limb ataxia makes a pontine lesion unlikely.

The cerebellar vermis is responsible for coordinating axial and proximal trunk muscles, playing a key role in gait and balance. Lesions of the vermis typically cause truncal ataxia and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Vermis lesions are unlikely to cause limb ataxia or lateralized nystagmus.

The frontal lobe is involved in executive function, personality, voluntary movement (via the primary motor cortex), and speech (Broca area). Lesions in this region may lead to contralateral weakness, behavioral changes, or motor aphasia. Ipsilateral limb ataxia and nystagmus make a frontal lobe lesion unlikely.

The cerebellum modulates and coordinates voluntary limb movements, with each cerebellar hemisphere controlling the ipsilateral side of the body. This patient’s right-sided limb ataxia (finger-to-nose dysmetria and intention tremor) indicates right cerebellar hemisphere injury. The right-beating horizontal nystagmus further supports the diagnosis of a lesion on the right side. Other common manifestations of cerebellar hemisphere injury include gait ataxia, dysdiadochokinesia, hypotonia, and dysarthria. Cerebellar injury does not cause weakness or sensory loss.
